PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cook (from 13 citizens) and Jones (from 46 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: VHF, UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. The decision to change to the UHF transmission in 1993 should not be made compulsory in Tasmania.
2. That VHF airwaves in Tasmania are not overcrowded, unlike Mainland Australia.
3. That Tasmanian television stations presently transmit in VHF which is properly suited to Tasmania's mountainous terrain.
4. That the UHF band relies on ``the line of sight'' and is unsatisfactory for transmission to many parts of the state.
5. That compulsory UHF will mean financial outlays for many, and could result in some being denied a signal.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, reject the proposals which would force Tasmanians to convert to UHF transmission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killings of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cook (from 98 citizens) and Stone (from 1,295 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and the members of the Senate. We the undersigned oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe there should not be two levels of Medicare rebates for general practice. We also believe there should be upgraded undergraduate training and postgraduate training for general practitioners to obtain appropriate skills. Current and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate, and there should be appropriate Medicare rebates for doctors who provide out of hours consultations.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support general practitioners to achieve the above.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate. We, the undersigned registered medical practitioners of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe:
There should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for General Practice.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded, and continuing medical education should be an independent activity controlled by the profession.
The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the Act is unacceptable.
Vocational training for General Practice should be structured so that appropriate skills can be acquired in a reasonable and not an excessive time.
The present and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support the medical profession to achieve these resolutions.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate. We, the undersigned medical students of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe:
There should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for General Practice.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded, and continuing medical education should be an independent activity controlled by the profession.
The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the Act is unacceptable.
Vocational training for General Practice should be structured so that appropriate skills can be acquired in a reasonable and not an excessive time.
The present and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support the medical profession to achieve these resolutions.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Kings Avenue and Northcott Drive

SPEECH.SPEAKER: REID

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate a petition from 201 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, requesting that the possibility of linking Kings Avenue and Northcott Drive in the Australian Capital Territory be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned, note with concern that the Department of Defence wants to seal off two public roads to make Russell Offices ``more secure''. Recent comments attributed to the NCPA's director of urban design, Mr Brian Binning, would suggest that he is in favour of this. In particular, Mr Binning claims that Kelliher Drive ``is mainly used to get to a 300-car gravel carpark . . . and as a shortcut to Northcott Drive''. In fact, Northcott Drive is a logical extension of Kings Avenue which presently ends abruptly at Russell Drive near the Australian American Memorial. Furthermore, Northcott Drive is the main approach road for those members of the community who live in the southern suburbs and are employed at the Campbell Offices or the Australian Defence Force Academy. We, the undersigned, ask that serious consideration be given to the possibility of linking King's Avenue and Northcott Drive via traffic lanes passing either side of the Australian American Memorial.

DEBATE.TITLE: SMOKING AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS ADVERTISEMENTS (PROHIBITION) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to prohibit certain advertisements relating to smoking and tobacco products, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Mr President,

It is with pleasure that I introduce the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989. The Bill represents a major opportunity for the Federal Parliament to contribute to the improved health of the Australian community.

Each year in Australia more than 17,000 lives are lost through tobacco-related illnesses. An even larger number of people are severely incapacitated and the cost to the community in providing medical care is enormous. Cigarette smoking is clearly our number one health problem. Governments at both Federal and State levels are doing excellent work in encouraging present smokers to quit. It is estimated that 2.5 million Australians are ex-smokers.

However, at the same time as smokers are either quitting or dying, many younger Australians are replacing them. Smoking rates among young people, particularly teenage girls, are high and in some age groups still increasing. Approximately 90% of smokers begin before the age of 20.
This situation is very clearly a result of cigarette advertising which is aimed at young people and attempts to link smoking with social success, health, wealth and sporting prowess.

This is recognised by all leading health authorities in Australia and by the World Health Organisation. Bodies such as the National Heart Foundation, the Australian Cancer Society, the Australian Medical Association and the Alcohol and Drug Foundation, all have policies advocating a total ban on cigarette advertising. Governments have also recognised this. In 1976, the Federal Government introduced a ban on cigarette advertising on the electronic media-radio and television. In recent years, both the Victorian and South Australian State governments have restricted most other forms of cigarette advertising including billboards, cinema and shop front advertisements. At the end of the last session of the Federal Parliament, a report titled Drugs, Crime and Society, by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, recommended a total ban on all forms of cigarette advertising. This was a unanimous recommendation across all four political parties.

The effect of the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Bill 1989 will be to end cigarette advertising in the print media. This can only be addressed at a Federal level. In other areas of advertising, this Bill brings all States in line with Victoria and South Australia. As was the case with the Victorian and South Australian legislation, time will be given for industry to comply. In the case of the outdoor advertising industry, existing long term contracts will be able to run their course up until 1 July 1991-the same date as the Victorian and South Australian legislation.

When the legislation passed the Victorian and South Australian parliaments, it received the support of both Labor and Liberal parties and I am confident that that support will exist for this Bill. Certainly the National Crime Authority Committee report illustrates a breadth of opinion in the Parliament in support of an advertising ban. The Minister for Community Services and Health is also on record as supporting such a move.

Similarly the Australian Community overwhelmingly favours a ban on all forms of cigarette advertising. A Morgan poll of 2,251 Victorians in October/November 1988 showed 63.7% approval, 28.9% disapproval and 7.4% do not know, on the question of an advertising ban. A clear majority of smokers also favoured a ban.

This illustrates a willingness on the part of most Australians to give our young people an environment free from the deceptive images created by cigarette advertising. If this legislation passes the Parliament in the coming weeks, it will be looked on as a significant step in reducing the social cost of smoking. If this Bill fails, the medical community, parents' organisations, churches and individual voters, will condemn those who have voted to protect the interests of the tobacco companies, at the cost of our children's health.
I sincerely hope this does not occur.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the courtesy it showed me yesterday in enabling this debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989 to be continued today so that I could make a very brief contribution to it. We have had a reasonably long second reading debate on the Government's proposals to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). There will, of course, be a very long debate at the committee stage. We also face another second reading debate on some of the subsidiary legislation which relates to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies.

SPEECH.PARA: In thinking about this second reading debate, I was struck by the amount of heat and, I suppose, rancour that there has been in the debate on Aboriginal affairs over this last year. I do not wish to repeat the very many harsh things which I and other Opposition senators have had to say over that period. I do not in any sense step back from those things, because I think all of them were warranted. But in a brief contribution to the debate on this Bill, I want to focus on the task which we have in hand and the concerns which I think are broadly shared around the chamber in respect of the need to do a better job in Aboriginal affairs than we have managed over recent years and, perhaps, over the last 200 years.

I think a number of honourable senators have made very interesting and useful contributions to the debate. Whilst I do not agree with the support which Senator McKiernan, for example, gave to the legislation, I in general support the summary which was contained in his speech of the reasons why we should be concerned. Senator McKiernan quoted the statistics which I think are fairly well known to honourable senators and which certainly were mentioned by a number of them.

We have with respect to our Aboriginal Australians a pretty depressing situation in terms of the social statistics which would normally be taken to indicate the welfare or lack of welfare of the particular part of the community. As Senator McKiernan pointed out, Aboriginal people make up something under 2 per cent of the population; they have an average life expectancy of 15 to 20 years less than that for other Australians; they have a very high incidence of communicable diseases such as hepatitis B, diabetes, heart attacks and so on; their unemployment is six times the national average; their incomes in general are very low; and many families live in substandard housing or in temporary shelter.

When we look at the situation with respect to the law we find that imprisonment rates, which were referred to by Senator Peter Baume who led for the Opposition on this Bill, are 14 times higher than those of other Australians. In a sense, it is not necessary to quote those statistics again, Mr Acting Deputy President, but it is worth doing so as a reminder of why there is such widespread interest and concern in the Senate about the situation of Aboriginal Australians. It would also, I think, be unfair not to mention the fact that there are many Aboriginal Australians who are not in that predicament and who are very much in control of their own lives. They are independent, self-sustaining members of the Australian community who have achieved a level of welfare and personal well-being which would be our objective for the whole of the Australian community and the whole of the Aboriginal community. There is, of course, a danger in this focus on the negatives of the Aboriginal community that we could lose sight of the successes who, after all, are important because they remind us of what can be achieved by Aboriginal people within the Australian community now. It is a reminder that our goal is for all Australians, including Australian Aboriginals, to achieve the same levels of welfare and well-being.

The common concerns of the chamber about Aboriginal affairs are not new. The enormous upsurge in activity in this area actually started with the Gorton Government with education answers, the McMahon Government with the first purchase of land and the Whitlam Government with the establishment of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA). The first Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was appointed under the previous coalition Government. There was bipartisan support for the purchase of land, bipartisan support for Aboriginal land rights legislation in the Northern Territory and so on. One can point to a great deal of activity and, of necessity, a great deal of experimentation. The point I wanted to make in the debate on this Bill is that one of the most consistent common points of policy since that period in the 1970s has been the view that, under one name or another, governments should be encouraging Aboriginal people to take control of their own lives. This is sometimes called self-management, sometimes self-determination. I think the latter phrase is dangerous because it can have political connotations which have nothing to do with the social advancement that we are concerned about.

Over the last 15 or more years successive governments have provided substantial funds to enable Aboriginal people to run communities and organisations, whether they are legal services, community stores, community councils, or town services operations. A huge range of activities has been funded by the Commonwealth and controlled by Aboriginals themselves on the basis that what successive governments have believed is that by allowing Aboriginal people to have control over their own lives they will assume responsibility more easily, make choices which suit them, and we will avoid the mistakes of the past through that process.

I think there is still a great deal of bipartisan support for that broad theoretical approach. But it has been my concern-and it is not a recent concern since the time of the Labor Government; it is a concern I had when I first became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at the end of 1978-that in the pursuit of self-management and Aboriginal independence, and by Aboriginal independence I stress that I mean personal independence and community independence, not political independence, we have chosen to put the most extraordinary burdens on Aboriginal communities, often guaranteeing the failure of both community efforts and individual efforts.

When I read the contribution of Senator Coulter to the debate I was interested to note that he referred to this goal. He used the expression `self-determination'. On page 254 of the Senate Hansard Senator Coulter talked about the fact that the goals must not be merely material. They must not be merely better health, better housing and the sorts of things Senator McKiernan had referred to because they could be achieved in an autocratic way, a directed way. Let me quote him exactly. He said:

One could say to Aboriginal people: `You will be healthy whether you like it or not. We will control your water supply. We will control the nutrition that you get. We will control the houses that you live in'. This legislation is not just about outcomes in that sense. It is about processes and about those outcomes coming about through Aboriginal people taking control of their own destiny and determining such things as water supply, the sorts of health services, educational processes, housing and so on, that they want.

I totally understand what Senator Coulter is saying. But I want to put a view which is not contrary to the spirit of that comment of Senator Coulter's but which raises, I think, the practical implications of what Senator Coulter is saying and what we have done. By `we' I mean Liberal and National Party governments as well as the Labor Government. We have put many Aboriginal communities in the quite extraordinary situation where we say to them `If you want clean water you have to organise it. If you want electric power you have to organise it. If you want housing you have to organise it. If you want rubbish collection service you have to organise it'. And so it goes. One finds remote and ill-equipped Aboriginal communities carrying the complete responsibility for the provision of what the rest of Australia regards as basic provided services. It may well be that there is some value for an Aboriginal community to undertake that responsibility, to create employment in the community, to create that sense of responsibility, but I suggest to the Senate that we put an enormous burden on Aboriginals which we do not put on people who have much greater economic, educational and material advantages.

I live in the suburb of Claremont, a middle-class suburb of Perth. I do not have to worry about my water supply, my rubbish collection, the cleaning of the streets, the electricity supply. All of those things are handled by other people. I pay rates-very high rates from time to time-but it is all done for me. I, in common with suburban Australia generally and indeed Australia generally, exercise my self-management by having a much narrower range of responsibilities. I have to get myself out of bed in the morning. I have to make sure that I get to work on time. I have a very limited range of things for which I personally am responsible. Perhaps I vote for my local government council, which has responsibility for some of those things. I certainly have to vote in State and Federal elections, which ensure that great bureaucracies exist to provide these other services. My simple point is that in the name of advancing what is an acceptable social theory of giving people responsibility so they will exercise responsibility and take control of their lives, we forget the complexity of burdens that we put on those communities and those individuals. If an Aboriginal family has little background in education, in employment or in living in a Western-style community, an Australian-style community, and we say to them, `You must not only learn the habits of the orderly use of time, of getting to work, of getting your children to school, and of supervising your children at school'-the myriad tasks which make up the areas of self-control we have over our lives-`but you must also be responsible for making sure that your rubbish is collected, that the electricity system works, that the pump works and all of these other things', it is my view that in many cases a gross overburden is placed on these people.

The truth is that when I took over the portfolio in 1978 there were massive breakdowns of self-management. There were communities in chaos. As I dot around Australia now and visit communities I find the same thing. I went to Red Hill the other day, a place I saw in 1979 as a hopeful experiment of the new way. I was back there at the beginning of 1988 and I found a disgusting mess. One could go on multiplying examples. I have visited Yuendumu, Papunya and many other places and found indescribable tension and stress-and often, disorder. The truth is that we have grossly overloaded many Aboriginal communities.

The Parliament of this Commonwealth has found something to be true, something Senator Coulter referred to, that is that we can impose these things. After all, the Schools Commission found that the best educational outcomes for Aboriginal people were in the State which was administered in a relatively authoritarian way-Queensland. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs found that the best environmental health conditions were in Queensland. I have never supported the directive, authoritarian approach of the Queensland department. I think that the recently resigned Minister, Mr Bob Katter, did a remarkable job in giving the Aboriginal people of Queensland a better deal under the present State Administration. I pay tribute to his efforts.

I do not want to be distracted from my core point, which is that in trying as a parliament to come to grips with the significant problems of Aboriginal people, it is our duty to ask: What have we learned from the last 15 to 20 years? What have we learned from the billions of dollars of expenditure and from the efforts which have been made by all of us to come to grips with the difficulties of Aboriginal Australians? Surely, we must learn from our mistakes as well as from the positives.

I would say that there are enough examples of the difficulties of putting self-management on such a broad basis, the sort of basis that was put to me when I met Mr Pat Dodson, for example-one of the favoured administrators of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). When I talked to Mr Dodson about how he saw things working, he had this romantic ideal of Aboriginals doing everything for themselves. I do not think that is an unfair summary of what he was putting to me. I put the simple view that that is nonsense. It is grossly unfair to the Aboriginal people and will not work. In a sense, that is my own fundamental reservation about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), because it fails to take into account what has been shown to work as against what has been shown to create often insuperable difficulties for Aboriginal communities.

It has been said in this debate, and said very fairly, that Aboriginal people have been encouraged to use democratic processes by the previous Government and the present Government. That is true and I do not think there is any avoiding that. But let me focus on what it seems to me were some of the promising areas of progress over recent years. Let me focus on examples which are certainly bipartisan because one of the best examples of what I want to talk about is headed up by a Labor member of parliament from Bathurst Island, Mr Stan Tipiloura. He is the brother-in-law of Senator Bob Collins, so Senator Collins knows him well and I met him in the company of Senator Collins.

The gentleman concerned is the chairman of his local community council, a democratically elected body. It is typical of the bodies which have been established in the Northern Territory which give community control over what are essentially local government functions. What I think has been developed in the Northern Territory is a pattern that we should have been considering as the potentially new wave pattern for us to adopt: democratic control within a local government framework which provided for accountability. What has gone wrong with self-management very often is that the accountability processes do not work.

Essentially we have had two areas of accountability: a large amount of taxpayers' money is handed to a community and the people who administer the money are accountable to the community because they are elected and they are accountable to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs because it controls the purse strings. That has proved to be an effective system of accountability in some cases but not in others. In far too many cases it has not been effective.

What the local government model developed by the Northern Territory did was to provide an accountability upwards as well as an accountability downwards and it is a nice non-racist system. It is non-racist because it adopts procedures which are common to the whole of Australia. If, for example, a local government council which is administered by some of your colleagues, Mr Acting Deputy President, in the Labor Party of New South Wales proves to be dishonest or incompetent, then the Government steps in and appoints an administrator. There is a local government Act which puts a whole lot of duties and obligations upon the elected officers. The shire clerk has a series of statutory obligations. He is accountable up as well as to the democratic process. From my own examination of what has been happening in the Northern Territory I think that that has provided the real seed of a working system for many Aboriginal communities. You have the democratic control of the people who can elect a council but the officials are not at the whim of people who are subject to all sorts of family and other pressures. They not only have their duty to the elected councillors; they have their statutory duty to ensure that the administration is honest and orderly and according to established processes.

I would say to people like Senator Coulter, whose sincerity in these matters I have never I hope in any way impugned, or to Senator Collins, whose sincerity in these matters I would never impugn, that this seems to be the pattern which we should pursue because unless you have effective accountability, you get disorder. You do not get the sort of social progress for Aboriginal people that we are pursuing out of chaos. I have visited Wiluna often, and I have found a community in disorder. I have not had an opportunity to visit Balgo for some time, but I am assured by many people it is in total disorder and there is now a working party of officials from governments and agencies desperately trying to bring order into Balgo.

I say to Senator Coulter and I say to the Government that is promoting ATSIC: no good can come out of this chaos. The children will not go to school; they will not be educated. The community's health will suffer; they will die if the water is not properly supplied, the sewage is not dealt with and the rubbish is not collected. It is not fair to the next generation to have them brought up in disorder because they are then condemned.

A few visits ago to the Northern Territory, I was talking to two distinguished Aboriginal people. One was Senator Collins's brother-in-law, whom I have mentioned and whom I greatly respect, and the other was Mr Wesley Lanhupuy, who is well known, I am sure, to Senator Peter Baume and others who have taken an interest, and who is now a Labor member of the Legislative Assembly in the Northern Territory. In my discussions with Wesley Lanhupuy, I particularly recall asking: `Where is the next generation of leaders coming from? Where are the Yunupingus and the Lanhupuys and the other brilliant Aboriginal leaders coming from?'. I suspect that the disorder of recent years is condemning the Aboriginal people to having an unproductive generation. We really have a situation where we are refusing to learn from what has worked and we are chasing theories without regard to what has been demonstrated not to work. That is the core of my personal concern about what the Government is doing.

I have spoken very harshly in this chamber of the efforts of Minister Hand. I understand that in private he has more than repaid me in kind, and in public he has certainly repaid me in kind. I have spoken harshly of the ministry of his predecessor, Clyde Holding. I have used words against them that I have not used, for example, against Minister Howe, who has administered a portfolio I had when in government; and I would not speak harshly of him because I think he has conscientiously applied himself to the task. But in Aboriginal affairs, the Government has unfortunately applied itself to romance, to theory, to totems and to self-indulgence. We have not seen from the Government a focus on what is happening to Aboriginal people in Australia today.

What is happening in too many cases is not good, not right, not fair, not proper and not just; it is grossly wrong. ATSIC represents an enormous risk that the grossest errors will be repeated over and over again. The strange proposal of 1,200 elected councillors, these regional organisations, and at the same time this very great authority left with the Minister but this extraordinary responsibility vested back to regional councils is a formula which will almost certainly produce a repeat of the disorder which has blighted the lives of so many Aboriginal people.

My concerns are essentially practical. They are no different from the concerns that I expressed to DAA officers on my first visit to Alice Springs during the first month of 1979. Is what we are doing working? How do we explain the Papunyas and the other places where there has been so much disorder? Amoonjama is a sharp example of the disorder that flowed from the social theorising of 1975.

In my view, the real problem with ATSIC is that it will produce change for the sake of change, change for the sake of theory, and will not produce the practical, on-the-ground results that the Aboriginal people are entitled to demand. I am very, very sorry that the Government has not been prepared to consult more fully with the Aboriginal people in the way that the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs demonstrated was required. I am even more sorry that the Government has refused to focus on the practical problems which face Aboriginal Australians and has refused to listen to people like its own Aboriginal members of parliament in the Northern Territory.

I believe it has refused to listen to people like Bob Collins, whom I first saw working with the Aboriginal community on Elcho Island many years ago, and I have had a great respect for his capacity to communicate with the Aboriginal people, and his understanding of his Aboriginal constituents from that time. I do not believe that what is happening now represents the ordered and sensible views of those members of the Labor Party who know something about this subject. This is theory gone mad. This is why so often Ministers of the Left of the Labor Party are a disaster. This is a tragedy for the Aboriginal people. Let me say in closing that nothing will bring me greater pleasure, should this legislation be passed, if I am proved to be wrong, but, unfortunately, I do not expect that to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, in closing the second reading debate in relation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989, I think it is essential that we focus our eyes very clearly on the real object of our concern and the reason for this legislation being brought before the Parliament, and that is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people-the communities that live within our wider Australian community. I do not think there is any argument with the view that those descendants of the original inhabitants of this continent and the surrounding islands are a particularly depressed and deprived sector within our Australian community. All the indications, social indicators, health indicators and so on, which are put together in relation to Australians, indicate that it is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are particularly at risk and particularly vulnerable, and who have succumbed to that risk and that vulnerability in relation to their situation, both in a simple physical sense and in the social, cultural and economic sense.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said before, but I would like to put on the record the fact that for Aborigines the average life expectancy at birth is 15 to 20 years less than for other Australians; that Aboriginal infant mortality, while improving, is still nearly three times that for non-Aboriginal Australians; that Aboriginal people suffer from a higher incidence of both communicable diseases such as hepatitis B and lifestyle diseases such as diabetes and heart disease. Aboriginal unemployment is six times the national average. On average Aboriginals earn only half the income of other Australians. A large proportion of Aboriginal families live in substandard housing or temporary shelter. One could go on and on about the situation in which Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders find themselves.

That is the current reality. When an Australian government or an Australian parliament is considering the programs which ought to be put in place and the way in which those programs ought to be devised and delivered quite clearly there is a very heavy obligation upon us in relation to this particularly disadvantaged group within our society. That is not because of some mistaken assumption of guilt for what might have been done in the distant, or even not so distant, past, as colonisation, as the movement of people, particularly from European societies, into this continent took place. I am not referring to any of the claims that one is trying to assuage some sort of inherited guilt in relation to those matters; I am talking about the consequences of the dispossession, the dispersal of Aboriginal people and the disruption of their culture which has led to the present realities.

It is the current and present realities, as outlined, which I refer to and which, as I say, need to be kept in focus as the matters which at the end of the day need to be improved by whatever machinery is put into place. To an extent, therefore, of course one agrees with Senator Peter Baume and others who have said that one of the tests-I think they indicate that it is the primary test-in relation to the sort of machinery that is put in place will be the effect that it has over a period of time on the sorts of social and other indicators which I have outlined.

It is also very important to indicate that the process, as Senator Coulter put it, is as important in many ways as the outcomes. Of course, decent housing, proper supplies of fresh water, adequate systems for the disposal of sewage, education for youngsters and continuing health care, particularly for mothers with small infants, are absolute life imperatives as far as those communities are concerned. But as has been pointed out-I think Senator Chaney in his remarks made this point-an authoritarian, autocratic or paternalistic imposition of methods by which those better outcomes might be achieved is not a way in which Australian society can operate.

One needs to try to encourage the participation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in devising programs and in indicating those areas where the rest of the Australian community might, by its expertise, assist them. Therefore, I found it a little difficult to follow some of Senator Chaney's remarks about the horrendous burdens that might be placed on Aboriginal communities in relation to the way in which the Bill will operate. I think he indicated, in some of his remarks, that they would be virtually solely responsible for their individual and community well-being. There is no indication under this arrangement that such an onerous burden will be placed on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They are not to be solely responsible for their physical, individual, social, communal, economic well-being. They are and will remain part of the Australian community. Indeed, when one looks at the objectives set out in the Bill, one finds that object (d) of the `Objects' clause states:

to ensure co-ordination in the formulation and implementation of policies affecting Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders by the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments, without detracting from the responsibilities of State, Territory and local governments to provide services to their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents.

That matter needs to be emphasised in relation to what apparently may have been put to Senator Chaney by some representatives of the Aboriginal people, including, according to Senator Chaney, Pat Dodson. Senator Chaney outlined the view to the Senate, and characterised it as somewhat romantic, that the Aboriginal people should take sole responsibility for the provision of the services and other matters which are required for their individual and community sustenance and life. Even if it is true that Pat Dodson expressed that view-and I do not know that it is-the Government is not putting that point of view. The Government is emphasising cooperation and continuing responsibility in respect of the Australian Government and Parliament, State governments and parliaments, and local governments, as well as community organisations within the Australian community. Those responsibilities cannot be shirked; they still remain. This is in the legislation and it is the intention of the Government that ATSIC arrangements should operate in that way.
As I say, outcomes are obviously going to be terribly important. During the second reading debate, Senator Coulter made this point:
Surely the process should involve more Aboriginal participation, determination and self-management. That is what this legislation is about.

I think that is right. We do not want to get caught up in slogans or labels. But quite clearly, in all this, as has been constantly the case in Aboriginal affairs in Australia, there is a difficult tension between the self-management principle and the accountability principle. Senator Chaney in his term as Minister and in introducing the Aboriginal Development Commission legislation made a judgment as to what should be the balance between self-management and account- ability. Over the last year at least-perhaps the last year and a half-we have had constant, hour after hour, day after day, week after week debates and processes, particularly within the Senate Estimates committees and in this chamber, trying to get that balance correct between accountability and the important process of restoring to Aboriginal persons and communities self-esteem, dignity and so on, which comes from making decisions which can influence the shape of their own future.

That balance is about to be radically altered-I do not think that is an improper term in this debate-by the ATSIC proposal. It is not a proposal which, I think Senator Boswell said, would centralise power in Canberra. That is not the object and I do not think a fair reading of the proposal would lead to that conclusion. The fact is that at the moment we have a proposal before the chamber whereby the Commission itself will be constituted by 20 members, 17 of whom will be elected by representatives of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I believe that that in itself will provide a very good and effective safeguard against the sort of centralisation of power here in Canberra, which Senator Boswell was concerned about. It is certainly different from the situation, and I think the honourable senator would agree, where you have a Minister in charge of a department and then, in relation to the present ADC, being able to appoint, as we know through the traumas of 12 months ago, a majority of members to that ADC.

Here we have a situation where the Commission will in fact be put into place by the vote expressing the will of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in their various communities around Australia. These determinations as to the way in which funds should flow back to the various areas of Australia where Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are found will be largely based, as we know, on the recommendations of the regional councils. Those regional councils themselves will quite clearly have a very important role in the operation of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have absolutely no power at all. They cannot even hire and fire an officer. They cannot even put on a cleaner.

—That is not correct. The fact is that they are allowed to put together, for the purposes of formulating estimates, those indications from within their own communities of the programs which should be given priority and the sort of funding which should be allocated to the various organisations which can best provide the services to those communities.
—And if they disagree with the Minister he can sack them.

—If the Minister disagrees with the proposals which are put forward for the expenditure of funds within a region, then he has to come into this Parliament and indicate why that is so and where that is so. It is a fully public process. If something is not in accordance with the Minister's view of how services should be provided, then he cannot do anything about it secretly. He cannot do it by some sort of executive action which is not subject to scrutiny; it has to be brought into this Parliament. I think that that is an important protection for the regional councils' functions.

SPEECH.PARA: In preparing its plans for the development of the communities within a regional council's particular region, the cooperative element still has to be emphasised because the council will be working with other programs which are provided by ATSIC and will be, of course, dealing with other bodies-both community bodies and local and State government bodies. This, of course, will have an enormous impact on the communities and their regions.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I think it is also necessary to say something about the terminology `black parliament', although I do not think people in this debate have really fallen into the trap of speaking about a black parliament emerging in relation to this ATSIC proposal. That particular terminology is not justified whatsoever. The fact is that the persons who form the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will, as they meet in that Commission, have no legislative powers. The Federal Parliament will retain its role in that ATSIC will be totally dependent on the will of this Parliament as to its very existence and as to its functions. It will be required to meet all those standards of accountability which are so important and which this Parliament, and this chamber in particular through its various committees, has indicated are absolutely essential. I could go through the various accountability procedures but we will come to those in more detail in the committee stage debate.

I believe that this legislation is an important stage in the historic resolution of the way in which the wider Australian community relates to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people here in Australia. The fact is that the objects clause indicates I believe very clearly what this Bill is about. I think I might read it into the record:

The objects of this Act are, in recognition of the past dispossession and dispersal of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and their present disadvantaged position in Australian society:
(a) to ensure maximum participation of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders in the formulation and implementation of government policies that affect them;
(b) to promote the development of self-management and self-sufficiency among Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders;
(c) to further the economic, social and cultural development of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders; and

I will not read paragraph (d). I have already dealt with that. It deals with the coordination of Commonwealth, State and local government organisations. It emphasises and does not detract from their responsibilities. I believe that in that objects clause one has the summary of the reasons which have led to the development of this particular proposal.

Naturally, the reorganisation over the whole of Australia to such an extent, as is proposed through regional councils and through the Commission, will bring problems of the sort that attend any such major reorganisation of the delivery of services and the provision of a means by which people can make their views known. But there is within the Bill and as sought by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs a process by which the initial stages, the early operation of this particular proposal, can be monitored by the Commission itself taking real responsibility for indicating to the Parliament how this particular scheme in practical terms is working.

I agree with those who say that one cannot describe this in prospect as being absolutely perfect, that nothing will have to be remedied and that no alteration will ever need to be made in relation to its operation. But we at least have to see how the delivery of programs, the process and the manner by which they are devised improves the lot of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I believe that the processes within the legislation recognise that this is a matter for continued review specifically by the Commission, by this Parliament and particularly by this chamber. In these ways the Bill, when passed into law, will provide a very sound foundation for the further advancement of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people within our democracy, within our society-always subject to the ultimate jurisdiction and responsibility of this Parliament. The Bill will allow great progress in those indicators which I outlined at the beginning of my remarks, enabling Aboriginal people to assume their rightful self-esteem, which has in many cases been stripped from them by the way in which we as a society have dealt with those people over many generations. I commend the Bill to the Senate and seek the support of honourable senators for the second reading.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the order of 17 August 1989, the Senate will now proceed to the second reading of the two related Bills.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill and the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill were introduced into the Senate it would have been possible for the Opposition to have sought to have three second reading debates. The Opposition has not taken that course. It has agreed readily to a cognate debate for the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill and the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill. I mention this as a manifestation of the goodwill which we bring into this debate and which we wish to see conducted in good order and in appropriate time. Secondly, it would have been possible for us to have asked for an unrestricted speaking list for this debate. We have not done so and we have agreed readily to the Government's request that this cognate second reading debate for two Bills be restricted in time to three hours. This is a further manifestation of our desire to see the Government proceed in good order with this legislative package.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to attract any points of order but I would like to make one very brief comment about the summing up speech made by Senator Tate to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill, the debate on which has just been completed. He made much, and these Bills make much, of Aboriginal participation in the process. The Opposition cannot but note that a Government which talks so much about Aboriginal participation has at no time had an Aboriginal person present in the chamber to advise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very sad.

—This point was raised by Senator Boswell when debate on the ATSIC Bill was begun. The Government still has not seen fit to add to its team of advisers any Aboriginal person and it makes the discussion about Aboriginal participation rather hollow. It seems to be one of those pronouncements of theory by this Government which do not appear to have any practical effect-certainly not here in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I will turn first to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989. Honourable senators will remember that we had several generations of legislation in this package. It is interesting to look at the earlier generations of Bills to see what they had. In the 1988 ATSIC Bill, the provisions for the Institute actually formed part V of that legislation. The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which looked at that package and which made recommendations, recommended that the Institute should retain its own Act, and I will come back to that. Before that Committee the Institute of Aboriginal Studies made a submission and I refer honourable senators to page 1402 of the transcript of evidence where the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS) said the following:

The Institute, through its Council, has consistently maintained that it is essential that it remain an independent organisation with its own Act. Some of the arguments for adopting this position are: The Institute is a research and funding body which must retain its independence and integrity in order to pursue its activities without the sorts of pressures that might be brought to bear upon it if amalgamated with a larger body primarily concerned with matters relating to the welfare and advancement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
I stop there to say that that objection is very germane to many of the amendments which we have proposed and which, if necessary, we will move at a later time. I go back to the quotation:

The Institute's unique collections of print and non-print materials place it in a position more akin to the National Library of Australia than to a large bureaucracy. It is quite inappropriate therefore that it become absorbed into a large Commission.

There is no evidence that there will be any effective cost savings or efficiency increases by the proposed amalgamation. Because of the Institute's very special functions, it needs to retain its own building, its own administration and its own particular facilities. The specialist functions are not duplicated elsewhere in the portfolio and there is no suggestion that there are areas where savings could be made.

The activities of the Commission will concern the administration of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in Australia. The Institute is a research and resource facility and has little or nothing in common with the proposed Commission. It is not evident that amalgamation with the Commission will benefit either the activities of the Institute or the Commission.
I now refer honourable senators to page 22 of the report of the Senate Select Committee. It is part of the unanimous report. At paragraph 2.42 we find the following:
The AIAS also expressed serious reservations about the implications of the McIver Report-
That was a report by Dr R. McIver entitled Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Proposed Organisation Structure. The report of the Senate Select Committee continues:

. . . for the Institute's independence from ATSIC. The Institute concluded that the report appears to clear the way for total absorption within the Commission. The report highlights the immense vulnerability of the Institute and all it represents, if it is allowed to be absorbed within the Commission.
Because of all this, Madam Acting Deputy President, the Senate Select Committee recommended-and I refer honourable senators to paragraph 2.46-in the following terms:
The Committee recommends that AIAS should retain its own legislation and continue to deal with other Aboriginal Affairs portfolio agencies as it has in the past.

There is a bit more to the recommendation which I will not read. The point I will make now, and again and again, is that while this Bill represents the redemption of the first half of that recommendation, it does not meet the second half. The Australian Institute of Aboriginal Affairs did not pretend that its present Act is perfect. It considered that the 1964 statute needed some updating but it considered that this could be a self-contained operation. The Institute used the following words in its evidence:

Council perceives that the time is right for change. However, in adopting this view, Council remains of the opinion that the best way to protect the interests of Aboriginal Studies is to safeguard the Institute's position and guarantee its future existence by retaining an independent statutory base.

Having said all that, we now turn to the present legislation. I have referred honourable senators to the previous generation of Bills and we find that the present Bill we are considering is a carbon copy of what was part V of the 1988 Bill. The Government has changed nothing. It has merely taken part V of the previous Bill, put a cover around it, changed a few words and said: Here is a separate Bill for the Institute of Aboriginal Studies. There is nothing different--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not good enough.

—And it is not good enough. I take the interjection from a councillor of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. It is not good enough. Specifically, it retains the nexus between the Institute and the ATSIC and it is that nexus that is so dangerous. Let me make it clear to honourable senators when we talk about independence that the Senate Committee recommended that the AIAS should retain its own legislation and, `continue to deal with other Aboriginal Affairs portfolio agencies as it has in the past.' One needs to ask in what way it has dealt with other agencies in the past. I will tell the Senate: The AIAS has operated directly to the Parliament for its funds. It has reported to the Parliament. It has been a creature of the Parliament, carrying out a specialised function. But what is proposed in this legislation is that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies should become a creature of ATSIC, that its funding should come through the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and that it should be controlled and dominated by ATSIC.

SPEECH.PARA: This redeems neither what the Institute called for, nor what the Senate Select Committee, by unanimous recommendation, called for. It is not good enough, as Senator Teague has said. I remind honourable senators of an article by Jack Waterford in the Age newspaper of 16 August 1989 in which Mr Charles Perkins, AO, had some things to say about his own career. Among other things, he talked about this legislation. The article stated:

`I would think that the present arrangement between the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Institute of Aboriginal Studies should remain', he said. `The task should be to make them more effective . . .'
Mr Perkins made it clear in a public statement that he does not support the creation of an institute subservient to and subsumed within an ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charles Perkins's words are exactly what the Opposition is now arguing.

—Mr Perkins's words are exactly what the Opposition is now arguing. I ask the Government, further, to tell us something about the way it has administered the present Act under which the Institute operates. The Act provides that a number of councillors shall be appointed by the Governor-General, acting on advice. But I am advised that six such appointments have remained unfilled since 1985. Why is it that the Government has not even been willing to exercise its obligations under the present Act, even though I am assured by friends that the AIAS has been pressing Mr Hand so to act for some time? We invite the Government to tell us why it is that it has refused for some years even to bring the Institute to its proper numbers.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to spend the rest of my time talking about the other piece of legislation which is part of this cognate debate-the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill. Before I do so, I want to indicate quite clearly that the Opposition will oppose the Bill before us relating to the Institute for the reasons I have outlined. Should we be unsuccessful, we will proceed during the committee stage to propose a number of amendments. I turn now to the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill. Some Bills which come before this Senate are neutral in their effect, some are foolish but this one is evil and malevolent. This Bill, which we are asked to approve, not only is a denial of Aboriginal self-management but also is totally unnecessary.

The Senate Select Committee, in chapter 4 of its report, spent some time setting out the special role of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), its special character and the special function it has performed in relation to Aboriginal self-management in Australia. Whatever we may wish to say against the Commission, it has been the flagship of Aboriginal self-management. It has been a fully Aboriginalised commission-all the commissioners have been Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. I remind honourable senators that clause 202 of the ATSIC legislation, which has just been given a second reading, seeks to abolish the Aboriginal Development Commission. Should that legislation go through the third reading stage and receive royal assent, the ADC will cease to exist. It is one thing to believe in capital punishment and to hang someone, but to draw and quarter that person first is a cruel and unnatural process. That is what this Bill does. Why, given that the Government intends to abolish the ADC some hours from now--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already voted on it.

—We voted on the second reading motion and the indication, therefore, is that the Government may have support later on. Why, now, does the Government wish to emasculate-eviscerate-the ADC as it exists? That is why this is an evil and malevolent piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980 represented a carefully fashioned compromise between the needs of Aboriginal self-management and reasonable accountability. Senator Chaney, the then Minister, consulted Aboriginal people very carefully-something which Mr Hand cannot claim-and adjusted the legislation to meet their concerns. It is the only Act of Parliament ever introduced into the Parliament by an Aboriginal parliamentarian. From 1980 to 1988 four Ministers from both sides of politics found that they could work within the essential concept of the Bill. At times it was not easy. There were tensions and conflicts but the difficulties were worked through. The Fraser Government had the vision of progressively handing over to the ADC more functions as commissioners gained more experience. I recall that when I was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I passed the housing function to the ADC in 1981. I note that the capital fund was topped up during the period of the Fraser Government. This was done to extend independence and self-management, in the real sense of those words. The ADC was created and funded as an instrument of Aboriginal self-management. The capital fund was established and funded to allow independence and self-management to become a reality.

Great care was always taken in proposing appointments to the Board of Commissioners. A balance in respect of areas, sexes and experience was sought. But the important thing was that four Ministers then left the commissioners to get on with the job. Of course there were difficulties. Some reports of the Auditor-General and investigations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure criticised the Commission. I remind honourable senators that one of the Expenditure Committee reports was produced under the chairmanship of a Mr Gerry Hand. Those reports did not recommend the destruction of the Commission. The present Minister came on to the scene like a bull in a china shop with his impractical ATSIC proposal. Following his 11 May massacre he exacerbated the situation by appointing inexperienced and headstrong acting commissioners. He issued the first direction under section 11 that any Minister had found it necessary to issue. He sacked and humiliated eight commissioners who had done their best for their people. He has gone further to hint very broadly that he will seek further ministerial control. Of course, all this led to the need for further examination by the Auditor-General.

We are told, in the ATSIC Bill, that the answer to the problems of Aboriginal Australia is to provide more self-management. The Government uses the term self-determination, which is probably a dangerous term. Yet the ATSIC Bill tries, in a most snide way, to put the commissioners' operations under the closest, the most paternalistic, ministerial control. The same thing is attempted in this ADC Amendment Bill. No previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ever needed the close and stifling controls this Bill seeks to impose on Aboriginal people.

Of course there have been difficulties. Of course there have been embarrassments. Of course there has been bad judgment and of course there have been wrong decisions. But how else do we expect things to progress as people take control over their own lives and make their own decisions? How else could self-management for Aboriginal people become a reality? This Bill sets out to bind the ADC hand and foot, to remove those elements of the ADC Act which made self-management a reality. Even as we debate this Bill we know that the Government has put in train plans to destroy the ADC completely by administrative means. The Government has worked out a plan to gut the ADC administratively. We know that funds for the ADC were reduced in the Budget. It appears that a function with the ADC has been transferred back to the Department-an amount of more than $20m. We know that a draft Cabinet decision was prepared in July 1989 which set out means by which the ADC could be gutted administratively. That draft Cabinet submission has been put into the public arena by my colleague Mr Warwick Smith. We have seen it. It suggests, inter alia, that one of the things the Government might be able to do is the following. I will read option (b) from the draft Cabinet submission:

the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to withdraw the section 8 (g) determinations in respect of housing grants and possibly other functions, these to be undertaken from 1 December 1989 by DAA, with appropriate adjustments to appropriations;

It is interesting to note that in the Budget money was removed from the ADC. Mr Warwick Smith has released publicly a photocopy of an Aboriginal Development Commission commission-in-confidence resolution without submissions from the meeting of 7 to 11 August 1989. The resolution reads as follows:

The Commission RESOLVED to recognise the depletion of their budget by $26.5m to service the Minister's commitment to Priority Community Development Strategy and RECORDED their displeasure about the way in which this happened.

It indicates that it was signed by Terry O'Shane, Chairman, and that it was approved. So the Government has been trying to gut the ADC administratively. It now plans to dismember it with this Bill and then to execute it in the ATSIC legislation. We are asked to agree to all these amendments to put the Minister in the driver's seat, to end self-management in the ADC as we have known it since 1980. Neither the Prime Minister nor the Minister has given the ADC a fair go. It worked under four Ministers. Why could it not work under the fifth Minister? There has been absolutely no consultation with anyone about this Bill, about these provisions. What do the hand-picked commissioners think of the controls which are now to be put on them? We know that they expressed their displeasure at some of the administrative consequences. I have just read out their commission-in-confidence resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're learning. They're learning that they can't trust the Minister.

—That is correct. But will Aboriginal people get any chance at all to talk about this Bill, about what it is going to do to the ADC? The Minister is always telling us how much he was willing to consult about ATSIC. How much is he consulting about his moves to destroy the ADC?

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no justification for this Bill. Somebody in the Department of Finance was sent over to the ADC to see what controls could be put on it, and he did his job. This Bill is the outcome. The sad thing is that his terms of reference did not take into account the Minister's rhetoric about people's power and self-management. The Prime Minister has never explained what lies behind his grand plans for administrative arrangements in Aboriginal affairs. He has not established a case.

This Bill sets out single-mindedly to control every aspect of the ADC's activities. Any voice of opposition will be suppressed. Any challenge to the Minister's determination to have his way will be crushed. What began with Ministers from this side of the Parliament as a far-sighted and even courageous exercise in Aboriginal self-management now lies in ruins. We are going to see Labor senators and Australian Democrat senators vote for this to occur. It is unbelievable that they should take this course.

We on this side of the chamber find it hard to understand how the Australian Democrats have failed, and continue to fail, to see what the Minister's agenda really is. How can they even hope-still less how can they be sure-that the fine sentiments on ATSIC about self-management will not end up crushed in the same ministerial determination to impose his will as we see now operating in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission? We will go through the clauses later. But, of course, once the statute is in place it will be all too late. Sadly, it is probably too late now for the Aboriginal Development Commission.

The Opposition will oppose this Bill. We will oppose it as vigorously as we can. Either it is unnecessary, because the Government will be abolishing the Aboriginal Development Commission should it succeed in having clause 202 of the ATSIC legislation passed and proclaimed, or it has already finished off the ADC by underhanded administrative means. If the Government really wants this Bill, if it really wants it to apply, the Government must explain how this Bill, whose principles fly in the face of so much the Government has said about Aboriginal self-management, can proceed. How can the Government proceed with such a Bill? The Government stands condemned in its own terms with this legislation.

To sum up, there are two pieces of legislation in this package. The Opposition has cooperated in having them debated together and in limiting the length of time allowed for their discussion at the second reading. We will oppose each of the Bills: the ADC Bill, because it is an evil, malevolent and destructive Bill; and the Bill for the establishment of an Institute for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies because it does not adequately redeem the letter or the spirit of what the Senate Select Committee recommended on this matter. Should the second reading succeed, we will move appropriate amendments at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a most lucid and excellent speech from an honourable senator who adorns the Opposition benches. I do not say that facetiously. Senator Peter Baume is certainly in his proper place where he sits now. I do not necessarily say he should be there as Leader of the Opposition but certainly he should be on the front bench. He has done the most honourable of work in the area of Aboriginal affairs. He pointed out that development took place under the Aboriginal Development Commission, which was set up by the Fraser Government, and that as time went by funding was increased and more tasks were given to it. That illustrates the fact that the position where Aboriginals are entitled to take their proper place in society, not only by law but by fact, has to be reached. In fact, this journey has been attempted by various governments.

SPEECH.PARA: What came out of Senator Peter Baume's address to us was the fact that there is need for development. The argument, as I understand it, between the Government and the Opposition is not whether there should be development-I understand both sides agree on that-but how it should be done. The Opposition has said that the mechanisms the Government has adopted are wrong and that the sort of people we have advising us are wrong. Senator Baume says that history will show that to be so. That may be so. It will show whether the Opposition was right or whether the Government, led in this instance by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), was right.

Mr Hand has come in for a lot of criticism. It is often difficult to see what the gravamen of that criticism is. On one occasion it was that he was not taking sufficient care of his Department, that he did not have sufficient control over those institutions we have in society to service Aboriginals. Certainly, towards the end of last year and at the start of this year that was the charge laid against him. Now the charge seems to be not that he has done too little but that he has done too much, that the controls he has instituted are too strong, too powerful, and that he did not have the right balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —He certainly is not using the Department or any of his professional advice.

—Senator Tambling, more than anyone else, has led the charge. Senator Peter Baume has a constructive approach to what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. What Senator Baume says needs to be taken on board. It is a course that the Minister has not pursued; he has pursued another course. At least Senator Baume has put forward something creative. With great respect to Senator Tambling, his contribution to this debate over the months has been destructive. I say that not in an unkindly sense but in a descriptive sense. If we go through the many well-researched words he has used in the debate on Aboriginal affairs-and he is acknowledged by this side to be a person with a great deal of experience in this area-and put on one side the constructive criticisms Senator Tambling has made, the sorts of things he says ought to be instituted on behalf of Aboriginal affairs, and put on the other side his criticisms in terms of denigration and condemnation of policies, of people and of institutions, we will realise that the side with the negative criticism is overwhelmingly the stronger side. Senator Peter Baume, on the other hand, makes criticisms but is creative in doing so. That is what we need.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a legitimate place for criticising or condemning people, but that criticism must be balanced. Senator Tambling has never, in my experience, made any concessions in this chamber as to the Minister's goodwill in attempting to do something creative, whether it is right or wrong, whereas many other honourable senators on the other side, including Senator Peter Baume, have done so. That is the difficulty we have when we take on board interjections such as the one Senator Tambling made. We have to look at his interjection in the context of the sorts of contributions he has made in the chamber. Senator Coulter has been very critical of the Minister and of the policies of the Government from time to time, but in doing so he has put forward creative alternatives. As I understand the Minister's approach, he has taken on board many of the proposals that Senator Coulter has put forward. So it is a matter of how one goes about debating things in this chamber. One can throw a one-liner across the chamber from material one has-it is a legitimate tactic, and happens again and again-criticising particular people who try to create things, and thus score points. On the other hand, one can make a positive contribution to the debate. In my view, it is a more useful procedure to take the second course.

Senator Peter Baume criticised the fact that there is no Aboriginal person in the chamber instructing the Minister. I am not sure what that means or what the significance of it is, beyond perhaps a symbolic gesture. Perhaps Senator Baume is saying, `It would look good, it would look nice, it would look lovely, if we had an Aboriginal person in the chamber as we debate this matter'. I am sure that is right, but whether it would further the debate, I do not know. The debate has to go ahead on its merits or otherwise. If the honourable senator would like some sort of symbolic figure in the chamber, I can take the matter up with the Minister.

Senator Peter Baume mentioned Mr Perkins, OA, and what he has to say about the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill. I am sure that what Mr Perkins has to say should be taken on board. I have never understood Minister Hand to be other than ready to take on board what Mr Perkins says. He is not the sort of person to hold any ill-will against Mr Perkins. On the other hand, Mr Perkins is one person whose views must be valued. There are many others. The Minister, after his very long research into these areas, has chosen to go down the particular path we have on this occasion. Much criticism has been made about the Minister's lack of consultation. Much criticism could be made about anybody for lack of consultation.

If change is going to take place, it has to take place in a sensible context. As I said before, there is no argument in this chamber but that change has to take place. Any change will bring problems. Mr Gorbachev in Russia is not making his changes with roses all the way; nor is that happening in Poland. Mrs Thatcher is not universally popular in England. Even the changes in a country as close as New Guinea have not been received with joy all over the place. This is so when there is any change in administration, just as when Mr Reagan came to power. We would only have to ask the air traffic controllers what they think about change. The fact that pain comes with change is hardly an argument against change because there is very little change that comes without pain. It just seems to me that some of Senator Baume's argument-certainly not all of it, because there was great merit in it-was saying, `Look, because there is trouble, because there is pain, because there is difficulty that comes with change, that change should not take place'.
