I am sure that is not what he meant, but that is certainly how his argument came across.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is also not what he said.

—I think the inference, the tone, the sort of general context, the overall ethos of the speech tended to put that forth. As I said, I am sure it was not intended. It might just be, may I say, that I have misinterpreted what he said. Even I, at these times of great change, can make mistakes.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just have a look at the Bills themselves. Senator Baume criticised the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill 1989 because, he said, it put too many strictures on the ADC. Then he went on and said, `Even apart from the Bill, the Government is going to gut this Commission in any event'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Abolish.
—I think the word the honourable senator used was `execute'. Senator Puplick, I do remember what he said. I thought `execute' had more poetry to it than `abolish'.
—You end up equally dead, though.

—Death by any means, I suppose, is hard to bear. If we look at the Bill itself, which I will now do, we see that it talks about the functions, corporate plans, grants and loans to be repayable or conditions breached; loan, grant, acquisition and guarantee documents to show legislative authority; appointing a general manager; and putting in really what are audit functions. In fact, when we look at proposed new section 40b, we see that it does just that. What the Bill does, if looked at on its own, is quite unexceptional. It puts into place proper financial management procedures, and that is all it does. Looked at on its own, the Bill really is very optimistic as to the future of the ADC because what it seeks to do is to improve its functioning.

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem, it is said, is that it is ultimately going to come under the control of ATSIC. And that is true. ATSIC is obviously going to have much greater control over the sorts of things that the Aboriginal Development Commission is now doing and will have greater control over the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. Of course it is. That is the whole thesis and the whole thrust of ATSIC: what it seeks to do is to give people who are Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders a greater say over their own affairs, just as we have a greater say over our own affairs by electing governments, city councils, shire councils, and even boroughs-I love the name `borough'-such as the Borough of Port Fairy. That concept of electing people to do things is hardly foreign, and let us hope it never becomes foreign to people in Australia.

So I want to say this: a lot of what Senator Baume says is correct. He has put an interpretation on what will happen. He has spoken in terms of gutting and executing. Those words flow very colourfully and attractively from his mouth, but what they do is to throw a particular interpretation on what is being done by this Minister. I could use other phrases, such as, `Here is a Minister who seeks to give Aboriginals a say in their own affairs, who seeks to give to people control over their own destinies, who seeks to redress past wrongs by enabling people to exercise some degree of choice'. The argument then is not so much what the reality is as between particular interpretations. I am confident that my interpretation will prove to be correct.

Can I just go back to something that Senator Chaney said in the speech that he gave before Senator Tate replied. It just seemed to me to-and I will finish on this, Senator McKiernan; I said I would go for only five minutes and I see I have gone over my time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to catch your eye.

—The honourable senator has got my eye. I just want to make this point and then I shall sit down. Senator Chaney was saying, `Look, we are really thrusting too much in the way of responsibility onto Aboriginals. We are making them organise their own clean water, organise their own rubbish collection, organise their own clean streets, and we do not put this burden on the rest of the community'. I am not sure that we are going out and asking every Aboriginal to organise his or her own clean water or to organise her or his own power. What we are saying is that we are setting up bodies and institutions which will make arrangements to have those things done and that those bodies and those institutions will be elected democratically. That seems to me to mirror very much what happens in the community generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that Senator Chaney made was in reference to places like Red Hill, where he carried out experiments, or experiments were carried out while he was Minister, and where he returned years later to find that they had not worked as well as they might. He was probably being optimistic. Where we have a culture which has been quite badly shattered over the years--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you shut him up?
—That is rather hurtful, if I can say that. Senator Boswell sitting here --
—Yes, Senator Boswell. That is not very parliamentary, either.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. From Senator Boswell, whom I look upon as one of the cheerful, happy souls around this place who bring joy and lightness to us, that is rather hurtful. But I am sure he did not mean to hurt me.
—I withdraw my statement.
—Thank you, Senator Boswell. Thank you, Senator Cooney.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Where that culture is shattered, we cannot expect to have overnight results and, in the end, I do not think anybody does. I will sit down with this comment: I think ATSIC is the next step in the progress towards giving the Aboriginals a proper place in society. I have an expectation that we will be legislating again, as time goes by, because as time goes by there will be progress; and as progress takes place, new legislation will have to be brought in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I am very glad to see that you are in the chair because I know that you are particularly interested in the subject of Aboriginal and Islander affairs. We have spent a lot of happy time together going around the communities and the islands. I can remember well when the Islanders made you grandmother or mother. Ba Ba, I think they called you, which meant mother of all the islands-a tremendous gesture in appreciation of what you and your husband have done for Aboriginals in the Queensland communities. Let me put it on record: under your husband's stewardship, there are no better treated Aboriginals in Australia than those Aboriginals in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate today is debating the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill. The Institute Bill has been introduced as a result of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which recommended that the Aboriginal Institute should retain its own legislation and continue to deal with other Aboriginal affairs portfolio agencies, as it did in the past. That is a recommendation that the Committee made that was agreed to in principle but, in fact, not in reality. As my colleague Senator Peter Baume has said, the present Bill is almost identical to the Bill which proposed the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ACTSIC). However, the Government retains its domination of the Institute, because its board has to have three ATSIC commissioners. So there is really little independence gained from this sleight of hand transfer.

The Government paid lip-service to this piece of legislation, and it was only lip-service. However, the Government has rejected outright the Committee's recommendation on the future role of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) within ATSIC. The recommendation was that a greater proportion of the current activities of the ADC should be the responsibility of the proposed Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC) than is envisaged in the Bill. In its response, the Government said that a broader role raised the prospect that the AEDC would operate through a more decentralised structure. This rejection is not surprising as the history of Aboriginal legislation over the past two years under the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, has been one of centralisation, control and domination by the Minister, the greatest cost being to Aboriginal and Islander self-management.

The Senate faces a difficult and strange task today. It is being asked to amend legislation that we were asked to vote for an hour ago, and that in turn is going to gut this particular ADC Act. The second reading motion for the adoption of that legislation was carried. So we are now asked to amend legislation that is really not in force. I believe that the Minister, Mr Hand, is suffering such paranoia about the independent actions of the ADC that we have seen a series of events aimed at reducing the ADC's responsibilities and resources, culminating with this piece of legislation before us today. This is nothing short of a ministerial vendetta against the ADC, which began after the 1987 election when Mr Hand was appointed as the new Minister. He surrounded himself with like-minded advisers. He came up with a prime ministerially endorsed plan to amalgamate the various arms of Aboriginal affairs administration. He refused even to acknowledge formal advice from the Government appointed ADC Board on the ramifications of its ATSIC proposal for the ADC and Aboriginal affairs in general. He has crudely ignored the fact that such advice is part of the ADC's statutory functions and that the ADC was the most experienced and professional body to offer such advice. The Minister would not discuss any details of his ATSIC proposal before he got Cabinet endorsement and approval.

Following this refusal to accept advice which was not in line with his own views, the Minister then set out to bring the ADC to its knees through a series of Machiavellian events that saw the ADC commissioners dumped unceremoniously and their names and reputations savaged through false information leaked to the press. The chairperson, Shirley McPherson, was hounded out of office on the whim of the Minister. He reduced her responsibilities and then encouraged a vote of no confidence in her. When the Minister found that he could not control the unrest he had fostered in senior officers within his portfolio, heads rolled; many resigned in anger and frustration as they saw their lives' work disintegrate before them. When the Minister found that he could not hide the discrepancies in the administration of his portfolio, he found a scapegoat in Charles Perkins and gave his head on a silver platter. When the Minister found that his own Government dominated Select Committee recommended transferring the ADC to ATSIC, he turned the other cheek and amended the ADC Bill. What we are discussing at the moment is a proposal to gut the ADC Bill in order to reduce its powers and bring it under ministerial control. The Minister has tried all sorts of ways to rid himself of this nemesis-the ADC-the only remaining body run by Aboriginals and committed to the economic development and financial self-sufficiency of Aboriginal and Islander people.

A draft Cabinet submission dated July this year proposed various ways and means of gutting ADC functions without offending the Australian Democrats. I am sure that Senator Coulter has seen that draft Cabinet submission. It is hypocritical in its purpose, which was to take funds away from the ADC without offending the Democrats, because the Government was afraid the Democrats may turn against it for its actions in gutting the ADC. If Senator Coulter, the spokesman for the Democrats, has not seen that submission, I will gladly make it available to him.

ATSIC repeals the ADC Act. So what are we talking about today? The Minister has also taken it upon himself to reverse completely the Government's formal response to an expenditure committee's inquiry into the ADC. The response in October 1985 was made only nine months before the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced his intention to create a single statutory body with responsibility for all aspects of Aboriginal affairs. At his press conference in July 1987, the Prime Minister said that the Minister and the Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA), Charles Perkins, would work together on the new legislation. We now know what happened and how that has turned out. Mr Perkins has been scrapped, thrown on the dust heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will come back.

—I hope he does come back. It shows that the Minister and the Prime Minister were committed to ATSIC long before any consultation with the Aboriginal and Islander people. The Minister has never listened to any feedback. I point out again-and I know that this has been picked up by Senator Peter Baume-that if Aboriginal people are to have self-determination, if there is to be an interchange between Canberra and the Aboriginal communities, surely there is an Aboriginal person in the DAA or ADC who can come and sit in the officials' box to communicate with and tell their people what is actually happening in Canberra. We have sat here through four or five hours of debate. There has not been one indigenous person in the advisers' box. That shows how hollow ATSIC is in terms of self-determination. On the role of the ADC, the Committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission's role should be maintained and strengthened. Its emphasis should be increasingly on programs associated with Aboriginal development, including housing, enterprises and land acquisition, with welfare programs remaining with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or elsewhere.
The Government's response then was to support the recommendation regarding the aims and objectives of the ADC. The Committee found:

Whilst the Commission cannot be insensitive to the wishes of the Aboriginal population at large it does have a leadership role to exercise particularly in the area of Aboriginal enterprises, which is not being fully exercised at present.

The Government also supported another recommendation on housing responsibilities. The Committee said that the grant-in-aid housing program should remain the responsibility of the Commission. The Government supported that in addition to supporting a recommendation that the funding of housing and enterprise programs can be linked with training programs. That is particularly important in the case of enterprise programs where the basic skills are best learnt on the job rather than in institutionally provided courses.

It is overwhelmingly clear from this Bill before us that those Hawke Government commitments that made the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, like so many others on so many other issues, have been swept aside. None of these commitments have come to fruition. In fact, the opposite has occurred. The ADC has lost $26m in resources and its responsibilities have been lessened. Now, through this legislation, it is further to be restricted or almost abolished. The Prime Minister seems to be under the hold of Gerry Hand's Left-dominated faction. The Government has reversed its own policy, sacked key personnel who opposed its view, dismissed the advice of Government-appointed professionals in Aboriginal affairs and given the Minister totalitarian powers so that he can force through his pet project. This has become an obsession with the Minister. It is a case of win at all costs and the black people of Australia have no standing whatsoever. The Minister is going to get his own way irrespective of what damage it causes to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

The Prime Minister's appreciation of and praise for his former Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Charles Perkins, means nothing if Mr Perkins's views on ATSIC and the ADC are completely ignored. And it is no good the Prime Minister coming into this Parliament and giving Mr Perkins great accolades as a man who can communicate with the black people of Australia and then completely ignoring what Mr Perkins has said about the arrangements between DAA, ADC and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. What he is recommending is entirely what the Aboriginal people want, entirely what the Opposition is saying and what the Government formerly agreed to-that is, that the arrangements between the DAA, the ADC and the Institute should remain and the task should be to make them more effective. There is no argument with us; there is no argument with the Aboriginal people; and there is no argument with Charles Perkins. There is some misunderstanding in the Left of the Australian Labor Party that seems to have been thrown ATSIC as a bone to shut it up on other issues. I suppose that is how the Labor Party works. There are four factions and the Left has to be fed a bone every now and again to shut it up.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party throws a brown paper bag at them.
—You should not talk to me about that. I will bring up the Curtin Foundation. We will have a look at who is on that and who got their snout in that trough.
—Order! Senator Boswell, will you direct your remarks through the Chair, please.
—Yes, I shall do that. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry that I was forced to respond to that interjection. I would ask you to control the Minister, too.
—The Minister is not in his right seat. He should not be interjecting.
—That is also right. Mr Perkins said:

SPEECH.PARA: It all seemed to change after the election in 1987 . . . In Aboriginal affairs, there is now a lot of confusion. When Clyde Holding left the portfolio it was a top level effective machine of government which was doing what it was supposed to be doing. Now it is disorganised, there is a great deal of unhappiness and poor morale.

The Minister could not even tell Mr Perkins to his face that he was to be dismissed. Gerry Hand left him sitting in his office. Gerry Hand never had the guts, the fortitude, to go up and say to Mr Perkins, `I'm sorry, Charles, we can't work together. It's time that we parted. In the interests of the Aboriginal community, in the interests of Aboriginals, you'll have to go'. Mr Hand left him in the office for an hour and a quarter having a cup of coffee. He disappeared out the door. He did not even have the guts to give him his marching orders. As Mr Perkins said, `I was treated like a dog, left like a dog and pushed out through the door'. What an indictment of people that are supposed to represent the Aboriginal communities. This is like so many other cases in one white man's zealous one-eyed pursuit of a magic solution to our Aboriginal problems.

This cyclops mentality has caused great dissension and confusion amongst the Aboriginal communities around Australia. The Chairman of the Aboriginal Coordinating Council in Queensland, arguably the largest community council peak body in Australian Aboriginal affairs, has publicly supported the Western Australian Advancement Council which `condemned the Minister's actions as per section 11 advice to the ADC commissioners'. It said:

We feel that the only true decision-making power that Aboriginal people have ever held has now been lost forever, and sadly, Aboriginal people allowed it to happen. It is painfully obvious that at the end of the day it is `party politics and government priorities' that are the real issues and not `Aboriginal development'.

That is the message that is coming from Australian Aboriginal communities. It is a message of despair, disaster and loss. Mr Hand's commissioners are rapidly ascending the learning curve. They are realising that while it was great to have the Minister appoint them and to make trips to Canberra, some expensive sacrifices are also going to have to be made. The commissioners are already most disgruntled with the Minister for cutting their funding by $26m. They passed a motion on 10 August to record their displeasure and, as a matter of fact, they nearly all walked out.

The most serious question that all this ruthlessness raises is: How can any Aboriginal, Islander, Democrat, State government, Commonwealth body, local authority, or non-government agency be confident that the Minister will not do the same again and again? How can they be sure that they will not be stabbed in the back or dismissed for expressing a different opinion? If a Minister is prepared to dismiss eight commissioners for disagreeing with him, why will it not happen again? This Minister has an obsession with this legislation and nothing is going to stand in his way. He has already dismissed eight commissioners. He has driven Mrs Shirley McPherson out of office and she is going to be a great loss to the Aboriginal community.

The ADC Act is to be crippled by this legislation before the ATSIC Bill repeals it and replaces the ADC with a commercial development corporation within ATSIC which will also be tied to the Minister's apron strings. The ADC Act was set up by a former coalition Government as a vehicle for the promotion of Aboriginal self-management. I think it was set up by Senator Chaney. In 1981 it was agreed to transfer housing funds to the ADC to give it a base for economic development. The role of the ADC was then, and remains, distinctively different from that of a department of state. The current Minister, however, does not seem to appreciate the different requirements of welfare and economic self-management functions. The amending Bill that we are debating deprives the ADC of self-management status. I still cannot get an answer as to why this is being done.

The ATSIC legislation which the Senate discussed earlier today virtually writes out the ADC. On the same day, we are debating a Bill that will do the same thing. The existing Act provides for the Minister to direct the ADC as to the form of its estimates, but does not provide authority for ministerial approval. That power will be given to the Minister by clause 14 of the Amendment Bill. Clause 15 provides for the Minister to give written directions on the administration of the Commission's finances. The Commission has to comply, even if these directions are in conflict with the corporate plan. The Minister now also appoints the general manager who is responsible for the day to day management of the ADC-another loss of power.
Mrs McPherson, the former Chairman of the ADC, advised the Minister that ATSIC and the weaker AEDC would not further the economic development and financial self-sufficiency of Aboriginals. She said:
We believe that the type of arrangements proposed will jeopardise these objectives and those of Aboriginal self-management and decisionmaking.

The Labor Party is practising the most horrific thing, something that Aboriginal people dislike, that is, patronisation. Aboriginal people hate it. Honourable senators opposite are patronising the Aboriginals. They claim that Shirley McPherson will come back, that she will not be lost, but they kicked her out. They tell me that Charles Perkins will not be lost, that he will be back, but they kicked him out. Honourable senators opposite are engaged in something that is most disagreeable to Aboriginal people who absolutely despise being patronised. They hate it. Government senators are saying to them, `Don't worry: we'll kick you out, but keep quiet about it because we will get you another job somewhere'. It is not on. The former Chairman of the ADC also stated:

Splitting enterprise and housing programs and splitting commercial lending activities between the proposed ATSIC, AEDC and the Housing Trust will mean a poorer service to Aboriginal people and a wasteful allocation of resources.

By reducing the power and autonomy of the ADC, the Minister has obstructed the only avenue of escape from welfare dependency that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders have. By placing recruitment practices and administration under the Public Service Act, this Amendment Bill will inevitably lead to the dissipation of the ADC's economic and commercial development expertise. No previous Minister has needed this sort of tight control. Everyone has been able to work within the system, yet two of the Bills we are discussing today gut the ADC. The Amendment Bill is only another proof, if proof is needed, that a new system of Aboriginal patronage exists in Aboriginal affairs under the current Minister. Ministerial appointments, ministerial control and ministerial approval will mean that the favoured few will benefit greatly; the rest, the Aboriginals and Islanders in the communities, will be resigned to obedience to these favoured few. They will be cowed, not liberated; they will be controlled, not in control.

It is clear that the Amendment Bill sets out to control every aspect of ADC activity. No contrary voice will be tolerated. I ask the Australian Democrats, especially Senator Coulter, how they can be sure that ATSIC will not be crushed by the same ministerial domination and obsession that we have seen with the Minister's crushing of the ADC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating cognately two Bills relating to matters concerning Aboriginal people in Australia: the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill and the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill, both of 1989. In opening my contribution to the debate, I recognise the time constraints that the Senate has agreed to in debating these two pieces of very important legislation. For that reason, I will limit my contribution this afternoon to the legislation. I recognise the limitations other speakers are putting on themselves in their contributions this afternoon and for the remainder of discussion on the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal very briefly with the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill. I make the point very strongly that the Government has adopted and accepted the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The Committee was set up last year to investigate a number of matters concerning Aboriginal affairs and it made some recommendations concerning the Institute of Aboriginal Studies. When this Bill is passed, as it undoubtedly will be, the Institute will remain the premier research institution in the field of Aboriginal studies in Australia. It will continue to operate the Aboriginal Studies Press and will continue to publish a wide selection of work related to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues. In passing, I recognise the work of the Western Australian, Ken Colbung, who is the Chairman of the Institute. I trust that he will continue the good work that he has done for Aboriginal people not only in his home State and mine, Western Australia, but throughout Australia.

The second Bill we are debating cognately this afternoon is the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill 1989. Senator Peter Baume, in his opening comments on the Bill, called it `evil'. He called it a number of other things as well. I dismiss Senator Baume's contribution as mere rhetoric. It is the job of the Opposition in opposition to oppose, but the use of words such as `evil' adds very little to the debate. The Bill is a very important one and it is unbecoming of an honourable senator of the calibre of Senator Peter Baume to resort to low tactics such as putting such names on things.

The honourable senator also said that there was very little debate on this legislation and that very little information about the administration of the Aboriginal Development Commission legislation had been given to the Aboriginal community or to the community as a whole. Notice on this was given very early in the piece by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, on 10 December, 1987, in the first major statement about the proposed changes in the administration of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. Those statements were reaffirmed by the Minister and also by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 11 April this year. If the Opposition parties and honourable senators opposite have not come across those statements, I would be more than happy to provide them with copies.

A new arrival in this country, listening to the debate, would think that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was a perfect organisation. I think that is what is being proposed. A stranger to the country or someone unfamiliar with Aboriginal affairs could be led to believe that no mistakes have ever been made in the administration of the Aboriginal Development Commission. That is not true; mistakes have been made. Indeed, those mistakes have been recognised by Opposition parties and Opposition spokespersons as well as by Government spokespersons and people with an intimate knowledge of the Aboriginal Development Commission. As an illustration, I will quote one such Opposition spokesperson, although there are many others. The quote comes from Mr James Porter who is at present the honourable member for Barker in South Australia, although he will not be for very much longer. I will quote a short paragraph of Mr Porter's speech in the other place on 5 October 1984. He stated:

The Aboriginal Development Commission was established by the previous government. However, our initiative in its implementation does not bind us to recognising weaknesses and even disappointments in the operation of the ADC concept as a working instrument for Aboriginal advancement and self-management.
The report identifies a number of specific matters that warrant the serious and immediate attention of both the Commission and the Government.

That is just one quotation to illustrate the point that I am seeking to elucidate here in the Senate this afternoon. If we need further elaboration to illustrate that the ADC is not a perfect organisation, we have to look no further than the special audit report by the Attorney-General which was brought down in March of this year. We could, if we wanted to develop the matter further, refer to the Hansard transcripts of proceedings of Estimates Committee E over the last 18 months to see where a number of miscalculations and errors of judgments had been made by the Commission, the commissioners and so forth.

Here is where we get to the nub of the question. Honourable senators will recall that while those debates were going on within the Parliament and outside it there were a number of calls for the head of Gerry Hand saying that the Minister should resign because of the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio and the administration of the ADC. That call for his resignation was echoed a number of times, including by a number of honourable senators who are in this place at the moment.

Let me quote, to put it into perspective, from the Auditor-General's special audit report of March 1989 into the ADC and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Under the heading `Minister's powers', in paragraph 2.1.5 on page 7 it states:

Under the ADC Act, the Minister has power to give general directions to the ADC but he is not involved in the approval of particular grants or loans. The ADC must provide the Minister with annual estimates of expenditure in such form as he determines but the ADC is not required to obtain his approval of the estimates. In practice, however, the total amount of expenditure by the ADC in the broad categories of expenditure are influenced by the Government in the Commonwealth Budget context. The Minister may add to ADC's functions by notice under sub-section 8 (g) of the Act.

Despite the fact that Ministers have very little power under the Act which was introduced by the previous conservative Government, in 1980 I believe, Mr Hand's head was still called for because a number of errors had been made. What we are doing in the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill, whose second reading is being debated in the Senate this afternoon, is actually attacking the very problem of where the ministerial responsibility is, where the parliamentary responsibility is. We are addressing that. Clause 4 of the Bill which will amend section 8 of the Act is designed to enhance accountability. It will ensure that the Minister could require the Commission to provide information, including financial information.

Clause 5 provides for greater ministerial involvement in the formulation of the Commission's corporate plan. Clause 6 again gives the Minister further powers. If the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission or the ADC does not work in the future, clearly the accountability will be on the Minister's head and Opposition senators, members of parliament and the community at large will rightfully, if things go wrong, be able to call for the head of the Minister, for his resignation to be delivered on a plate. This Bill will, for at least a short time, give the Minister the power to control things.

A number of individuals' names have been mentioned throughout the debate. I want to refer to only one, Charles Perkins. Charles Perkins's resignation, and the manner in which it occurred, has been misconstrued by a number of people for their own motives. Various allegations have been made about what happened on the day of and in the events leading up to Mr Perkins's resignation. Mr Perkins has himself put the details down on paper. He has asked people, if they want to continue to refer to his resignation from his position within the ADC and as Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, to refer to his notes and not put their own interpretations upon them.

I mentioned during Senator Boswell's contribution that Mr Perkins has not departed the scene of Aboriginal affairs in Australia. A person of Charles Perkins's calibre could not do that; he would not physically be able to do that, his conscience would not allow him and he will continue to be involved in Aboriginal affairs. We might find that involvement happens a little sooner than we might wish. Following the next election Senator Charles Perkins might be addressing the Senate, putting the record straight and even taking part in an Estimates Committee meeting when he would not be the subject of the interrogations that have taken place at some of the Estimates Committee meetings. In talking about Mr Perkins and the possibility of his coming into this place, I refer to a newspaper article in today's Melbourne Age which states that Mr Perkins might nominate for Parliament-either the House of Representatives or the Senate. One of my senatorial colleagues, Senator Puplick, would probably be more favoured if he went for the House of Representatives because it is Senator Puplick's seat that would be in jeopardy if Mr Perkins did determine to go for a seat in the Senate.

I have exceeded slightly the time I have allocated for myself on these two Bills. Aboriginal affairs is a controversial issue in Australia today. The fact that it is controversial is not the making of the Government, it is not the making of the Minister, it is not the making of the Minister's colleagues in the parliamentary Caucus. It is not even down to the fact that the Minister happens to belong to the left wing faction of the Australian Labor Party. I am proud to say that I am a member of that faction as well. In the years to come when we can look back in hindsight and reflect on achievements, the name of Gerry Hand will be well remembered and well respected for the changes that he will be responsible for bringing into the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the second reading of the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill and the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill, I would like to concentrate my remarks on the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill. This Bill is designed to tighten up the ADC but we need to ask some very fundamental questions as to why it is seen that that tightening up has to take place. Unlike the honourable senator who spoke just before me, Senator McKiernan, I am certainly not here as an apologist for Mr Hand. Mr Hand's record through this whole sorry, sad saga will certainly mean, as Senator McKiernan said, that he will be remembered but he certainly will not be remembered in the way in which Senator McKiernan was rather hopeful that Aboriginal people in the Australian community would want to remember him.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of very significant events have taken place since July 1987 when Mr Hand became the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I am totally confused and bewildered by the way in which the Cabinet, the Labor Government Cabinet, has succumbed to the pressures of the socialist Left on this issue rather than responding to the genuine, the real, pressures, requests and demands of Aboriginal people throughout Australia. The Labor Government has run to the socialist Left agenda, not to an agenda that is set out to benefit Aboriginal people.

The fact that the Bill before us today is, in effect, complementary to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill of course needs to be carefully considered. We need to look at the motivation for what has occurred. I would argue that much of what has happened in this Aboriginal political area has been vindictive. It has been vindictive against many Aboriginal people throughout Australia. I have read with interest the annual reports of the Aboriginal Development Commission for 1986-87 and for 1987-88-the last one available to us. They are very interesting. Every senator should take the time to put those two reports alongside each other and to draw some significant comparisons.

In the 1986-87 annual report, which was a full report, properly documented, properly set out, with good content from the Chairman and from many other people, it is interesting to note what the then Chairman of the ADC, Mrs Shirley McPherson, had to say in her introductory remarks. She acknowledged:

The Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980 which established the ADC in 1980 is a unique piece of legislation, visionary in outlook and clearly recognising Aboriginal needs. It was only enacted after extensive consultation with the Aboriginal people and with the bi-partisan support of Parliament.
My fellow Commissioners and I have worked hard and responsibly to ensure that the trust placed in us by both the Aboriginal people and the Parliament is fully justified.

Mrs McPherson talked about establishing in that year a corporate plan, a compilation of program procedures manuals and the ADC recognising clear goals, objectives and strategies. Sure, there were still many inherent problems in this whole portfolio area. But at least in 1986-87 Mrs McPherson and the ADC in their report had the good grace to recognise the contribution of other Aboriginal Australians who had participated at the Commission level. Mr Mick Miller, Mr Getano Lui Jr, Laurie Walna and Robert Tipungwuti had all retired during the year and were given proper acknowledgment in that report. The 1986-87 report was comprehensive. It acknowledged the problems, but it also highlighted all of the significant events that were taking place.

By comparison, the shocking annual report of 1987-88, which was tabled recently in this Parliament, is a disgrace. It was obviously compiled with obvious political interference and intervention in the recognition of it. As many honourable senators would know, it is currently under investigation by a committee of this Senate because of its inadequacies and because of the parts of it that are absolutely wrong. The introductory letter to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has the wrong date on it-1989 could not even be put in print, the year before was the date attached to the letter.

The former commissioners of the ADC were sacked by the Minister in the eleventh month of the financial year. They had given an 11-month contribution. But they were not even mentioned anywhere in the report, let alone recognised. I will come, in a moment, to why they were not recognised, to why they were completely overlooked and to the fact that the Minister replaced them. None of them is given any credit for the great contribution that he or she had sought to make. Certain other ADC Board members are inadequately described. The report fails to mention that Mr Charles Perkins was one of the Board members appointed on 13 May 1989. Therefore, he was there for six weeks at the end of the financial year; but he does not even get a credit, a photograph or a biography similar to the other potted biographies in the front section. Why? Because some six or eight months later he fell out of favour with the Minister too and he was obviously removed from any retrospective recognition of the role that he was to play.

There was also no chairman's comment. As we know, Mrs Shirley McPherson has been critical of much of the stance taken by the Minister in developing the ATSIC proposals. So, the chairman's comment was deleted, pulled out, not even acknowledged in the annual report. The photograph of Mrs Shirley McPherson that is printed can only be described as probably the worst one available on the ADC's files. She was put in the report with a snarl on her face and looking downwards. The psychology of the presentation is ridiculous. There is no foreword from the ADC Chairman at all in that year's annual report.

I refer also to the concern about the general manager's overview. This matter has been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for investigation. I have been told by people who have spoken to Mr Mick O'Brien that he has indicated that the overview as published is not what he recalls writing in draft form. It was never submitted in its final form to him for signature. Therefore, the signature appearing for Mr Mick O'Brien is a forgery.

All of this leads me to the fact that it only highlights what Senator Teague so correctly pointed out to us the other day: the Minister, Mr Hand, in May 1988 set out on a vindictive and deliberate plan to undermine the Aboriginal Development Commission. It was a political matter of getting numbers for ATSIC without weighing up the decent arguments that were put forward. Minister Hand was using Aboriginal people, Aboriginal leaders and Aboriginal communities; he was seeking to convey a message for political purposes. Senator Teague pointed out in his comments in the ATSIC debate on 30 August 1989:

My criticism is reserved for the Minister, Mr Hand, who deliberately subverted the ADC to his own political line. The tactics of the Minister's men in the civil war were conspiratorial, secretive and dissembling, using every delegated power to the hilt for their own advantage and using the violence of numbers to bully a conclusion through.
There is no evidence that the Minister has encouraged discussion built on trust, openness, free debate, the tendering of clear evidence or soundly established material.

Senator Teague tabled a transcript of a discussion in July 1988 between eight of the new Hand-picked and Hand-appointed commissioners of the ADC at a meeting, in which there are some very interesting comments. The comments from those Hand-picked commissioners include:
Stand Mick-
that is, Mr O'Brien-
aside and say that the Chief Officer of the ADC is now Mike Stewart and all staff answerable to him. That's it.
. . . we have to override them. Now, that's utilising your authority. Right. Override them. And change their position.

We should knock this into a resolution. Mike Stewart is now the position of the General Manager. Put Mick O'Brien on special duties, and if he can't come at those, we can put him aside. Mike Stewart will hone in on them and Shirley is not to leave Canberra.

The other thing is we want to cover the political scandal. We don't want Mike Stewart getting involved with all the administrative matters. We've got to be careful about that. If we give him all O'Brien's delegations, he's going to be tied into knots. They'll make it hard for him. They'll just try and knock him off. What we want is a politician.

What disgraceful comments from the Hand-picked, Hand-appointed commissioners of the ADC! This situation comes about because the commissioners were specially appointed to do the job on the ADC-not to look after the interests of the Aboriginal people throughout Australia that the ADC had been struggling with since 1980 but to undermine the efforts and all of the other things that have been talked about by other senators today.

The ADC has had to walk through a minefield. But it is very interesting to note that in March 1988 the former group of commissioners put forward an alternative strategy for Aboriginal self-management. This was in response to the Minister's invitation to comment on Foundations for the Future-the preamble, the pre-discussion, to the ATSIC proposals. That alternative strategy needs to be looked at carefully. Mr Acting Deputy President, given the time, I will pursue that issue when the debate resumes.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations. Yesterday the Prime Minister claimed that the Opposition's proposal to give the Industrial Relations Commission real power to enforce its decisions was irrelevant to the pilots dispute because the pilots were allegedly outside the system. Now that Commissioner Paine of the Industrial Relations Commission has made it abundantly clear that the Commission still has jurisdiction in this matter, does the Minister agree that the Opposition's proposal is extremely relevant, and will the Government support it?

—Mr President, I have just seen the press references to Commissioner Paine's suggestions. I do not think they make it abundantly clear that the arbitration commission has jurisdiction in the formal sense at all. As I apprehend it, what Commissioner Paine was saying was that he is prepared to use his good offices as a conciliator in order to deal with the matter. One cannot acquire jurisdiction on the basis of an offer by a commissioner to deal with the matter. His offer is certainly in terms of the conciliation function rather than the arbitral one which would lead to the application of enforcement provisions contained in Senator Chaney's Bill.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question following the Minister's obfuscation. If I can quote Commissioner Paine, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is appropriate therefore to stress, notwithstanding the cancellation of those awards, that it remains open to the federation as an organisation under the Act to bring the dispute to the commission for resolution in accordance with the processes afforded by the Act.

I would say, by way of comment on that, that the same statement could be made with respect to the employers. I ask the Minister: Is he denying that there is a continuing jurisdiction in the Commission with respect to this interstate dispute, that the Commission does have powers of arbitration as well as powers of conciliation, and that what is missing is any power in the arbitration commission to effectively ensure compliance with its decisions? It is in that context that I ask the Minister: Does he not now agree that the matters we are bringing forward by way of legislation are relevant to this dispute-or certainly potentially relevant to this dispute-and will his Government support them?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the Government is willing to support any initiative which is designed to help settle this dispute in the proper way. But I still, I must say, disagree with Senator Chaney that the fact that a commissioner makes an offer like this--
—He has not made an offer. He has drawn attention to their jurisdiction, which we have always asserted.
—I think, of course, the Commission can assume jurisdiction in terms of its conciliatory function, but the Air Pilots Federation having no status in the Commission at the moment, it has no status.
—It is a registered organisation.
—I know, but it has no award. There is no award.
—They do not have to have an award. They have a dispute. That is what awards flow from-disputes.
—Yes, I understand all that.
—That is how you get before the Commission-you manufacture a dispute.

—Yes, I understand all that, Senator. This dispute has been taken outside the Commission. If Commissioner Paine wants to bring it back in by making an offer to conciliate it, that is an appropriate thing for him to do. But I do not think he immediately acquires all the jurisdiction of the Commission, because there is no award.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. Is the Minister aware that Telecom has expended millions of dollars importing public telephones called blue phones from the United Kingdom? Is the Minister aware that an estimated 20 per cent of these phones have revealed faults in operation since their introduction throughout Australia six months ago and that there are long delays in rectifying these faults? Can the Minister explain what steps are being taken to ensure that the public is not inconvenienced further by the high failure rate of these phones and give consideration to placing future orders for the manufacture of such items with Australian companies?

—Senator Colston gave some notice of his question and I have been able to obtain advice from Telecom Australia. Its new blue phones are manufactured by an Australian subsidiary of a United Kingdom company. It has been assembling quantities of the phones and is now preparing to manufacture substantial componentry in Australia. I am also informed that approximately 20 per cent of blue phones installed by Telecom have proven to be defective in operation. These problems have arisen as a result of a manufacturing fault in the coin handling mechanism. Testing of a modification to the coin handling mechanism to avoid such problems is almost complete. As the results have been extremely encouraging, production of the blue phones in the UK and Australia is expected to recommence shortly. In the interim, modified spare parts are being progressively installed to rectify existing problems at known locations.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: PILOTS DISPUTE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask whether he is aware of an advertisement in today's Sydney Morning Herald which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Fly the R.A.A.F. to Hamilton Island!

Now is your chance to fly with the Royal Australian Air Force! A special Hercules service operating in conjunction with Ansett Airlines will fly Sydney-Hamilton Island on Saturdays, commencing September 2.

Does the Minister believe that this is an essential emergency service requiring Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) services? Does the Minister think holiday-makers going to Hamilton Island have priority over Australian soldiers returning from Kangaroo 89, people going about their normal productive business, cases of urgent personal need and, in fact, the needs of other holiday resorts? Can the Minister advise who gave permission for the RAAF to be used in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read today's Sydney Morning Herald, but I wish I had, on the basis of Senator Reid's question.
—Can I table a copy of the advertisement for the Minister's benefit?

—I do not care whether the honourable senator tables it or not. I am asked whether this is an essential service. I would have to find out. I suppose that, for those who want to go there, it is. Do holiday-makers have priority over servicemen returning from Kangaroo 89? I have to say that there have been some claims made about this, including those made in a question yesterday from Senator Newman. I will be addressing those false claims at the end of Question Time. I will make inquiries as to the rest of Senator Reid's question, and let her know the answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Are reports correct that Thai and Australian business leaders will meet during the visit of the Prime Minister of Thailand to Australia to discuss possible Australian involvement in power generation in Thailand? If these reports are correct, can the Minister tell the Senate what progress has been made on the idea? Did he have the opportunity to assess the prospects during his recent visit to Thailand? Has he received progress reports on the proposal from the Australian consortium which is reported to be interested in it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is opportune that Senator Devereux should ask this question today, as we have just attended a luncheon for the Prime Minister of Thailand, General Chatichai. It is true that the press reports-the report I saw was in the Melbourne Age today-an initiative by an Australian consortium in Thailand for a billion dollar value project for the design, building and operation of a black coal fired power station on the eastern seaboard of Thailand. At the present stage the consortium, comprising the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, Leighton Holdings Ltd, Port Waratah Coal Services, CRA Ltd, and the Joint Coal Board, has put an initial proposal in outline to the Thai authorities and will at the end of this year make a full presentation of all the technical details and data to the Prime Minister of Thailand in the expectation that shortly after that there will be a decision by the Thai Government whether to go ahead with the project.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage I would have to say as an observer of these proceedings that the prospects that a project of some sort will proceed in Thailand are relatively good. As I have said, the total value of the project would be about $1 billion. But the expectation of the consortium is that, in terms of material supplied to the power station, about 30 per cent would be Australian content. The feedstock to fuel the power station is most likely to be Australian, high calorific content, low sulphur, low ash, low moisture black coal. It would constitute at a minimum about 60 per cent of the feedstock to fuel the power station.

The Thai authorities are concerned about environmental issues concerning the location of the power station. One of the reasons why I believe that this power project and initiative by the Australian consortium has real legs is that the actual level of atmospheric pollution is much lower than is the case with lignite fuel power stations on brown coal reserves in Thailand. Thus, while any power generation makes a contribution to CO2 emissions, given the very high energy content per unit of input, this is environmentally one of the best ways of power generation.

This project is a good example of Australian initiative in a growing market. The economy of Thailand is expanding by about 9 per cent per annum. The fact that Australia can compete internationally against the best projects proposed by other countries, the fact that Australia is a country recognised world-wide as the leader in coal-based power generation and the fact that Australia now has a real opportunity to demonstrate in situ in Thailand our ability to deliver highly technical, highly complex and very worthwhile industrial development indicates to other Australian industry that the markets that exist in South East Asia for Australian resource development, Australian power generation and Australian transport and communications are very real. If this project goes ahead it will demonstrate our capacity and open up market opportunities for other Australian entrepreneurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask: Is it a fact that the final environmental impact statement (EIS) for the Coronation Hill mine contains a proposal for a new access road to the mine site? Is it a fact that the road would involve major engineering works and that it passes through the breeding habitat of the extremely rare hooded parrot? Is it a fact that this breeding site contains only five breeding pairs, the highest number known to exist anywhere? Is it also a fact that any spillage of transported cyanide or other chemicals along this road not only would contaminate the local environment, but would inevitably flow into the South Alligator River? As the final EIS provides no environmental assessment whatsoever of this road, will the Minister call for the preparation of a preliminary environmental report, or EIS, on the road? Finally, does the Minister recognise that this situation is conclusive proof that the impact of the proposed mine extends far beyond the project area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Before answering the specifics of Senator Sanders's question, I think I should give some background information. I have until 12 September to provide advice to the Minister for Administrative Services, Stewart West, on the Coronation Hill mine environmental impact statement. I have not yet received from my Department its recommendations and its assessment of that EIS. I would expect to do so in the next few days. As soon as I have received them and before 12 September, I will make sure that I address some recommendations to Mr West. As to when a decision might be made on whatever I recommend, I will not attempt to predict a date. Obviously, broad issues are raised in the EIS on Coronation Hill which could have effects on areas quite some distance away. Given that, and the argument which is currently going on about the sickness country, it may be some time before Cabinet can actually make a decision. When I am aware of that taking place, I will let Senator Sanders know.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the specifics, I am aware that the final EIS contains a proposal for a new road to the site. This road obviously carries with it considerable potential for damage to the environment along the lines which the honourable senator has mentioned. There has been no separate environmental examination of that road. It would be up to me to recommend either a public environmental report or an EIS-or I could just say that I did not like the proposal at all, if I thought it was as bad as all that. But I am not going to pre-empt the judgments of either my Department or me. I will wait until I have had a proper assessment placed before me rather than just going on the cursory glance I have had at the final EIS. The decisions will be made very shortly and I will let the honourable senator know as soon as I can. Obviously, endangered species like the hooded parrot need to be looked at very carefully. I can give the honourable senator an assurance that they will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to an article by Glenn Milne which appeared in this morning's Australian newspaper? Can the Minister confirm that to attempt to inflation adjust the income tax treatment of interest would have the types of consequences set out in the article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in which the journalist Glenn Milne sets out a series of major problems that are inevitably associated with Mr Peacock's proposal. He also attributes the credit for bringing attention to those problems to Senator Stone and Mr Blunt. I do not know whether the credit for pointing out to Mr Peacock what a silly idea it is really resides with Senator Stone, but it would not surprise me if it does.

ANSWER.PARA: On the substance of the issues raised by Mr Milne, he points out that there would be massive additional complexities in the Income Tax Assessment Act if Mr Peacock's proposal were to be implemented, adding probably many hundreds of pages to an Act which is generally agreed to be excessively long already or longer than is really desirable. More importantly, probably, it would also discriminate, in the very worst way, against a number of productive Australian enterprises.

The proposal is that the tax system be partially indexed-that is, that only interest paid and received be indexed. There would be no indexation for stocks and no indexation for depreciation of plant or for replacement cost to be used as the basis for tax deduction. Only on borrowings or lendings does he propose indexation. That is a serious distortion which would be compounded if his proposal is to exempt from the interest indexation provisions passive investors, speculators in real estate. It would be further compounded in the worst possible way because another part of the Opposition's taxation policy is to exempt, after a five-year period, capital gains from any taxation.

The final consequence of these four things piled upon each other would be to provide massive penalties for people who invested in mines or factories with the intention of generating income, and huge windfall gains to real estate speculators who invested in land or buildings. In other words, it is exactly what the country does not want. It would give a big free kick, of course, to negatively geared property investments in Bowral favoured by Ferrari-driving, yuppie shadow Treasurers. I do not believe, however, that Dr Hewson will support this proposal, even though he would be a beneficiary from it.

The Department of the Treasury estimates that Mr Peacock's proposal would cost $3 billion to $4 billion on a net basis and that it would also have certain effects. I can confirm that the figures which Mr Milne has used in this article were those used by the Treasurer in a speech that he made on the subject on 9 August. Mr Milne said:

According to figures prepared for the Treasurer, Paul Keating, a comprehensive inflation adjustment scheme would cost the average farmer more than $40 a week, an interstate truck driver would pay as much as $75 a week. The tax bill of a typical service station owner would rise by 75 per cent, and for a motel operator it would double.

The Peacock proposal would provide windfall gains to real estate speculators and would penalise almost everybody who is actually involved in productive enterprise or who may invest in productive enterprise. The additional cost to revenue of the proposal would, of course, either require additional taxes to be raised elsewhere or a lower public sector savings effort. I think there are plenty of people in the Opposition, certainly Senator Stone and Dr Hewson, who understand the problems with this proposal. Their problem is how to bury it without simultaneously burying its author, although that may not be worrying them for very much longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and it follows a statement that the Minister made yesterday in reply to a very user friendly question from Senator Childs. Is the Minister aware that the database on which the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal based its rather amazing recent decision in relation to payments to pharmacists represented a response from only 0.3 of one per cent of pharmacists in Australia? Is the Minister also aware that under the new guidelines pharmacists will actually be required to pay the Government for the privilege of dispensing prescribed items? Accordingly, can the Minister please advise the Senate of any other business or professional group which is expected to provide a service without any mark-up whatsoever or, in this case, provide a service at a loss? Given that the decision is likely to lead to the closure of over 1,000 pharmacies around Australia-a fact which the Government has not denied-can the Minister advise just which health care professionals the Government expects to appear and fill this massive void in primary health care for elderly and isolated Australians? Finally, can the Minister inform the Senate as to the cost to the Australian public of advertisements placed in metropolitan newspapers today in which the Minister has sought belatedly to justify the Government's decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am constantly amazed by Senator Calvert. On Tuesday night I was on duty during the adjournment debate and Senator Calvert made a speech in which he inferentially admitted that he had not read the report. It now seems that he may have read at least some parts of the report. At least that is some progress; I would hope that Senator Calvert would read the whole thing and I would hope he understands these points which are the points I made in answer to the question yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: The Tribunal which brought down this report was set up by legislation of the Fraser Government. The Tribunal stands independent of this Government and its decisions are binding on the Government and on the industry. It is not, therefore, as the honourable senator said in his question a case of when the Government will make a decision. He has said that the Government has a hands-on responsibility in this. It does not; so I think that many of the rhetorical points that the honourable senator has made about effect are points being promoted by particular interest groups to win an argument rather than points that are being promoted objectively on the issues being analysed. They are simply debating points. At this stage it has to be said that the Minister today-or is it tomorrow-is having talks with the Pharmaceutical Association of Australia about the application of this report and that the Minister also pursued, before the Tribunal brought down its decision, an attempt to forge a common approach to put to the Tribunal between the pharmacists and the Government. It was the unilateral action of the pharmacists in withdrawing from that that meant both the Government and the pharmacists put different views to the Tribunal.

I return to these principal features. The Tribunal was set up under legislation enacted during the Fraser years. We have not tinkered with that; it is independent of government; it is binding. If there is a way of resolving these matters, they will be explored fully in the proper talks between the Association and the Minister. Senator Calvert's alarmist rhetoric is just simply an unwelcome addition to what is a serious and important debate in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Whether the Opposition has read the report or not, the Minister has not answered the question I asked. If the Government takes advice from the Remuneration Tribunal, which he said he is bound to do, will the decision, if taken, close down 1,000 pharmacies in Australia? That is what the Opposition is interested in. We could not care less what the Tribunal thinks. It is the pharmacies of Australia we are concerned about.

—Dear, oh dear! This is a tribunal that has sat for many months, has heard over 160 submissions and has come to a decision based on the evidence before it; and Senator Calvert is saying that it does not matter what the report contains. Senator Calvert is concerned about only one thing. I do not intend to add credence to his inflated figures that he bandies around here just to make a political point. The most sensible thing is to deal with issues of this complexity, detail and importance in a properly managed way. We are doing that.

—I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to recent comments from a number of individuals, including the previous Governor-General, which are somewhat critical of the existing regime of consumer credit laws in this country. Can the Minister indicate whether we are any closer to the introduction of revised uniform consumer credit legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner raises probably one of the perennial debates running in the Australian community. The request for uniform credit legislation in this country has been going on for 15 years. Some of the major implications of it are far-reaching. In essence, over the last six years at least we have had a major development in the credit industry and we now have operating a much more national or international industry. Therefore, there needs to be a much more uniform approach in the way that we regulate that particular industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The other part of the problem is that, because of deregulation, there have been major movements in terms of who now has the major part of consumer credit business. Whereas, for instance, six or seven years ago finance corporations may have had three-quarters of it, it is very much the banking sector that now covers that same amount. Given the fact that the legislation as introduced in the 1960s and 1970s was geared towards regulating finance corporation lending, one will find that at least three-quarters of consumers these days are not covered by a very important piece of consumer protection. It not only affects industry and consumers in this way, but also makes it impossible to run national and effective educational campaigns. So it has been the Government's priority for at least the last 15 months or so to bring about agreement with the States in this vital area.

As I have said, the law at the moment does have some inadequacies. It does not cover a major proportion of lending, and to that extent something like four-fifths of lending is not covered. The other problem with it is that, as well as being antiquated, it is also somewhat cumbersome and does not really take into account the needs of industry and consumers into the 1980s and thereafter. It has been a priority of government. At the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers in 1988, this issue was given a pretty hefty kick along. When we met again this year, in 1989, having had the Victorian Law Reform Commission develop in substantial proportion a Bill in plain English to cover this area, Ministers agreed to the publication of that Bill. In fact, I was pleased to be able to release today a copy of the Bill for public comment. The Ministers have agreed to meet later in the year or early next year to further consider industry and consumer response to the draft Bill. As I have said, it has been released this morning. It is important, and the Government sees it as important, for two main reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is cheaper than a press release. You do the press releases here.

—No, I am not reading a press release. First of all, it brings the law into tune with the requirements of both industry and consumers in the 1980s and 1990s. Secondly, it extends consumer protection to those four-fifths of the community that at this stage do not have it. In doing so it covers all parts of a consumer transaction-pre-contract, during the time of contract and aspects of it at the closure of a contract. A most important aspect is that the Bill embodies a very clear and concise requirement as to detailing of interest and all charges levied in a consumer credit contract.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been able to release the Bill for public comment this morning. Some aspects of it still need to be worked out with the States but I feel that those points really nibble at the ankles of major economic and consumer reform here and I anticipate that when we meet in about six months time after the two months consultation period that is to take place we will get further and final agreement and give this legislation the kick along that it really needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Government's announcement in the Budget to introduce a self-assessment system for company taxpayers. Is the Government proposing to introduce a full self-assessment system whereby companies will need to assess their total net tax liabilities and where notices of assessment issued by the Tax Office will be the exception rather than the rule? Is it a fact that if no notice of assessment were issued the Tax Office could go back into the records of company taxpayers years after the lodgment of a return and outside the present three-year time limit which could substantially increase a company's tax liability? Is it also a fact that the right to lodge an objection and challenge a decision of the Commissioner through the courts arises only after an assessment has been issued by the Tax Office? When introducing the legislation for these changes, will the Government protect the rights of companies by limiting the power of the Commissioner to increase the tax liability more than three years after payment of the tax?

—Mr President, I was just looking to see whether I had any briefing from the Taxation Office or the Treasurer's office which would provide enough information to answer that question. I do not seem to have it. There are a very large number of questions and I will get an answer for Senator Messner, but I certainly do not know most of the specifics on which he sought information. My understanding is that the self-assessment system will operate in the corporate sector similar to the way in which it operates for individuals, but I really do not know. I will get the honourable senator an answer.

—Would the Minister, in checking with the Treasurer about that, take into account the statement by the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, in a recent speech when he said that the Treasurer had announced that assessments were to be the exception rather than the rule?
—Yes, I will do that.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to my question on 23 May regarding the North Pacific military exercise, PACEX, scheduled to take place in September-October this year. In the answer it was stated that the Government is aware of the exercise but that the Australian Defence Force (ADF) has not been invited to participate in the exercise and nor will it. The same applied to observer status. Given this statement, I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the fact that the United States Pacific Command in Hawaii finally acknowledged the existence of the proposed exercise on 7 August and that sources in the Japanese Defence Agency stated that almost all United States forces in the Pacific will be involved in the manoeuvres, including those stationed in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines. A press report in the Japan Times dated 9 August also stated that Australia plans to join the event along with Thailand. I therefore ask the Minister whether this report about Australian involvement is true, and further ask whether the United States is trying to hide its embarrassment about PACEX by proposing separate joint exercises-whatever that means-with the Royal Australian Navy which is apparently what it is offering the Japanese? Finally, if the report is true, why is the ADF taking part in an offensive exercise which is based on a scenario of direct confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union which promises to be the largest military exercise in the Pacific since World War II?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing has changed since I answered the question from Senator Vallentine some time ago. I find it difficult enough to believe what is in the Canberra Times let alone what is in the Japan Times. The fact is that there is no change. We have not been invited and we are not participating. We do not believe that any invitation will be forthcoming. I think the honourable senator's references to other exercises apart from PACEX and the United States trying to hide its embarrassment et cetera are a bit over the top. There will be a routine passage exercise with the United States naval forces in South East Asian waters. It will take place in the next few weeks, but it is not part of PACEX '89; it is just part of normal routine operations.

—My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate arises out of the answer which he gave to a question from Senator Chaney at the beginning of Question Time today. In that answer, the Minister virtually pleaded that the parties in the airline dispute should get together or that somebody should get them together. In that event, I ask the Minister the patently obvious question: Why is the Government itself not showing some leadership in this matter and taking some steps to get the parties into negotiation, particularly in light of his view that the pilots are now outside the arbitration system and that Australian Industrial Relations Commission does not have the jurisdiction to provide the sort of leadership and skills needed for negotiations between the parties? If the Government is not willing to take that step, as it has not so far been, what other steps does it propose to bring the dispute to an early resolution before it bleeds the country to death?

—Senator Durack misread me if he thought I was pleading for a settlement of this dispute. I was not pleading for that. I said that the Government would welcome such settlement, as would everybody else. That is a different matter. But if I might just go over the history a little, the Government was at all times concerned that this matter should be dealt with within the confines of the Industrial Relations Commission. The pilots saw fit to withdraw from the jurisdiction of the Commission. Their awards were subsequently cancelled and the pilots subsequently resigned. Senator Durack asked me why the Government is not showing leadership. The Government has all the time indicated that it was primarily a matter for the parties to deal with.
—Why did you stop the parties coming together?
—It is not stopping anybody coming together. Senator Stone should not be silly.
—It is stopping them coming together.

—The honourable senator should not be silly. That is not true at all. As has been indicated on a number of occasions, the airlines are willing to talk about the issues, but at present that does not seem to be happening. Commissioner Paine of the Industrial Relations Commission has offered to deal with the dispute or to try to conciliate it. That is a welcome initiative, but I do not think it is an offer which, as I said earlier, comes within the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission. The Industrial Relations Act requires a dispute to exist between an employer and an organisation of employees. These pilots are no longer employees; they have all resigned. They are not employees within the meaning of the Industrial Relations Act. Senator Chaney looks puzzled. He queried my view about this earlier, and I again repeat it. The jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission in order that that Commission might, if Senator Chaney's Bill were passed, issued an injunction is just not there at the present time. In answer to Senator Durack's question, I would welcome Commissioner Paine pursuing his offer.

—The Minister, in his answer, has tended to spend a lot of time on this sterile question as to whether or not the parties are or are not in the jurisdiction, and the fact of the matter is that it does not matter whether they are or are not in the jurisdiction: nothing is happening at this stage.
