Is he aware that the pilots have said, I understand this morning, that they are prepared to enter into negotiations and that apparently the airlines have said that they are, and yet nothing is happening? I ask: if the Government is not prepared to take any step, is its only answer to this dispute the initiative that Mr Paine seems to have taken, or does it have any other way or ideas of solving it?

—I am glad that the honourable senator describes this as a sterile debate, because the rest of his Party does not think so; they do not think it is a sterile debate. I am very glad the honourable senator thinks it is a sterile debate because the burden of Senator Chaney's question here earlier today, which Senator Durack perhaps did not listen to, was: `Would it not be nice to get this back into the arbitration jurisdiction so my little injunction procedure could apply?'. That was the burden of his question, and I am glad the honourable senator described it as a sterile debate. I think it is too. In so far as the question of bringing the parties together is concerned, if the pilots have said today-and I did not know this-that they want to negotiate, their employers are there and willing to negotiate with them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Will the Minister inform the Senate how many sole parents around Australia have applied for assistance under the Government's recently launched jobs, education and training (JET) program? When does the Government expect the JET scheme to be fully operational? Does the Minister have any figures on how many people are likely to be eligible to participate in such a training scheme?

—The JET scheme commenced operations in March of this year and up until mid-August some 2,500 sole parent pensioners have volunteered to participate. It is expected to become fully operational by November 1990. As for eligibility, all sole parent pensioners-and there are approximately 240,000 of them-are eligible to participate in the program, but it is the intention of the Government to target the program to sole parents who have school age children and who have been in receipt of the pension benefit for 12 months or more; to sole parents where the youngest child is within two years of 16, that being the point at which the entitlement itself terminates; and to teenage sole parents-the third target group. The reason for that, of course, is that these people are, by definition, very young and it would be undesirable if they were to establish at that very young age the habit of not participating in the work force. The JET scheme combines the resources of three Commonwealth departments-Employment, Education and Training, Social Security and Community Services-and is a recognition by the Government of the special difficulties faced by sole parents in attempting to re-enter the work force.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I draw to the Minister's attention an amazing claim in a newsletter issued by Mr Peter Sawyer that hepatitis B vaccine contaminated with HIV-that is, the virus causing AIDS-is recklessly and knowingly being distributed in Australia, and a further part of the amazing claim made by Mr Sawyer that this is part of some grand conspiracy to establish some world totalitarian rule. I hope and trust such a claim is as untrue as many of Mr Sawyer's other claims. I ask the Minister whether there is any substance in any of the claims contained in the document being circulated by Mr Sawyer and whether there is any evidence to support his claim that virus contaminated vaccine is being distributed for use in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of preface to the answer to this question let me say that one of the times of great pride for me as a Minister in this place was when I was a conduit on behalf of Dr Blewett on Monday in putting down the statement on AIDS. It was a matter of great pride because of the positive and bipartisan support of Mr Shack, of Senator Puplick, who spoke in this place, and of the Australian Democrats. It was a fine example of bipartisanship in this Parliament. Indeed, it is bipartisanship of the order that restores my faith that, at times of national need, it is possible to find between all of the parties a degree of unity which perhaps eludes us at other times. I think this is an occasion when the Parliament as a whole can take a bow.

ANSWER.PARA: It is against that background that I turn to the direct answers of a factual nature to the two questions which Senator Peter Baume has asked. The answer to both questions is no. The detailed answer is as follows. A serum derived hepatitis B vaccine manufactured by Merck Sharp and Dohme was approved for marketing in Australia in 1983. The Department of Community Services and Health is satisfied that the procedures used to manufacture the vaccine would destroy any AIDS virus which might be present in the starting material. No case of AIDS has been attributed to use of this vaccine. This vaccine has effectively been superseded since 1987 by vaccines manufactured in yeast, using recombinant DNA technology. The use of this technology overcame the previously limited supplies of the vaccine. Small stocks of the serum derived vaccine have been maintained primarily for use in persons sensitive to yeast products. Total distribution this year has been 125 doses. I am informed that the manufacturer categorically denies that there has been any attempt to promote this product since the advent of the recombinant DNA vaccine. I think that answers the two questions on a factual basis.

I conclude my answer to the general question in the spirit in which I began-a spirit of bipartisanship-by quoting from a press release put out by Senator Grant Tambling of the Northern Territory. We in this chamber all know that Senator Tambling and I have had many disagreements on a number of matters, but let me quote approvingly his press release attacking a letter circulated by Peter Sawyer:
``The extreme right-wing network preys on people's frustration, fears and vulnerabilities to the point where they can be manipulated in support of hidden policies.
``Basically, the philosophies of the League of Rights organisation are racist, anti-semetic and neo-Nazi.''
I agree entirely with those words of Senator Tambling. I think that is the overwhelming view in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories: Further to my earlier question on 1 June 1989, can the Minister advise whether the Government of Western Australia has yet chosen to nominate any wetlands for inclusion on the list of wetlands of international importance which is maintained under the Ramsar Convention, to which Australia became a signatory in 1974. If so, which wetlands have been nominated and when? Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Environment Protection Authority has recently approved a major canal-type tourist development on a wetland near Busselton which has been identified by the Department of Conservation and Land Management as worthy of nomination under the Ramsar Convention? Is the Minister further aware that this area is used by more than 75 species of birds, including 21 protected species under the Japan-Australia migratory bird agreement? What power does the Minister have to prevent destruction of the natural values of the Vasse Wonnerup wetlands which qualify for nomination under the Ramsar Convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that Senator Jenkins asked me some time ago a question about wetlands and their nomination under the Ramsar Convention. The Government of Western Australia has not yet submitted to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service a list of wetlands it may seek to have nominated under the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance. However, I understand that a list of places is currently being considered by the Western Australian Cabinet and I am assured that an announcement will be made in the very near future.

ANSWER.PARA: I have received a number of representations from residents-I will have to hope my pronunciation is correct here-of the Vasse Wonnerup region which indicate their concern over some developments proposed for that area. Last year the Acting Minister for the environment at the time, Clyde Holding, wrote to the Western Australian Minister for Conservation and Land Management advising that the Commonwealth considers that the wetlands satisfy the criteria for designation under the Ramsar Convention. That letter did indicate Commonwealth support. Stage 1 of the Port Geographe development has been assessed by the Environmental Protection Agency in Western Australia and has been approved, as I understand it, subject to certain conditions. This stage of the development is being used as a vehicle to secure the protection of the estuarine system, most of which, as I understand it, is in private ownership. The Western Australian Government has given an assurance-and I am confident it will live up to it-that stages 2 and 3 of that development will be put through a rigorous environmental impact assessment procedure.

I am aware that an officer of the Royal Australian Ornithologists Union produced a report which referred, I think, to the 21 species to which Senator Jenkins referred. Under the Ramsar Convention, the protection of wetlands is implemented through legislation and administrative arrangements that are in force in the States and Territories with coordination of it effected through the Council of Conservation Ministers. Until such time, however, as the wetland is listed the Commonwealth has no power at all to intervene. So at this stage of the game there is no power in Western Australia to intervene, but in any event, I would not assume that stages 2 and 3 will go ahead. There has to be a rigorous environmental examination and we will see what the Western Australian Government determines as a result of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Three months ago the Minister described the Government of Western Australia as being a little slow in its cooperation with the Federal Government. Would the Minister now agree that that is an understatement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I said it was a little slow; now it is a little slower but it is getting there and I am assured it will happen very soon.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister taken heed of the statement of his colleague, Mr Keith Wright, the honourable member for Capricornia, on the Queensland pineapple industry, which is under attack from cheap imports? Mr Wright said, and I quote from the House of Representatives Hansard of 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is a need right now for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, to sit down with the processors and the farmers and talk this issue through.
Mr Wright went on to say, and it is reported in the same Hansard:
I argue for a 10,000 tonne limit and then a penalty rate tariff for anything over and above that.
Will the Minister give a firm commitment to back Mr Wright's proposal of a 10,000 tonne quota on imported pineapple?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of what Mr Wright said in the House of Representatives but I know he has certainly been to see me about the pineapple industry and I said I would look into the matter for him. But the answer to your question `Will I give an unequivocal guarantee to support a 10,000 tonne limit on pineapple imports?, is no.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister and note that he will not support his colleague. Would the Minister be prepared, as an interim measure, to reinstate the 10 per cent Industries Assistance Commission tariff on canned pineapples that his Government has effectively reduced to 5 per cent for developing countries?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is the Minister aware of a statement made by a member of the Australian Federal Police on a television program this morning that there is a possibility that Australia is facing a threat of increased amounts of cocaine finding its way into Australia? Have any steps been taken to meet this challenge and has the breakdown in the justice system in Colombia, the main world supplier, affected our surveillance and information from overseas, or has it had any effect on police operations within Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Jones for his question which indicates his continuing interest in the law enforcement effort directed at trying to curtail the supply of drugs which are abused within the Australian community. I know that he is greatly concerned about the incidence of international drug trafficking, which is a problem that all governments are facing. As international traffickers do not recognise boundaries of nation states, so nations themselves must cooperate in order to ensure that as far as possible this very dangerous and deadly trade is curtailed and, in some instances, one would hope, completely wiped out.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a fact that information coming to Australian law enforcement authorities and, indeed, to me personally on my recent overseas trip, indicates that the drug barons-the war lords in Colombia and other nations in South America-are targeting Australia as one of their next most lucrative markets. Having saturated the United States of America, having done great damage and causing devastation to the whole fabric of many of the inner cities, as I was able to observe recently, and having made inroads into Europe in recent years, the drug barons are now looking to Australia and Japan as countries with a lot of disposable income which can be used for the purchase of these drugs.

The Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority indicated in its recent report, entitled Drugs, Crime and Society, that its best information was that some 84,500 Australians used cocaine in the last 12 months. I hope that those persons who, because they think it is trendy or sophisticated, snort cocaine-or whatever the expression is-realise that they are contributing to the cash flow which leads to the violence, murders and social disintegration which they see on their television sets at night. That is precisely what is happening. There is a huge transfer of money from countries like the United States, the European nations and Australia to meet the greedy, rapacious demands of drug barons and war lords-in this instance of Colombia-for money to sustain their armed forces. This leads to the destruction of their justice systems and, indeed, the whole social fabric. That is what happens when a so-called Australian recreational user uses this drug.

In answer to the question from Senator Jones as to what steps are being taken to meet this challenge, we have found that the best way to inform ourselves and to take steps to interdict the supply of cocaine into Australia is to adopt the same method that we have recently adopted in relation to the importation of marijuana, heroin, ecstasy or whatever it might be-that is, to place Australian Federal Police liaison officers in our embassies abroad. We have them in Bangkok, Manila and Singapore. As I announced to this chamber, earlier this year I placed an Australian Federal Police officer in Argentina. A commercial passenger air link has recently been opened between Australia and Buenos Aires in Argentina. As this is the only service between Australia and South America, we posted this officer to that city. Putting an officer into Colombia would have exposed him to great peril and danger. As we know, many officers of the drug enforcement administration in the United States have been killed in Colombia. I believe that the sort of intelligence we can obtain from that posting will be extremely useful in our, in turn, targeting those who would try to traffic this drug into Australia. Indeed, we have made preparations to send a second officer to Argentina to back up the efforts of the first person appointed.

The question of the importing of drugs into Australia and the way in which we, as a nation, tackle that problem is a very complex one. Through the Australian Federal Police and other agencies we are trying to interdict the supply. But, in the end, unscrupulous profiteers will serve any market in order to make huge profits. They are not concerned about the degradation, destitution or even the deaths of many of our young Australians in particular that they cause. For that reason, the combined efforts of the health and police Ministers in having a program which tries to interdict supply but which also tries to shrink the market by encouraging Australians not to become part of the intoxicated and drug-ridden society which prevails is an important and, I believe, world leading example of the way in which nations should attempt to tackle the drug abuse problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 August, Senator Coulter asked me whether I had misled the Senate on 7 April 1989 in response to a question from him about ivory imports into Australia. I told Senator Coulter on 29 August 1989 that such products had derived from an endangered species and are prohibited from importation into Australia under the provisions of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. The Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act is administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. The Indian elephant is listed in schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act and is totally prohibited. Therefore, goods manufactured from the ivory of the Indian elephant were prohibited from importation for commercial purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The African elephant at that time, namely, 29 August this year, was listed in schedule 2 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act. This meant that imports were prohibited unless a permit was issued. A permit was issued only if the country of origin had in place a management plan which had been approved by the Federal Minister responsible for the Wildlife Protection Act. Only two countries-Zimbabwe and South Africa-had such plans.

Following growing concern about the high volume of trade in ivory from the African elephant, the African elephant has now been transferred from schedule 2-conditional approval, that is, dependent on the management plans-to schedule 1: total prohibition for commercial imports. The necessary changes to the schedule of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act were made by gazettal on 28 August 1989-in fact, the day before Senator Coulter asked his question. As a result, goods made from ivory of the African elephant imported for commercial purposes are now also prohibited. In the context of the question, reference was made to a statement by the World Wildlife Foundation supporting the Prime Minister. I table a copy of that statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

I find the Minister's answer very unsatisfactory. It is unsatisfactory for this reason: on 7 April 1989 we were debating the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3). To that latter Bill, the Australian Democrats moved an amendment which would have had the effect of altering the provisions of that legislation so as to impose, at that stage, a total prohibition on the importation of all worked ivory products. When the matter was raised, Senator Button gave a response which I presume was given on the basis of advice which he had taken from officers present in the chamber. In relation to elephants, Senator Button said in part:

Senator Coulter also raised two matters relating to the Customs Tariff Amendment (No. 3). He drew attention first to the provisions in the Bill regarding worked ivory. He drew attention to the fact that the endangered species which provide these goods-I think it is the elephant only. I think that that is right, is it not?
Senator Coulter interjected and said, `Mainly'. Senator Button continued:

They are under increasing threat from poachers and illegal traders. As Senator Coulter is aware, Australia, as a signatory to the harmonised system convention, is obliged to specify these goods in its national tariff. However, I assure Senator Coulter that, as these products are derived from an endangered species, they are prohibited from importation to Australia under the provisions of the Wildlife Protection (Regulations of Imports and Exports) Act 1982. This Act gives effect to Australia's international commitments under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora.

First, at that point Senator Button did not make the qualification of the difference between the Indian and African elephants in terms of the listing of schedules 1 and 2 of the CITES Convention, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. Secondly, by referring to the increasing threat from poachers and illegal traders Senator Button clearly gave the impression that he was talking about the products derived from the ivory of the African elephant. To the best of my knowledge the question of poachers and illegal traders has not been raised in relation to the goods derived from the ivory of the Indian elephant which is a schedule 1 animal as distinct from the African elephant which is a schedule 2 animal.

It was on the basis of Senator Button's advice to the Senate that the Opposition parties at the time did not support the amendment moved by Senator Coulter. Had we been properly advised by the Minister and his departmental advisers that products derived from the African elephant were in fact schedule 2 products and, therefore, not in the same category as the ivory derived from the schedule 1 Indian elephant, we would have supported Senator Coulter's amendment to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3). We would have amended that Bill. We would have sent it back to the House of Representatives and we would have had the matter dealt with. The fact that we did not support the Australian Democrats' amendment was purely on the basis of the advice given to the Senate by Senator Button, which advice was erroneous.

I resent very strongly that we are given by a senior Minister advice which is incorrect, as a result of which we did not take certain action. The consequence of that was that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) grandstanded on the basis of making that change which the Parliament would have made in April-not in August when the Government got around to it. We would not have been put in the position of having to wait those extra months because of the completely erroneous advice given to us by Senator Button in an answer on 7 April. So a problem was identified. The Parliament was asked to deal with it. The Minister said, `Don't deal with it. It is already dealt with under the legislation'. We deliberately forwent the opportunity to deal with that matter. Almost six months later, the Prime Minister made a grandstanding statement about the matter saying what a great fellow he has been about the whole thing. Senator Coulter had to raise the matter in relation to the answers given by Senator Button, and Senator Button's answer today frankly was most unsatisfactory.

May I say that the Parliament is rightly concerned when a matter of technicality, of detail, of law, is raised with the Minister responsible for the Customs Act. The Minister consults his advisers. He gives an answer to the Senate which is not correct and as a result the Senate declines to take action on a matter which it could have acted upon at the time. Subsequently, this situation is brought about. If that is the best the Minister responsible for the Customs Act can do, after consultation with officers of the Australian Customs Services who are present in the chamber on a debate and a potential amendment, it is a most unsatisfactory situation. I can assure the Minister that, as far as the consideration of similar amendments to legislation are concerned, the Opposition does not intend to put itself in the position of accepting the Minister's assurance on similar matters with the same degree of confidence that we might have in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also extremely concerned about what has happened, because as Senator Puplick has just pointed out, at the time this matter was being debated the issue of the importation of ivory into Australia was already recognised as a very important issue, certainly by many people in the environment movement. On the basis of Senator Button's reply to me on that occasion that ivory was not being imported, I did not pursue the matter then. Therefore, as Senator Puplick has just pointed out, a very significant opportunity to address this matter months earlier than the Government has addressed it has been lost. It is extremely distressing to find that the provision by a Minister of information which is so misleading has prevented a very important matter being correctly addressed and addressed at a time when effective action could have been taken much earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the opportunity which has been lost, of course, is the opportunity which Senator Puplick and Senator Coulter legitimately had to have this issue dealt with by the Parliament three months earlier than it was. In so far as my answer of April led them into that position I apologise. It was the result of the advice I received in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me, however, just recapitulate what the position was as at April. The position at April was that there was a total prohibition on the importation of ivory from the tusks of Indian elephants; there was a prohibition on the importation of ivory from the tusks of African elephants. But in the case of African elephants the prohibition applied unless a permit was issued. A permit was issued only if the country of origin had in place a management plan which had been approved by the Federal Minister responsible for the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act. Two countries, Zimbabwe and South Africa, had such approved plans. So in the total picture of importation of ivory there was only one circumstance, as I understand it, in which it could be imported. It was if a permit was issued and the permit was issued on the basis of an approved management plan in the country of origin.

Nonetheless, I concede that there is a minor discrepancy-I would so regard it-in the answer which was given by me in April. I concede that the action the Liberal Party might have taken in response to Senator Coulter's initiative might have been different. To that extent I apologise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question yesterday by Senator Newman and a further question today by Senator Reid on certain matters relating to the use of defence aircraft in the current pilots dispute. I will attempt to answer both questions now. Ticket proceeds from civilian passengers on Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) flights are to be retained by the airlines. The airlines have reached an agreement with the Department of Defence under which they will either provide or pay for fuel and other operational and maintenance costs on an hourly basis. In effect, therefore, they are chartering the aircraft from the Government. The precise costs of this sort of operation are not yet clear as the RAAF has not undertaken this sort of operation on a scale of this kind before. If the revenue received by Defence from the airlines does not in the end fully cover the RAAF's additional expenses for this operation, the Minister for Defence will seek supplementation for the shortfall through the Additional Estimates.

ANSWER.PARA: RAAF staff are clearly working very hard to sustain this operation. They deserve praise and gratitude for it. RAAF personnel are paid a service allowance in lieu of overtime of over $4,000 a year. This was increased by 123 per cent last year. Since the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal was established by this Government, all national wage increases have flowed on to the Defence Force quickly and in full. Additional rises have also been granted under productivity and anomaly provisions. Because of this, the Defence headquarters have decided that the two-year review allowed for in the Act has not been needed.

In answer to Senator Reid's question on Hamilton Island, the agreement between the Department of Transport and Communications, the RAAF and the airlines is that they will all work out flight details together. The understanding is that the RAAF will service routes that cannot be serviced by other measures. These will include isolated areas like Western Australia and Tasmania and, judging by the advertisement from which Senator Reid has quoted, it would appear that the airlines are seeking to include Hamilton Island in that as well. Given that they are chartering the aircraft, that would be a matter for them.

When it comes to Kangaroo 89, however, to which Senator Reid referred and about which Senator Newman put out a press release yesterday, they are in fact quite wrong in their assertions. Number one priority is being given, and will continue to be given, to defence personnel returning from Kangaroo 89. Qantas Airways Ltd will be taking up what the domestic airlines may have taken up had they been in full operation. There is no truth to the claim that defence personnel are being downgraded in any way in priority. They are priority No. 1 and will remain so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in response to Questions without Notice asked by Senator Newman on 30 August 1989 and Senator Reid this day, relating to the use of Defence aircraft during the airlines dispute.

There are undoubtedly some matters in Senator Richardson's response which Senator Newman will want to respond to when she has the opportunity to do so. In the first part of his answer, the Minister indicates that the arrangement between the Government and the airlines is a charter arrangement, but he clearly is not able to tell us what the basis of it is. Normally, if one hired a plane or a car, one would know exactly what was being paid. The Minister goes on to say that, if what is finally worked out to be the cost does not actually cover the costs, the Minister will be seeking funds from the Additional Estimates later in this financial year. It leaves me almost speechless to think how one could possibly have an arrangement for charter whereby--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator.

—It is not often that I am speechless, Senator Button. It is amazing to think that one can have an arrangement whereby an aircraft is chartered and then find out later that what one is prepared to pay does not cover the cost. I hope that, sooner rather than later, the Government will give us an explanation. How could any additional estimates even be contemplated in those circumstances? I believe that the explanation that it is a charter is something that the Government has thought up afterwards to try to explain what is going on and to get around this particular type of advertisement. Why is the Government not putting on special planes to fly to Ayers Rock? Tour operators out there are suffering mightily as a result of what is going on at the present time. I could spend the rest of the afternoon telling the Senate about the difficulties that the operators here in the national capital are having in filling their hotels as a result of conventions that have been cancelled at the National Convention Centre and other places.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear from this advertisement that there is some fairly neat arrangement between the Government, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Hamilton Island to get flights to that island. Would we not all like to go? It is on Saturday of this week. How is it that it is Hamilton Island that is being favoured over and above every other resort in this country? I do not believe that the Minister's explanation is adequate. I do not believe that the suggestion that it is a charter, where the Government cannot tell us the cost of chartering the aircraft, is adequate. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUDITOR-GENERAL'S REPORTS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President I present the following four reports of the Auditor-General for 1989-90:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report No. 6-Department of Employment, Education and Training-Post-graduate Awards
Report No. 7-Department of Employment, Education and training-CRAFT
Report No. 8-Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-ACT Administration
Report No. 9-Department of Defence-Post Separation Employment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Auditor-General's Reports Nos 2 to 9 of 1989-90 tabled on 30 and 31 August 1989.

I particularly want to draw attention to the Auditor-General's Report No. 5 presented yesterday relating to the Department of Employment, Education and Training-Jobstart. I want to draw attention to the fact that the Auditor-General clearly has pointed to some serious problems in this program. It is a program that quite frankly has not in fact achieved its objectives. This Government's management of it has been apparently incompetent and I think it is very important that the Senate be aware of the Auditor-General's comments in his review. For example, on page 7 the Auditor-General concludes:

. . . on the basis of the review that there was an urgent need for the Department to examine the operation of Jobstart to determine whether it was meeting the needs of the long-term unemployed as prescribed in its objectives.

In other words, the Auditor-General is questioning whether the Government has made another muck-up with another of its highly publicised but largely incompetently run, misdirected and wasteful endeavours to be seen to be doing the right thing by a targeted political group, and that is in this case a segment of those people who are unemployed.

This Government's gestures and posturing in this area have been exposed by the Auditor-General. It is all very well for the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to smirk and scratch his head over this; he obviously has not read the report. I think it would be very useful if he did because then he would see that the Auditor-General reveals that 58 per cent of participants failed to complete the full 26 weeks of subsidised employment work experience. This, by the way, is in the Queensland division.

The Auditor-General says that the Department should establish the reasons for the high drop-out rate to determine whether Jobstart was in fact meeting the needs of individual participants. Here we have the Auditor-General, fortunately, having the fortitude to question whether this Government program, which has more political than practical overtones, should in fact be examined to see whether it is doing what it is supposed to do. This is, as I said, simply another example of the Government trying either to paper over the cracks or to spend money trying to create an illusion that it is doing something meaningful for political purposes.

Mr Deputy President, there are many other criticisms in the Auditor-General's report. Briefly, the response from the Department to some of those criticisms has been strong and well argued. The Auditor-General has conceded that there have been improvements since the audit took place, but he persists that some criticisms remain relevant and unsatisfied. In these circumstances, there is a clear need for the Government to do what the Auditor-General advised and see whether Jobstart does anything more than serve some political purpose and whether this enormous drop-out rate is justified. The Auditor-General also raised the question about whether the program was properly run in the first place because people in the over-45 age bracket are getting a raw deal as a result of Government policy. Quite properly, these matters should come to the attention of the Senate. I hope the Government will do something meaningful to respond to the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also make some comments on the same Auditor-General's report referred to by Senator Michael Baume. I do so because the Government is expending some hundreds of millions of dollars on a series of so-called training or work enabling programs. It seems to be something of a speciality of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to produce another set of initials with a flash program which is supposed to meet some perceived social need. When an Opposition gets up and says that it thinks something like Jobstart is a waste of taxpayers' money, it is very easy for a Government member to stand up and say that the Opposition is being hard-hearted again and ignoring the needs of the unemployed. I must say, however, that this report bears out the concern which I have felt about this Department since the beginning of this decade. It has a record of non-performance which is very serious.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had very high youth unemployment for most of this decade. We have had significant unemployment for the whole of this decade and a very substantial amount of money is expended on programs such as Jobstart. There is a great deal of scepticism in the Opposition about the effectiveness of those programs. The important thing to note is that this is an assessment of just one of those programs by the Auditor-General's Office. The fact that it is the Auditor-General's Office, a non-political body with no political axe to grind, which makes the criticisms is important to note because the criticisms it makes of the program are so severe as to suggest that it ought not to continue. This program is not small potatoes. It is $85m worth of job subsidies which are handed out. As Senator Michael Baume pointed out, the Auditor-General has found that there is a frightening degree of failure.

The report points out that 21.5 per cent of participants leaving Jobstart ceased within six weeks of starting; that 39.5 per cent dropped out within 13 weeks; and that in total 58 per cent of participants failed to complete the full 26 weeks of subsidised employment or work experience. It is always a problem to know whether a subsidised place is an additional place. Everybody knows that employers can arrange their employment requirements to take advantage of subsidies, but everybody also knows that some employers genuinely use this to create positions that would not otherwise apply. One cannot therefore make a blanket condemnation. However, when we find that almost six out of 10 of the participants in a program do not stick with the job for the 26 weeks of the subsidy period, it is time to ring some alarm bells and to question whether the hundreds of millions of dollars which are being spent on this and like programs are being wasted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The way they were with CEP.

—Senator Michael Baume assists me with his comment by reminding me of the disastrous waste of money under CEP and the very poor quality assets that were often purchased at enormous expense with very, very limited social value. My reason for wanting to intervene in this debate is that I think this would be one of the 200 programs that Senator Peter Walsh identified a year and a half ago as being the sorts of programs which represent a significant waste of taxpayers' funds and which need attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise the matter in the context of this program review because every Liberal and National Party senator knows that as soon as one of us raises an area of waste, we are accused of being heartless, not being concerned with the unemployed, not being concerned with the poor or whatever. The truth of the matter is that to throw hundreds of millions of dollars of the taxpayers' money into waste bins, and obviously a large proportion of this money is effectively thrown into the waste bin, is not doing anything for the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is coming off technical training.

—As Senator Watson, who I think is going to take part in this discussion, is saying, it is happening at the cost of technical training. The fact is that we have a hotchpotch of programs. The initials are quite extraordinary: We have got ITS, FAT, JET, Jobstart, Skillshare, and so it goes. This is in the finest tradition of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Senator Peter Cook, who is at the table, has taken something of an interest in labour market matters. He would be as aware as any honourable senator in this place of the extent to which many of these programs represent a nice set of initials, a nice set of brochures and very little else. My purpose in intervening is to say that, in the Opposition's view, this is an area for Government attention. This is an area where Senator Walsh should stop being coy, should admit that this is one of the 200 programs which are in drastic need of cutting and the Government should take a constructive attitude to that instead of every time the Opposition raises one of these matters, accusing us as being Darwinians. We are not Darwinians. We simply say that, as the Auditor-General has exposed, there has been a gross amount of waste in these programs and it should not continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the various reports submitted today by the Auditor- General. Included in that package is Audit Report No. 4 on the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) which deals particularly with Aboriginal student assistance schemes. I would highlight for the benefit of the Senate that some $74.1m was spent on Aboriginal student assistance schemes around Australia last financial year and in the Budget Papers the Government has recently announced that this amount will be significantly increased in the current financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The report that we are considering today shows that an investigation by the Auditor-General into the administration of these schemes in the Victorian branch of the Department of Employment, Education and Training found very fundamental administrative and financial weaknesses. Specifically, the report refers to the fact that the proof of aboriginality was not generally sought from applicants; secondly, that enrolment and attendance checks were not undertaken; thirdly, that administrative policies were not adequately developed in some areas and that computer facilities available through the Department's education student assistance system were inadequate and did not, inter alia, facilitate processing of benefits, the application of cheques to avoid duplicate payments, recovery of overpayments or the development of an appropriate management information system.

We can criticise the Department because of these administrative errors that have been highlighted, but more particularly we need to look at the impact that this has on students. I am familiar with the fact that the problems in Victoria are reminiscent of the problems in the Northern Territory and perhaps nationwide. For example, earlier this year I had representations from some 50 students attending the Northern Territory University who were forced to seek emergency loans as a result of the administrative bungling in the Darwin office of DEET. There were long delays in the processing and payment of Austudy and Abstudy entitlements which meant that some students were forced to wait for six weeks or even longer for their benefits. Not surprisingly, some of these students even considered dropping out of courses. That particular problem is not being appreciated in a debate of this nature. If students are being forced to drop out of courses because of departmental bungling we have a very horrific situation.

Other complaints that were lodged with me about the Northern Territory Office of DEET focused on high staff turnover, inadequate training, the lack of communication with applicants and an inability to address in-house departmental problems. I highlighted the matter in various press comments in the Northern Territory. It created quite a degree of debate and comment from other people. Perhaps the reaction was best highlighted by a letter to the editor in the Northern Territory News on 15 May this year by a constituent of mine, Mrs C. Shilling of Stuart Park in the Northern Territory, who said:
I can assure Senator Tambling that six weeks is a very speedy time for processing-the applicant with whom I have been involved has waited for four months.
During this time there has been incorrect information given, documents mislaid, refusal to answer the phone or return messages and meaningless platitudes to fob off inquiries.

The matter was addressed, I will accept, by a spokeswoman for the Minister for Employment and Education Services, Mr Peter Duncan, who admitted that the processing of the tertiary student allowances in the Northern Territory took longer than anywhere else in Australia. The reason, she said, was unclear.

On 26 April this year I wrote to the Auditor-General asking him to look at the administrative practices and the financial procedures within the Department's Northern Territory office, which I considered to be hopelessly inefficient and which had led to very serious errors in the provision of Abstudy and Austudy. I called on the Auditor-General to investigate the local office of the Department and to look at ways of preventing a repeat of the shambles next year. The Auditor-General has responded to me by saying that audits of the State offices of DEET had `detected weaknesses in administrative and financial procedures'. The Auditor-General added that the Australian Audit Office planned to investigate the Abstudy scheme in the Northern Territory in 1989-90. Given what I have read in this report today on the Victorian situation, I do not believe it will be good enough to wait for a subsequent Auditor-General's report for the Northern Territory.

This problem must be occurring right around Australia. The Auditor-General has said that he accepts that he must undertake surveys and studies of the other State offices of the Department, which shows that there must be considerable problems. I have a number of Aboriginal students in my electorate who attend colleges such as Kormilda, a significant secondary college in the Northern Territory. I am aware that students there who are entitled to Abstudy grants have had to wait considerably longer periods than the six weeks or four months that were relevant to the Northern Territory University. These students come from isolated Aboriginal communities such as Lajaimanu in the western regions of the Northern Territory. In trying to sort out the administrative nightmare, the Aboriginal students want to take their problems back to their families but the communication system does not make that a viable option. In fact, the issue has compounded so much that at a meeting of the Isolated Children's Parents Association recently held in Perth a motion was passed condemning the incompetence of the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Darwin and requesting that the head office in Canberra intervene. I certainly hope that that Department is looking seriously at the plight of these Aboriginal students that has now been highlighted by this report on Victoria. I hope it is looking at the magnitude of the problem right around Australia. The situation is intolerable. It cannot be allowed to continue. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIA AND THE PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFERENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, this third report to the Australian Government entitled Australia and the Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference is an important document because it deals with a vital area for Australia's well-being, that is, the future trade between Australia and not only Japan, China and the other areas of east Asia but also the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN)-indeed, the United States and the whole Pacific region. The great majority of Australia's trade lies in this area and it is understandable that from the early 1980s an initiative has been taken to have a national Pacific cooperation committee. The Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference, PECC, has been held some six times at 18-month intervals, and the last was held in May in Osaka, Japan. Sir Russel Madigan, as Chairman of the National Pacific Cooperation Committee of Australia, has brought this report to the attention of the Australian Government and, by its tabling, recently to the attention of the Parliament and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a very close interest in the increasing success of Australia in trading in the entire region. There is no doubt in my mind that by early next century the Asia-Pacific region will be the centre of world trade. Over the last 400 years since the end of medieval times we have seen a shift in the focus of world trade from the Mediterranean to the North Atlantic and from the North Atlantic to the entire Atlantic Ocean, particularly the trade with Central, South and North America. I believe that the centre of world trade, which has been very much between Europe and the Americas, will be put into the shadow of the majority activity occurring in the Asia-Pacific region.

I am pleased that a very experienced former Australian Ambassador to China, Dr Ross Garnant, has been commissioned by this Government to give a far-sighted analysis of trading prospects in the region. I also want to endorse directly the Australian Government's initiative, supported by the Opposition, to call together in early November the Foreign Ministers of the six and the five-that is, the ASEAN six and the United States, Japan, Canada, New Zealand and Australia-into an 11-nation conference to look at ways of increasing regional trade in the Asia-Pacific.

Last week I represented this Parliament as an observer at the ASEAN interparliamentary organisation and this concept, called the Australian initiative, was one of the principal items for discussion. It is warmly received by ASEAN countries and there is a great deal of expectation about the Foreign Ministers' meeting here in Australia in November.

I also want to draw to the attention of the Senate an article in the Far Eastern Economic Review of 17 August by Mr Jusuf Wanandi, a person whom I have met in Jakarta, where he is the Director of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies. He is a far-sighted and excellently qualified person in economic matters. I will seek leave to incorporate that part of his article which refers to principles of cooperation and six introductory points that should govern the cooperation that is being looked to in this Asia-Pacific trade. I would have loved to expand upon those six matters. I happen to agree with Jusuf Wanandi, and I think they fit very well as a contribution to the context of the coming trade. I will therefore seek leave at the end of my speech to incorporate that paragraph in Hansard. I just conclude by commending the work of the National Pacific Cooperation Committee of Australia and the way in which a whole new environment has been achieved in the later 1980s that is of benefit to Australia and the entire region.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The first condition concerns the principles of cooperation. The following six points have been put on the table:
Pacific economic cooperation should be based on independence, mutual respect and equality.
This regional cooperation should complement Asean's regional activities and role in the Pacific, and should strengthen multilateral mechanisms for cooperation, particularly Gatt.
This cooperation should not lead to the creation of an economic bloc or an exclusive trading arrangement.
It should be developed in a gradual fashion and be properly planned.
The objective of cooperation should be to increase the welfare of the people in the Pacific region and to reduce the gaps between the developed countries and the developing countries in the region.

This cooperation should contribute to the creation and maintenance of a stable and open trading system, regionally and globally, and a regional environment which is conducive to the promotion of mutual interests, including the ability to resolve regional conflicts peacefully.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE PROTECTION ACT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Knowles:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this report was first debated after it was presented here in this chamber I did not get a chance to speak, and I had wanted to at the time. I take this brief opportunity now to make some remarks. This is a most inadequate report and it comes after a most difficult year for the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I think it is disgraceful that this is the first annual report of the ADC which does not include the statement, or foreword, or introduction by the Chairman of the ADC, and I would like to know why that is not included.
—It has been referred to a Senate inquiry.

—Senator Tambling says that it has been referred to a Senate inquiry, and it is right that it be referred to a Senate inquiry because the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, who has lost the trust of this side of the Parliament, and indeed of half of the Aboriginal communities of Australia, sacked--
—What do you mean by `half'?

—I think it could well be more than half, Senator Boswell, but I am trying to be as objective as I can. This Minister, on 11 May, sacked eight out of 10 of the commissioners of the ADC in the period of this annual report, yet there is no mention of it in this annual report. The Commission was gutted by the Minister and there is no mention of it in this official report, a report not only to this Parliament but to the people of Australia. The Chairman, whom the Minister could not sack but wished to sack because she was appointed under a different clause, a different power, under the ADC Act, that is, by the Governor-General, was then isolated by the Minister's cronies and was not only forbidden to have any impact outside of Canberra in any public place by making any submission but also denied, by some administrative technique, from being able to put any comment of her own in this annual report.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the biographical descriptions that relate to the commissioners happen to be the briefest, the most rudimentary, with regard to the Chairman and are expansive with regard to each of the eight commissioners that were appointed by the Minister on 13 May. There happens to be a giant omission and that is that Charles Perkins, who was also appointed as one of the new commissioners by the Minister on 13 May, does not happen to be listed. Yet, the heading states:
Commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission at 30 June 1988 were

They are all listed, except one. Mr Perkins was not an insignificant appointment. At the time he was the Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Indeed, a few months after the end of this reporting period he was sacked by this Government not only as the head of the Aboriginal Affairs Department but also from the Aboriginal Development Commission. He ceased to hold any of his offices.

I believe that just in those three instances alone there are serious questions to be answered not only by the ADC but also by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs as he is responsible for this statutory authority. I also need to ask in this context, given these sorts of omissions, whether the General Manager's two-page overview at the beginning of the report was, in fact, written by him and whether the signature is his. I want to know whether or not this report, therefore, is bona fide and, if it is not, is it in contempt of this Parliament and the public of Australia? The Minister and the ADC need to answer a lot of questions with regard to these arrangements. It is an inadequate report and I look forward to the report of the Senate inquiry into this matter.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDELINES FOR THE PREPARATION OF DEPARTMENTAL ANNUAL REPORTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to outline the role of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in relation to the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports. Section 25 (6) of the Public Service Act 1922 requires the Secretary of a department to prepare and furnish to the Minister administering the department an annual report on the department for the year ended 30 June. Further, section 25 (7) provides that the reports prepared under section 25 (6) shall be in accordance with the guidelines from time to time presented to the Parliament by the Prime Minister after approval by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Accounts Committee is continuing to review past guidelines. In fact, it is not the only committee that is concerned about this issue. I would certainly like to acknowledge the important contribution that has come from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, in particular its contribution on the reporting of statutory authorities. That Senate Committee report recommended that urgent action be taken by the Department of Finance and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to develop new draft guidelines and that these draft guidelines should be referred to the appropriate parliamentary committee for consideration. It recommended the Joint Committee of Public Accounts as the appropriate committee. In fact, that Committee has the matter of reporting of statutory authorities under consideration at the present time.

I would like to give a number of examples of certain deficiencies. At page 129 of the Defence report for 1987-88 the Secretary of the Department of Defence refers to safety principles for explosives and talks about Australian Audit Office findings, observations and notations. It is significant that there is no mention of any action by the Department in relation to those Audit recommendations. This is a major oversight. These are matters which the Public Accounts Committee is looking at.

Also, we are concerned that a number of departmental Secretaries are not taking the full responsibility that they should. There is certain evidence that some departmental Secretaries are delegating these responsibilities to subordinates on the basis that they have faith in their colleagues' capabilities. This is a complete abrogation of a Secretary's role in relation to his responsibilities towards meeting the requirements of the Parliament. In fact, the Public Accounts Committee, through its Chairman Mr Robert Tickner, has warned that it will take very stern and tough action against departmental secretaries to ensure that they respond to parliamentary papers in their annual reports.

It is interesting to note that we took issue with, and took to task, Dr David Charles of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce because he took 18 months to respond to an important report on the offsets program. We were concerned about the superficial and fragmentary nature of the formal Government response to that report. The Public Accounts Committee has certainly put all departmental Secretaries on notice that it expects a higher standard from them and an appropriate response to the existing guidelines. In addition, the Committee and the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration are looking to ensure that guidelines are toughened up in certain areas, particularly in relation to statutory authorities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PULP MILLS: MODERN TECHNOLOGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the report to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) entitled Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection. The Senate first considered this report on 17 August this year. I heartily endorse the contributions of my colleagues Senators Watson, Puplick, Archer and Stone on that date. I urge people interested in this paper to look at the Senate Hansard of 17 August to see what they had to say in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: This report on pulp mills really arises out of the Wesley Vale disaster-I do not think there is any other way to describe it. A proposal was put forward to build at Wesley Vale a pulp mill of major importance to this nation. When I say that it is of major importance to this nation, let me also quote what the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, said in a press release on 18 August 1988:

This project is very important for the forest industries in Australia. It will mean adding value to the product. It will mean up to $300m net addition to the balance of payments and create an average of 800 jobs in the construction phase each year for three years and then 400 jobs in the operating phase.

Yesterday, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in an address to the National Press Club, repeated the points which the Opposition spokesmen have been making for 18 months. At last the Government has got the message. Of course, Senator Walsh, while he represents the Government as Minister for Finance, in many cases does not represent the views of his colleagues. But he took up the point that we are all concerned about the environment. We are concerned about many things. We want to do many things. Especially on our side of the chamber we want to do what we can for the aged and the young. We are concerned about education and health. But there is very little we can do unless we get the economy right. This economy is not right. We had an opportunity to do something to alleviate our current account deficit, which has been running at over $17 billion for this year. It will probably be around $20 billion for this year. But Senator Richardson stuck his nose in and told the joint venturers that their proposed plans were not good enough, that there were not sufficient levels of environmental protection. He imposed certain obligations upon the joint venturers, as a result of which they walked away from the project.

This report, prepared by eminent scientists, discloses the untruth of Senator Richardson's criticism, because the proposal involved a targeted level of effluent toxicity of level 4. That is the highest level aimed at by the rest of the world. For example, the Canadians, who currently have a level of 1 and 2, are hoping to achieve level 3 by 1994. This proposal was at a toxicity level of level 4 right from the outset, yet this Government, through Senator Richardson, destroyed this project, one of the economic projects that may have helped get this country out of its current hole. The environmental level would have been as good as any in the world-better than most countries. The Canadians were aiming for it in the mid-1990s. The proposal was rejected because Senator Richardson stuck his nose in and interfered. So the joint venturers walked away. I say they walked away because that is the truth, notwithstanding the Government's attempt to rewrite history by pretending that they did not walk away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (DIRECTIONS TO STOP INDUSTRIAL ACTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1989 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure this afternoon, in supporting Senator Chaney's Bill, the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill 1989, to detail to the Senate why we have brought this Bill back on. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of Australia and his Labor Government are going to learn the hard truth of Abraham Lincoln's saying that you cannot fool all of the people all of the time. Governments will be judged on what they do, rather than on what they say. The core of this problem is that the Labor Government angrily denounces striking pilots while scorning the positive solution put forward by the coalition as recently as a fortnight ago today. It is an absurd proposition for the Government to claim, as it has done repeatedly, that the current dispute is an example of the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

SPEECH.PARA: We must remember that the Labor Government is in office at this time. This strike is happening under the control of a Labor government. It is its policies that are exacerbating this situation. It is the macho mouth of the Prime Minister of this country that inflamed the strike in the first place last week. This Government is at its wit's end to know what to do about it. It is not the Opposition that has changed tack on this issue. It is clearly the Government that has ducked and dived and weaved all over the place trying in vain to find a solution. The solution was quite clearly put by Senator Chaney and my colleagues a fortnight ago. Yet the Government, with the aid of the Australian Democrats, voted against a Bill that would have brought an end to the strike that we are seeing today.

The overall position held by the Liberal and National parties is clear and logical. It has always been so. Either employees and employers withdraw from the centralised wage fixing system and negotiate binding agreements that are productivity based, or they stay within an arbitration system that is made to work.

Our Bill was aimed at giving the arbitration commission some teeth. What happened? The Government, aided and abetted by the Democrats, voted against it. The Prime Minister simply cannot have it both ways. The pilots, who make a wonderful propaganda target as tall poppies on high salaries, whose union is not affiliated with the Labor Party and whose members are not generally thought to be Labor voters, are accused of being glorified bus drivers working eight hours a week.

The Opposition in no way condones what the pilots are doing. That, I wish to make very clear this afternoon because it is the Government that is trying to give the story that we are condoning the action of the pilots. We are not condoning the action of the pilots. We are putting forward legislation that should enable the pilots to talk with their employers and come to voluntary agreements, as I have said, that are productivity based. So be it if the pilots need to work more hours. So be it if their productivity has to be increased in other ways. At the same time, the Government rejects Opposition legislation that would introduce effective compliance provisions to the Industrial Relations Act. Rhetoric and limited bandaid measures against the pilots strike are easy. But positive and sensible reform is unacceptable to the Government.

The rejection of the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Bill was not a mere procedural matter whereby governments follow the established, if not regrettable, practice of rejecting Opposition legislation, simply because it comes from the wrong side of the Parliament. One needs to go back and look at Senator Aulich's contribution but a fortnight ago, Senator Burns's contribution but a fortnight ago, to see how bad and how inflammatory their contributions were, and then have a look at the conduct of the Prime Minister last week. One will then see why this strike has got right out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is interesting to hear an interjection from Senator Collins that that is rubbish. It would be very interesting to hear from Senator Collins later on in the debate, because he is further down the speakers list, why that is rubbish. Even though the pilots admit, and many Government members are prepared to admit-without wishing to name names-that the Prime Minister did inflame the pilots dispute, the Government voted against a Bill only a fortnight ago just because it was our Bill. It flew in the face of all the support that had been given to the Bill. The Government has just been conned again by Simon Crean from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-the political masters of this Labor Government. It was Ralph Willis who agreed in 1987 with Senator Chaney. He promised to introduce a proper directions procedure that would give the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission some teeth, but he had to back off because Simon said. We are left with an arbitration commission that has no teeth.

SPEECH.PARA: If the employers and the pilots cannot agree to a solution, the matter should go to effective arbitration-and I emphasise the word effective. It has been made quite clear to the Senate that the Labor Party is fundamentally opposed to any commonsense solution such as strengthening compliance provisions to make centralised arbitration work. This Government, on the eve of a disastrous, ruinous dispute, has treated us to the same old pro-union rhetoric which might have been true in the 1890s or the 1930s but which rings very hollow in this day and age of 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will fix it, will it?

—Yes, this Bill will fix it. It is a pity for this country that the Government and people like Senator Collins are so narrow minded and so biased that they cannot accept that this legislation will provide a viable solution to what is happening to this country today.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told by Senator Aulich, who was the leading spokesman for the Government a fortnight ago, that employers are always in the box seat in industrial disputes. We get the same self-interested bleat that `enforced compliance with the law' is not a solution to industrial disputes. What a joke! We have been told by this outwardly macho Government that bringing parties under the scope of common law is the worst possible way to handle industrial disputes. They are the Government's words; they are not mine. These words and the actions of this Labor Government show where its fundamental loyalties lie-with the big battalions of powerful ACTU unions which, in this Government's view, have a God given right to stand outside the law. That is just unacceptable.

The reason this Hawke Labor Government has set its face against reform of compliance procedures is that the ACTU forbids it. We all know that a blue collar union that takes action outside wage fixing guidelines and causes massive economic damage will not be faced with legal sanctions and penalties if its good mates in Cabinet can help it. But pilots are different! Can anyone imagine macho Prime Minister Hawke getting stuck into the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia or into the Builders Labourers Federation in the same way as he got stuck into the pilots last week? It is not likely. He would not be giving them a smack in the chops. He would be kowtowing to them, he would be kowtowing to Simon Crean, and doing whatever they wished to try to get them inside the guidelines.

We only need look back to 1987 to see how readily this Government withdrew even the cautious and flawed compliance provisions then put forward that were too much for the ACTU. Yet, the then Minister admitted that it was essential that `there should be an effective means of ensuring adherence to the principles on which the system is founded and compliance with the decisions of its institutions'. They were the Minister's words then. What a shame they were never brought to fruition. What the coalition has proposed is not some radical destruction of the arbitration system. All we are seeking to do is to introduce the sanctions without which it fundamentally cannot work. One has only to look at what bodies such as the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) have to say. In a media statement yesterday, Wednesday, 30 August, the Confederation of Australian Industry-the largest employer group in the land-commented that there was a need for sanctions in the industrial relations system. In commenting on the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill the Director General of the CAI National Employers Industrial Council, Mr Bryan Noakes, said:
The absence of effective means by which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission can enforce its orders and awards is a fundamental flaw in our industrial relations system.
Probably the most telling part of this press release is the last paragraph. It states:
If the Commission had the powers proposed in Senator Chaney's Bill, the deplorable consequences of the action by airline pilots could have been avoided.
The silence is deafening from the Government now, is it not? The Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. (MTIA) commented:

In introducing in the Senate a private member's Bill on industrial relations, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, has done the community a service by focusing attention on the need for long-overdue compliance provisions in the compulsory conciliation and arbitration system.
Apart from many other things, the MTIA went on to say:

The Opposition's Bill has obviously been carefully drafted with the practicalities of day-to-day industrial relations in mind. It contains no provisions which any fairminded person prepared to abide by the rules of compulsory conciliation and arbitration could object to. On the other hand, it clearly would remove the imbalances which presently exist and which favour recalcitrant unions at the expense of employers who are trying to work within the system.

But no, the Government still wants to walk away from such a proposal. What the coalition has proposed is something that can and will work. We, according to our policy from which we have not deviated one inch-and I wish I could say the same about the Government but, as I said before, the Government has weaved all over the place and tried to throw the accusations back to the Opposition-would introduce a new division into the Industrial Relations Act 1988 that would allow the Commission to issue directives against industrial action to be followed by provision for Federal Court injunctions against breaches of those directives. Failure to comply would be treated as contempt of court with penalties leading not to gaol, as the Labor Party predictably howls, but to heavy fines that are the real sanctions. The third party suffering loss would be able to sue before the Federal Court. This is the practical solution to a pressing national problem. If the Prime Minister had the fortitude to implement it, he would have the support of the great mass of Australians, unionists and non-unionists alike, who believed in the commonsense principle that umpires must have the means to enforce the rules, and that rules are there to be obeyed. It is a great tragedy for Australia that the business community is losing millions of dollars each day through this dispute, that the Western Australian tourist industry loses $580 for each interstate visitor who cancels a trip, and that we have a Labor Government that does not subscribe to the commonsense principles of justice when it comes to industrial disputes.

We have people like Pamela Williams who wrote the most dreadful article in the Australian Financial Review the other day saying that we had deviated from our policies. Senator Chaney's response quite clearly stated that it is central to our policy that the best way to conduct industrial relations in this country is with direct employer-employee negotiations at the enterprise level. It is consistent with our policy-not inconsistent as the Government would have people believe-that we believe it is sensible to have direct discussion on what could be done to improve productivity to form a basis for a proper wage rise for the pilots. Senator Chaney described that as a very constructive option. He also said that if that were not acceptable to the parties then and only then would we need to look to effective arbitration. That is where our proposal to give the Commission some real power and some teeth is really needed. All we are getting at the moment is some cheap provocative verbiage while the constructive alternative proposed by the coalition is continually rejected out of hand. It is rejected despite the support it has received from the business community, which has the deepest concern for practical industrial harmony, because it may diminish the power of powerful militant unions who, unlike the pilots, exercise the levers of power over this Labor Government. Madam Acting Deputy President, it will be interesting today to see where the Labor Party stands on this very important Bill that may see Australia get back to some viability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill I must admit from the outset that my initial reaction when I discovered that the Bill was to be re-introduced was that all we should do was simply vote against the Bill and not treat it with any regard at all. But in looking at the second reading speech and listening to many of the comments, particularly the comments just made by Senator Knowles, I think it is very important to place on the record quite publicly the fact that this Bill will do absolutely nothing with regard to the airline dispute.
