SPEECH.PARA: I will go a little further with that question in a moment but, before I do that, I make one or two comments on some of the things that were said by Senator Knowles. One of her remarks at the outset was that the whole situation was inflamed and she was laying almost all of the blame at the feet of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I think her words were `the macho mouth of the Prime Minister has inflamed the dispute'. That is absolute nonsense. People on the other side continually say, whenever there is an industrial dispute, that the Government should take a hard line and we should not tolerate any sort of industrial disputes at all. Here we have, quite clearly, a situation where a group of people have deliberately set out on a course which will do irreparable damage to the economy of this country and, because the Prime Minister took, quite rightfully, a very hard line on this whole dispute, we are now told from the other side that his macho mouth is the cause of all the problems. It is absolute nonsense.

If we again look at what this Bill would do in terms of the current dispute, the truth is that it would do absolutely nothing. Senator Knowles said that of course it would fix the dispute. That is not true and there is no way that it will fix it. I will be very interested to hear other speakers explain to us how it will. Senator Chaney said in his second reading speech that the current pilots dispute provides a perfect illustration of the powerlessness of the Industrial Relations Commission to enforce its directions. The truth is that there are no employees. All of the pilots have resigned. They are no longer under the jurisdiction of the Commission and there are no awards, so for people to say here that we are putting through a Bill that will impose enormous penalties on people and fix this dispute is patently wrong.

We have to look a little further and ask ourselves, `What is the real reason behind the introduction of this Bill?'. I have heard it suggested in places that Senator Chaney in fact differs a little from some of the hard liners in his Party in that he believes that all workers should be under the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission, while others believe that there should be awards and agreements outside the Commission. I quote from his second reading speech:

We do not seek to dismantle that system though we would expect that as the advantages of voluntary agreements come to be appreciated more and more, people will move in that direction, but it will not be an overnight change.

Of course it is not true that Senator Chaney differs at all from the hard line attitude of people on the other side. We have to ask ourselves what is the objective behind this Bill. I think the objective is simply that people are using a dispute in an emotional way to try to get up a Bill that partially gets their industrial relations policy on the agenda and maybe with a bit of luck-I am sorry, they will not have that sort of luck-they might get some base line established that they can add to in the future.

I must admit that thinking about that tactic reminds me of some advice I got many years ago when I first came into the trade union movement as an organiser. I was advised by an official who had been around for many many years. He said to me-in those days we were operating in the real law of the jungle in industrial relations and that is the sort of policy that the Opposition now wants us to go back to-`when the opportunity arises you take what you can, when you can; you establish that, then you go on and you build on it'. I think that is the very tactic that is being employed here now by Senator Chaney and people on the other side. They are trying to take advantage of a situation to get something in place and then later on build on it. I would have to say to Senator Chaney that maybe his tactics are not too bad. The problem is that the objectives are a little bit cockeyed at the moment and it may be that he ought to get some advice from people on this side of the chamber who have, during their lives, actually worked in industry and operated in the industrial system. It may be that we could change some of the objectives and he might see some sense and change some of the aspects of his industrial relations policy.

If we wonder what this Bill is all about-as I said, it has nothing to do with this dispute-it has the ultimate objective of the Opposition in putting in place punitive legislation that would be used in the future to attack workers in a much weaker position than the airline pilots. It is quite easy for the airline pilots, given their high salaries and the position they are in, for them to get employment somewhere down the track. They can afford to resign. They can afford to dodge around the system. Even if this Bill were in place they could dodge around the system by resigning. But workers on very low rates of pay in a factory would not be in that position. They would not have the luxury of resigning if they found themselves in a very weak position under the Opposition's industrial relations policy. If we had these enterprise unions that it has talked about, there would be thousands of little unions all over this country and people in small groups, in very weak positions, would be trying to compete with employers who had access to all sorts of legal advice and plenty of money behind them to fight them. They would be in receipt of all the necessary market information to be able to cause a dispute whenever it suited them.

Workers in that situation would have no hope under this legislation and continually those unions and those workers would be financially destroyed or they would be pushed back to work under conditions that, clearly, would be to their great disadvantage. That is really what this Bill is all about. It seems to me that what ought to be happening here and what the Opposition ought to be doing is looking at what is going on in Australia, what the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and this Government are attempting to do, in many instances very successfully. I suggest that the Opposition ought to be giving some thought to how we can do something constructive about some of the problems we face. I would not stand up here and say that we are in a situation where it is not necessary for changes to be made. Of course it is necessary. To a very large degree, we have got a very outdated system. Under the accord and with the award restructuring process that is going on, moves are being made to do something about that, but attitudes that have been built up over many years will not be changed overnight. It is the `them and us' mentality. If we are to achieve the productivity that we keep hearing about from the other side of the chamber, we have to get over that `them and us' mentality. That can be achieved over a period of time by people sitting down and constructively talking about changes in the way industry operates. In the metal trades industry award we are going to have some seven or eight classifications instead of some hundreds. As a result of that, people will get the opportunity to enter training programs and to broaden their skills. That is what we can constructively do about increasing the productivity of this country.

However, the Opposition simply wants to continue down the track of saying that all the problems in industry in this country are created by workers and trade unions. I suggest to Opposition members that they ought to talk to some of the more progressive employers in this country. They are coming to realise that as much as it is the fault of workers-and I am not suggesting for one second that the problems we have had are not to a large degree the fault of workers-it is also as much, if not more, the fault of management which has imposed a middle management system that prevented any sort of interaction between top management and the workers. It kept workers in a position where they could not have any real input into the direction an enterprise was going. People were put in a position where they received no real training and where they were locked totally into a system where they could not really constructively contribute.

What is being done by the ACTU and the Government in cooperation is to try, in a constructive and cooperative way, to put in place a system where people can receive broad training, can move from one place to another, can be of real benefit, can feel that they are contributing to the productivity of the establishment they are working for and can have some real interest in the future of that enterprise. To simply go down the track of legislation such as that proposed here or to implement many of the proposals in the Opposition's industrial relations policy would be simply to turn the clock back about 50 years, and we would entrench the `them and us' mentality much more than has been the case in the past. All the work that has gone on until now would be thrown completely out of the window. So I say to the Opposition that what it ought to be doing is giving some credit where it is due for the work that is being done by this Government and by the ACTU to really do something about this system.

I finish on this point in relation to the airline dispute. It is very strange that, while we have these people opposite talking about penalties and all sorts of things, there is no capacity under the current Industrial Relations Act or the wage case decision to settle this dispute. The people who say that obviously have not read the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I also wonder whether the representatives of the pilots have. I think it is important to quote from the clause entitled `Special Cases' in that decision. Under this clause and that decision, there is quite clearly capacity for the pilots to argue their case and to get wage increases within the system and not put the whole economy of this country in jeopardy as would the Opposition's policy. I quote from that document:

Both the ACTU and the Commonwealth contended that increases beyond those generally available for structural efficiency may be approved in special cases, provided that the cases are processed through a special case mechanism and provided there is negligible cost or it can be demonstrated that it should be approved on public interest grounds.
It says further on in that clause:

We recognise that there might be some work places where the objectives of the structural efficiency principle have already been achieved and there is no scope for further efficiency improvements. We would expect such instances to be rare. However, any such instances may be processed as special cases.
In my view, if the airline pilots could not process their case under that provision, then there is something wrong with their leadership and they are not fair dinkum about settling this dispute.

As far as the pilots dispute is concerned, the Opposition has continually said that it is the fault of the Government that no negotiations are going on. I heard Captain McCarthy on AM a few days ago say exactly that, that all they wanted to do was negotiate. That is very good, but when he was asked by the interviewer whether that meant that the pilots were no longer saying they had to get 30 per cent, he said that it did not mean that. The interviewer said, `Well, what does it mean? What is the meaning then of negotiating your terms?'. Captain McCarthy said, `It means sitting down around the table talking'. It is hardly negotiating when one is sitting around the table talking if at the end of the day one is told, `You will give us 30 per cent or you will never get an airliner off the ground'. There is hardly any negotiation in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's new about that?

—I hear an interjection from Senator Parer who says, `What's new?'. It just shows his ignorance of industrial relations. There has never been a case, in which these sorts of claims have been made in which there has been a negotiated settlement, where people simply said, `You will pay or else'. At the end of the day, there is a negotiated settlement, an agreement and compromise on all sides. In this instance at the moment the position is being put where it is 30 per cent or nothing. As far as I am concerned, and as far as the Government is concerned, that is an unacceptable situation, and until such time as the situation changes I guess the present position will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the Opposition is once again bringing on the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill 1989 [No. 2] in precisely the same terms in which it was debated and defeated in this chamber just over a week ago. Frankly, the shadow Minister for industrial relations is somewhat sterile in what he can produce and suggest in relation to this dispute if he has not changed one word-and he has not-of a Bill, the logic of which was debated and torn to shreds in this chamber last week and which has subsequently been torn to shreds in the media and the press. The shadow Minister ignores realities and brings before this chamber a Bill which is irrelevant to the current dispute that is going on out there in the community. The shadow Minister for industrial relations is simply unable to address in any positive way the current air pilots dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: When I spoke to this same Bill exactly one week ago I said that the Australian Democrats agreed that the compliance provisions in the Industrial Relations Act 1988 were inadequate. Quite obviously, they are inadequate. This strike is testimony that the compliance provisions of the current Act are inadequate. I also said that the reason there are no compliance provisions in this Act is as a result of the position taken by the Opposition in relation to the Willis Bill in 1987 and as a result of the tactical strategy of the Government. The Government pulled the Bill off and removed the compliance provisions. It then brought a Bill which did not have compliance provisions before the Parliament, and it was passed. That outcome was fundamentally a product of the attitude of those in the Opposition, and then they walk back here with some magical solution, which is to shove into the Bill a set of compliance provisions which do not even address the question of penalties and which today in fact address an industrial situation that is totally divorced from the provisions of this Bill because all of those pilots in fact have resigned. So it is obvious-and we all know it-that what is being played out here is purely an empty exercise in politics. It is a waste of the time of this chamber, because this Bill can do nothing about the industrial dispute that is before the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you contributing if you think it is a waste of time? Sit down.
—Senator Vanstone, you are on the speakers list, I notice. Would you let Senator McLean finish his speech in silence, please.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Presumably we will get some new shattering insight from Senator Vanstone when she gets the call. It is not an insight that is new in this Bill because those opposite have not changed a word of it since last week, so I do not know what wisdom Senator Vanstone is shouting across the chamber that is new. If there is some new wisdom, why is it not in this Bill? Why did the Opposition not rewrite it? In fact, we said to it last week that we would welcome discussions with the Opposition and the Labor Party with a view to reintroducing industrial relations legislation in some form with a balanced range of compliance and penalty provisions, which were dropped from the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill because of the position that the Opposition took. We made that offer last week and we have not been approached; nor has one word been changed in this Bill since then-despite the escalation of the strike, despite the resignation of the pilots, and despite the fact that this Bill is utterly irrelevant to the present industrial situation. We have already cited the fact that the Bill in its present form-and this is why we do not support it-is simply not tenable. We look for logic. There is no logic in this. We look for relevance. There is no relevance in this Bill.
—What would you do?
—We would certainly not agree to any industrial relations legislation which provides--
—Not what you wouldn't do.
—Senator Walters, I notice you are on the speakers list, too. I ask you to allow Senator McLean to be heard in silence, and I will expect the same when you are speaking.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Certainly this Bill in its present form, the same form in which it was last week, does not exclude the possibility of penal provisions. We would not and will not accept a Bill-just hear this message-that in its present form, in the form in which it is now, still provides the option for penal provisions downline. That is a fact about this Bill. If the Opposition is going to improve it, if it wants it accepted by us, let it change it in that sense at least.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the appropriateness of this Bill. It is obviously designed to make politics in relation to the pilots strike. That is all that it is designed to do. That is why it was raised last sitting week, and that is why the same Bill-unimproved, just as illogical, just as flawed-is before the chamber today. It does not acknowledge the fact that the circumstances of the strike have changed since then. There is no acknowledgment of the fact that things have in fact moved in the last week. Pilots have now resigned. They are therefore outside the system. They are not taking industrial action in the strict sense of the terms as defined in either the Industrial Relations Act or this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order.
—They are not employees and they are not in breach of any award.
—Order! There has been a point of order taken by Senator Vanstone.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Democrats are obviously on the cusp of telling us what they would do in response to this matter--
—There is no point of order.
—Well, I think everybody should be here to listen, so I draw your attention to the state of the House. (Quorum formed).

—I am pleased that Senator Vanstone in fact has called some honourable senators to the chamber to hear the points that I am about to make. I notice that most of them in fact are Government senators, who I think are quite happy to hear the argument that is being advanced. Very few of them are Opposition senators, who must frankly be absolutely embarrassed by the fact that their shadow Minister for industrial relations has been unable to amend a single word of a Bill that was defeated in this House last week and is flippant, superficial and wasteful enough of our time to bring it forward after probably one of the most serious industrial disputes in recent decades has advanced by one week. His sterility is such that he has to bring forward a Bill in precisely the same terms as it was defeated in this chamber last week.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that this is going to be embarrassing to some members of the Opposition, but only two days ago the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee)-I know that they are embarrassed by some of the things that the honourable member for Goldstein says-addressed the Victorian Employers Federation at the Industrial Relations Conference in Melbourne and made a few salient points about the Opposition's industrial relations policy in relation to the present pilots dispute. He said in relation to the pilots dispute:

It is hard to see room for collective bargaining in Australia. The pilots' dispute shows the consequences of the right to strike and the right to lock out which inevitably go with a collective bargaining system.
This is a former Opposition industrial relations spokesperson. Mr Macphee also defended the Industrial Relations Commission, when he said:

I believe very strongly that the Commission has given employers their best chance for years to rearrange the package of minimum award measures in conjunction with their employees, and to determine any over-award arrangements on productivity considerations, rather than union muscle or regional market rates.

Once again, it was the honourable member for Goldstein, the former industrial relations spokesperson for the Opposition, who said that. The pilots have been engaging in free collective bargaining. They are doing what the Opposition theoretically wants every employee to do, that is, to reach agreement with his employer outside the guidelines of the centralised industrial relations system.

We are watching in operation the Opposition's alternative industrial relations model. The whole country is watching it play itself out, yet the Opposition brings it back time and time again to be embarrassed by the industrial scene playing out the alternative formula. I am surprised that the Opposition has not gone back to the drawing board and not only amended the Bill before us but also done some serious thinking about its industrial relations model.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is under Labor not us!
—Order! Senator Walters, I indicated earlier that you are on the speakers list. Please let Senator McLean make his speech in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It can be reasonably argued that the pilots dispute brings into focus the effects of the system that Opposition senators advocate should be in place. As I said before, we are experiencing industrial relations chaos of the type that the Opposition industrial relations model would inflict on Australia. We are facing massive inconveniences which the Opposition's model would continue to inflict on Australia. We are facing an industrial decline in one of our key industries.
—I don't know how you sleep at night.
—I sleep very well at night. All of this is likely to get worse rather than better if we have in place an industrial relations model of the type that the Opposition is advocating.

SPEECH.PARA: The irony of the introduction of this Bill by the Opposition at this time is that the compliance provisions that were in the 1987 version of the Industrial Relations Bill would have been in place and could have been used had the Opposition not adopted at that time a purely political stance in relation to the legislation that was before the House. The 1987 Bill spelt out what penalties would apply for non-compliance with the directives of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As has been said before, the Bill before us today leaves the magnitude of such penalties open ended, only one of the inadequacies in this Bill which the Democrats cannot accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —We wish you would tell us what you would do.
—We pointed it out to the Opposition last week. We said we would sit at the table with Opposition senators.
—How would you solve the problem?

—For starters, we would address the fact that penalties are not provided or described in the Bill. We pointed that out to the Opposition last week. We invited Opposition senators to sit at the table and come to grips with that, but they have not done so. Even the Australian Council of Trade Unions was reluctantly prepared to support the compliance provisions in the 1987 Bill in return for legislation to bring sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act into the Industrial Relations Act. The Democrats indicated to the government of the day that we were willing to support such provisions, but the New Right at that stage-purely and simply making political mileage of it then as now-carried on, threatened to spend $9m to blow the Bill out of the water, induced the Government to pull the Bill off, and induced the Government to bring on a Bill which is inadequate in terms of compliance provisions and penalties and which does not address the vexed question of sections 45d and 45e and secondary boycotts.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it was the action of the Opposition which left us with flawed industrial relations legislation, thus giving the pilots the opportunity to bring us into this situation. Nonetheless, Senator Knowles had the gall to stand up and in a totally illogical, uninformed manner point across the chamber, in a typical gesture, saying that all the blame lay with the Government when the blame for the non-compliance provisions of the present Act lies on her side of the chamber. Last week, we simply pointed that out to the Opposition and told it to go away and do its homework and then bring back compliance provisions that make sense and are responsible. We would then consider them. The Opposition has asked what we would do. We would sit and rationally discuss with it and with the Government how to rectify the inadequacies of the present industrial relations legislation.

There are a number of quite specific problems with this Bill. (Quorum formed) Senator Knowles and Opposition senators collectively were presumably quite embarrassed and offended by the article Pamela Williams wrote in the Australian Financial Review on 28 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —An apologist for the ACTU.

—You can shout that out; it is just an empty sort of statement. I am prepared to take that article on its merits. I am prepared to be convinced by its logic. I am prepared to quote back to you some of the very valid points that were made in that article. You can attempt to push logic aside with empty words, as you constantly do, but Ms Williams made five telling points. Let me make the same points.
—Why don't you tell us how you would fix this dispute?

—Order! I ask Senator McLean to direct his remarks through the Chair. I have already indicated to Senator Vanstone that she is on the speakers list and will have the opportunity later this afternoon to make her speech.

—The telling points are simply these: five stages of the alternative industrial relations model of the Opposition have played themselves out in relation to this strike. It is a classic play-out of the alternative model. First, a secret ballot was held. There was a consensus among pilots that they would walk this course. It was arrived at by secret ballot. We do not identify with the course they have walked, but at least there was a secret ballot, at least that is democracy and we live with the consequences of it. Secondly, the Opposition's policy is that people should be able to opt out of the industrial relations system, as the pilots have done. They have opted out; they have opted out collectively and the system has pushed them to the point where they have opted out not only collectively but also individually. The system has failed; we agree that the system has failed. But it is the system the Opposition is advocating that has failed.
—Rubbish; nonsense!
—I am sorry this is embarrassing to the honourable senators but this is in fact the logic and the realities of it.
—I raise a point of order. Senator McLean is grossly misrepresenting the Opposition's policies--
—There is no point of order.
—There is a point of order.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The third observation that Pamela Williams made was that the Opposition's policy seeks direct negotiations between employers and employees. Now that is what we have had; that is what has collapsed; that is what has led to the subsequent outcomes. I am afraid that Senator Vanstone cannot deny that.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth point she makes is that the Opposition's policy urges the use of common law, and we are not opposed to that. It is the process which is currently under way in relation to the pilots dispute and is not resolving it. The fifth observation she makes is that the Opposition's policy talks about wage gains being achieved for productivity. That really, to my way of thinking, is only marginally relevant to this situation. I believe that the observations that were made in that article are perfectly valid. They are in fact weaknesses of the alternative model. They do legitimately cite weaknesses of the present model. We are in our present difficult position because we do not have an adequate Industrial Relations Act in place. We do need to improve it, and we have offered to sit at the table and work towards that improvement. We have cited the fact that the present inadequacies reflect a political game between the Opposition and the government of the day which occurred in relation to the Willis Bill of 1987 and left us with a flawed, inadequate Industrial Relations Act. We acknowledge those limitations and we would be more than willing to cooperate in the remedying of them.

In conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President, I summarise the Democrats' position. It has not changed in the four discussions we have had on this issue. We have debated it four times in the last six days of sitting and we have not changed our position. We see the Opposition as simply making politics at this stage. When the Opposition stops doing that and starts seriously talking about making legislation, that is when we will cooperate.

The second point I will make about the Opposition's proposal today is that we are simply citing the fact that the pilots' union is a powerful union. They will get what they want because in the model that they are playing out, which is essentially the Opposition's model, they have clout and they will win. Big will win, small will lose. The rich will get richer, the poor will get poorer under the alternative model that the Opposition is proposing and the one which is playing itself out.

The use of international flights and Air Force planes has been totally inadequate, as we are painfully aware, and we agree that nothing to resolve this dispute has been done. It is certainly not going to be resolved by the passage of a flawed, inadequate, politicking Bill such as the one that is before the chamber today. This has been one of the most destructive industrial disputes that we have seen in Australia in many years. Its long term effect, of course, will be very widespread and we all acknowledge that. The Government is not able to resolve the situation and nor will the proposition that is being proposed by the Opposition here today.

Probably one of the most significant things to be revealed in the four debates we have had, certainly to my mind and to the minds of the Australian Democrat members, is the inadequacies of the alternative model. They have been revealed to the same extent or more so than the inadequacies of the present Industrial Relations Act, inadequacies which we say essentially result from the political strategies of the Opposition two years ago. It is important that the Australian public realises what we are seeing. The Pamela Williams article, the Michelle Grattan article, and this debate-four times over-have revealed to us that even though we have a flawed Industrial Relations Act in place, certainly we do not have an Opposition that is able to propose an industrial relations model that is significantly better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this chamber and in the community we are used to hearing cloud-cuckoo-land promises from the Australian Dem- ocrats because they well know they will never be in government and have the responsibility of delivering their promises. We have just listened to Senator McLean for half an hour and we have not even heard any promises as to what the Australian Democrats would do with regard to the current industrial relations dispute relating to the pilots. All we have heard is a lot of negative criticism of this Bill-unjustified criticism as I will point out in a few moments-and the very positive proposals which are contained in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to what Senator McLean has just told us and what Senator Devereux said earlier in this debate, the introduction of the provisions of this Bill, the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill 1989 [No. 2], for the fourth time in less than two years and for the second time in a fortnight, clearly demonstrates the good will of the Opposition in providing yet another opportunity for this failed Government to get off the hook with regard to the current airline pilots dispute.

I reinforce the strong support which I have given to this Bill on those previous occasions. Let us hope that in the light of the industrial relations disaster currently being acted out in this country for once Labor and Democrat senators might at least acknowledge that it is time to incorporate the provision of sanctions in our industrial relations system.

The Liberal and National parties are seeking to refocus the nation's attention on the long overdue requirement for compliance provisions in our compulsory conciliation and arbitration system. We are arguing strongly for sanction provisions to go into the Act so that in a last resort situation there will be some enforcement provision for wilful breaches of an undertaking or commitment, or to uphold the arbitrator's decision. We have the Industrial Relations Commission currently twiddling its thumbs. It is utterly powerless, while the situation which is knocking this country for six flies in its face. The only sanction which was available to the Industrial Relations Commission was to cancel the pilots' award. Some powerful Commission! The absence of any effective means by which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission can enforce its orders and awards is a fundamental flaw in our industrial relations system and it is a graphic illustration that less than six months after the passage of a new Industrial Relations Act, the inadequacies of the current arrangements have been ably demonstrated by the crippling airline pilots dispute.

The Opposition has made clear its willingness to support the Government in its bid to conclude this damaging domestic airline pilots dispute. The Opposition does not support the pilots' claim and we have strongly condemned their industrial action campaign. It is no secret that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), despite his harsh rhetoric in attempting to cope with this situation, is yet again treading on egg shells when it comes to taking decisive action to resolve what is proving to be one of the nation's most destructive and debilitating conflicts. All the Prime Minister's henchmen, all the Prime Minister's malignant language, all his cavalcading around the media studios of Australia with his silken-clad assistant, cannot disguise the abysmal failure of the Government's accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It cannot disguise that the accord is producing a repeat year of stagnant productivity and declining real wages. Nor can it protect an inflexible wages system from close scrutiny.

Two years ago the then industrial relations Minister, Ralph Willis, promised to introduce compliance procedures that would provide molars for the Arbitration Commission but that Cabinet confidante, Simon Crean, brusquely put a stop to that. Two years later Australia is still waiting for those teeth, having experienced several severe industrial disputes during the intervening time, of which the pilots dispute is but the most recent. Each of these disputes has demonstrated the desperate need for specific and effective compliance provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who writes this stuff for you, Grant? You must be embarrassed.

—I am quite capable of putting this material together myself. I am glad that Senator Aulich is listening very intently to what I have to say. I hope he will take notice of it and support the legislation. Australia is still labouring under a stop-start government which back-pedals and fights with meaningless words, not action. We still struggle under an inflexible wage fixing system which focuses on individuals straining on the leash while productivity goes out the window.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard earlier from Senator Devereux that one of the problems with our industrial relations system is the `them and us' mentality. I agree with Senator Devereux with regard to that. But the way to overcome the `them and us' mentality is to get industrial relations back to the workplace and to the enterprise level, with direct negotiations between employers and employees, and to get the practice of industrial relations out of the hands of the industrial relations club, out of the hands--

TALK.START.PARA: —Into the hands of lawyers.

—Indeed, out of the hands of lawyers, out of the hands of union bureaucrats and out of the hands of Industrial Relations Commission bureaucrats. This, combined with the opportunities for employee-share ownership and profit sharing-which our policy will encourage-will demonstrate both to employers and to employees their common interests and goals. Coalition policy seeks legally binding voluntary agreements. If the parties cannot agree, then effective arbitration is the key. The Opposition has a clear plan to answer the kind of industrial muscle currently being exercised by the pilots and that is encompassed in this Bill currently under debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an absurd proposition to claim, as Senator Aulich and his Government colleagues have done and as Senator McLean did a few moments ago, that the current pilots dispute is an example of the Opposition's industrial relations policy in action. This dispute is happening under a Labor government, under the accord and under the rest of the present Labor Government's industrial relations policies. It is the Labor Government's policies that are making the dispute so difficult to resolve. As I said earlier, the Opposition does not support the pilots' claims. We have condemned their campaign of industrial action. We believe, however, that the pilots, like all Australian workers, should have the right to negotiate with their employers. But they do not have the right to hold both their employers and the nation to ransom.

Our proposal is for legally binding voluntary agreements. There is nothing voluntary about the current situation. That gives the lie to Senator McLean's gross misrepresentation of the Liberal-National Party Opposition's policy with regard to industrial relations. In the current dispute, only one side has opted out of the system and no voluntary agreement has been reached. That is where Senator McLean grossly misrepresented our policy, because our policy provides for voluntary agreements between both parties and for both parties to opt out on the basis of that voluntary agreement-not for one side to opt out unilaterally. Senator McLean went on to claim that industrial relations issues would simply be settled by the clout of the particular union involved. That is not the case because unless voluntary agreement is reached-voluntary agreement to which the employer and employee both are party-then the matter should go to effective arbitration.
In this case, if the employers and pilots cannot agree, the matter should go to effective arbitration. That is where industrial relations clout and union muscle would not be relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens when the pilots resign? What do you do then?

—I will come to that in a moment. That is the clear difference between the reality of our policy and the gross misrepresentation of it we heard a few moments ago from Senator McLean. In contrast, under this Government's legislation there is no way of bringing the industrial action to an end. The only course is a war of attrition, with the dispute dragging on endlessly for weeks and weeks. The Opposition has a clear answer to the sort of industrial blackmail being pursued by the pilots; that is, the Bill which we are currently debating. Regardless of other remedies which should continue to be available to employers, the Commission must have at its disposal a means of dealing with the refusal to accept the processes of conciliation and arbitration established in the community interest. If the Commission is not so empowered, then conciliation and arbitration become meaningless as a system for the resolution of conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: The current domestic airline dispute will not be resolved by Australian Labor Party rhetoric, nor will any other industrial disputes. The Federal Government's shameful record with other unions will attest to that. Look at the ongoing sickness on our waterfronts. It will continue because the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia is just waiting in the wings for its massive golden handshake for doing nothing but destroying our export competitiveness and thereby our economy and holding this country to ransom.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right.

—I thank Senator Vanstone for her encouragement. The Prime Minister is on record as claiming that pilots are exceptionally greedy and that if they gained their pay claims it would wreck the whole wage fixing system, which he falsely claims has produced for the great bulk of Australians a much better say. The Prime Minister is right about one thing. Under the present Government's approach the whole wage fixing system will be wrecked because the Government refuses to admit the shortcomings of centralised wage fixing. If the pilots succeed everyone will jump on the band wagon and will want a flow-on.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what traditionally happens in this country under the present system: workers get an increase whether they have contributed to lifting the country's productivity or not. What kind of wage fixing system do we have when Uncle Tom Cobleigh and all get a pay hike based on union muscle with unions holding the nation by the throat and costing it billions of dollars in lost national income rather than contributing to increasing the productivity and profitability of employers and thereby the national wealth and international competitiveness of Australia?

The Government has been caught out. It will not go for the jugular and throw the Trade Practices Act at the pilots. It is to the eternal credit of the previous Fraser coalition Government that it provided this avenue. Jay Pendarvis took the initiative in applying sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act and winning in the Mudginberri case. The Dollar Sweets case in Victoria was another victory in the use of common law torts. That is another case where a union was totally and utterly out of line in its behaviour. The Government cannot make any headway because it has tied its hands behind its own back and it is fighting with no armour in the absence of effective compliance legislation.

The Hawke Government could have invoked an array of strategies available under the Crimes Act to end this dispute. Instead we are subjected to venomous and cheap talk from the Prime Minister about how anyone can fly a plane and how bus drivers and airline pilots are nearly one and the same. This is how, in his fading years, the Prime Minister deals with an industrial relations conflict of the highest order. No wonder the waterfront unions are having the time of their lives. The only certainties are that this Hawke Government is big on talk, big on inaction and really big on its inability to give the Industrial Relations Commission effective sanctions.

The Hawke Government is directly responsible for the current failure in Australian industrial relations becoming one of the most serious in our history. The claims by the Prime Minister and by Senator Devereux-and Senator McLean, speaking for the Democrats in this debate-that this Bill that we are putting up is useless because the pilots have gone outside the system is utter nonsense. Because the Commission has cancelled the pilots' award it does not take the dispute out of the Commission's jurisdiction. Commissioner Paine pointed out only yesterday that the dispute could still be dealt with by the Commission `in accordance with the process afforded by the Act'. There is still an industrial dispute between the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and the airlines. Therefore the Commission still has jurisdiction.

If this Bill is passed the Commission could reinstitute the pilots' award. If the Federation continued to tell its members not to work, it would be in breach of section 187a (3) (c) of the Act as amended by our Bill; that is:
it would be engaging in conduct that hinders, prevents or discourages: . . . (c) the acceptance of, or offering for, work in accordance with an award.

The Commission could then make a direction aimed at the Federation. But, of course, the real point of the debate as to whether there is or is not jurisdiction in relation to our legislation is that if this legislation had already been in place before the dispute got under way this protracted dispute could have been avoided.

This strike in particular is a phoney war of inaction and ongoing dispute, despite the Prime Minister's support for airline management. The winners will be the ones who can hold their breath the longest. No matter what judgments are eventually obtained, I will bet that to ensure the planes fly again no punishments will be handed out at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do?
—What we would do, Senator Aulich, is introduce--
—Senator Chapman, would you please direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, in response to Senator Aulich, what we would do is ensure the passage of this legislation which would give the Industrial Relations Commission some effective teeth in dealing with the pilots. The fact that there is no effective compliance legislation, the fact that, as I said, no punishments will be handed out at the end of this dispute, is what is wrong with the industrial relations framework in this country.
—Give them six of the best.
—Order, Senator Aulich, you are on the speakers list. I suggest that you allow Senator Chapman to be heard in silence.

—Given the complete absence of effective compliance provisions, there is absolutely nothing else the Government can do except to grin and bear it. It is not only this Government which is grinning and taking it on the chin. Individuals in our community are being stood down, the tourism and hospitality industries are losing millions in income and productivity is on a speeding bullet down the drain once again. People across this country are being inconvenienced and international tourists may never come back, if in fact they have arrived here at all in the last couple of weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Together Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines turn over in excess of $2 billion annually. Their profits would be about $200m. When pilots worked office-type hours a couple of weeks ago, both airlines lost about $2m a day. It would cost both airlines about $100,000 a day to give in to the pilots' 30 per cent wage increase demand. So the airlines have a big incentive to settle, despite the size of this claim. The cost of keeping aircraft on the ground for both airlines in the event of almost total shutdowns is around $600,000 a day. On the one hand, the Government cannot allow such a settlement because of its ill-considered ideological commitment to centralised wage fixing and the consequences of a flow-on, but on the other hand, in the absence of effective sanctions legislation, the Government is powerless to end the pilots' action.

This Bill offers a real alternative because its compliance provisions would ensure that the Industrial Relations Commission could stop industrial action. Under the new division to be inserted into the Industrial Relations Act 1988 the Commission would be empowered to issue directions to prevent such actions and have substantial penalties imposed for the breach of such directions, while the right for common law and section 45 actions would be retained.

To summarise the provisions of our Bill, first, they empower the Industrial Relations Commission to give directions to stop industrial action; secondly, they empower the Federal Court of Australia to grant an injunction where such direction is breached; thirdly, they allow people to sue for damages caused by such breaches; and fourthly, they retain access to common law and other external legal actions for those detrimentally affected by breaches.

TALK.START.PARA: —And, fifth, it gives everything to lawyers to run.

—I am surprised, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Aulich has been so vocal during my remarks today because poor Senator Aulich has had to eat his own words that the use of common law torts was the worst possible way to deal with such situations. Since Senator Aulich made that statement a couple of weeks ago, the Government and the Prime Minister have backed the use of common law sanctions against the pilots. Ideally, sanctions ought to be in the industrial legislation itself because this provides a speedier way of dealing with disputes than the use of the common law. And, of course, speed is of the essence.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order.
—He cannot take it.
—Order!
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to be misrepresented and I will be seeking the opportunity to redress the inaccuracies later.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I can see that Senator Aulich regrets having made those comments a couple of weeks ago. As I was saying before that interruption, speed is of the essence in settling industrial disputes. Businesses can be ruined by any delay in the settlement of such disputes. It is important to have sanctions provisions in industrial relations legislation because a speedier resolution of a dispute can be reached than would be the case under common law. So such sanctions will be a useful alternative to the use of common law even if they are rarely required to be used. These sanctions will provide the molars for the Commission which will give it the authority it has always lacked.

SPEECH.PARA: Our Bill has been carefully put together with the practicalities of daily industrial relations problems in mind. It contains no provisions to which any fair-minded person prepared to abide by the rules of compulsory conciliation and arbitration could object. It also removes the imbalances which presently exist and which favour recalcitrant trade unions at the expense of employer groups which are attempting to work from within the system. The practical nature of our proposal has previously been recognised by the expert day to day practitioners in the field of industrial relations. This has been further reinforced this week by the Confederation of Australian Industry which said:
If the Commission had the powers proposed in Senator Chaney's Bill, the deplorable consequences of the action by airline pilots could have been avoided.

So much for Senator McLean's remarks that this Bill is impractical. The expert practitioners of industrial relations have on a number of occasions said that this Bill goes to the heart of the problem of industrial relations and the requirement for sanctions. As I said, the Confederation of Australian Industry is yet another body expert in industrial relations which has reinforced that view this week.

The Government has gained no ground with its confrontationist approach, however concerned it may have been about the consequences of the pilots gaining a favourable settlement of their claim. These feared consequences need to be addressed because they go to the heart of the weaknesses of the centralised wage fixing system. From the outset, Prime Minister Hawke took the lead in a confrontationist and high profile way in a dispute in which the Government was not directly involved. The Government supported the cancellation of the pilots' award by the Industrial Relations Commission. It supported the use of common law actions against the pilots and the use of military and foreign planes to provide replacement services. It has threatened to call in foreign pilots to fill vacancies created if Australian domestic pilots go overseas to work.

So we have 1,400 pilots controlling the economic stability of Australia's remaining seven million-plus wage and salary earners. But if it were not the pilots, it would be the wharfies or the metal trade unionists or the transport workers. Under our antiquated industrial relations system, any group can hold a gun at our heads and virtually get away scot-free with their scoop of prizes. One thing is for sure, the pilots dispute seems likely to hasten the transformation of our industrial relations system to one that permits greater flexibility. If there were no semi-automatic flow-ons to the entire work force from settlement of the pilots claim, it would seem likely that the dispute would be rapidly settled. So this legislation requires urgent passage to ensure that the dispute can be settled. Irrespective of that, it will remain for the next coalition government to undertake the complete overhaul of our industrial relations system which is so urgently needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reintroduction of this legislation into the Parliament in the way that it has been done is a political stunt, pure and simple. It is an absolute political stunt which has been nailed down this afternoon during debate-and I am pleased that it has been. Senator Chapman has said it, Senator Vanstone has said it by continual interjection, and Senator Knowles has said it-they have said that this Bill would fix the current airline pilots dispute. They fail to say how. There is a difficulty with an industrial dispute. By definition, an industrial dispute is a dispute between employers and employees. What do you do, Senator Chapman, when there are no longer any employees?
—I told you; you did not listen.
—What you said was nonsense, Senator, as I will now demonstrate. Who are you going to issue the directions to?
—The union.
—Oh, yes? What would it do?
—Order! Senator Collins, would you please direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Yes, Madam Acting Deputy President. The people no longer work for the airlines, so how will Senator Chapman direct them? There is a fundamental problem with the approach put forward by Senator Chapman which he seems to have ignored. We live in a democratic society. The reason industrial disputes are possible at all is that we live in a democracy. If we did not, they would not be possible. It always has been, it is, and it always will be a balancing act to try to preserve those fundamental tenets of democracy which allow industrial action and, at the same time, maintain a reasonable stability in the economy. The trouble with the simple minded approach of the Opposition-and it truly is simple minded-this nirvana it is painting by its proposal for collective bargaining is the fundamental problem with trying to put this theory of collective bargaining together with sanctions.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I have a point of order. This is misrepresentation. Our policy is not collective bargaining, it is voluntary agreements.
—There is no point of order.
—You cannot make explanations in the middle of a speech, and you know it.
—Senator Collins, please do not keep talking to Senator Chapman.

—There is a fundamental conflict between a theory of collective bargaining and sanctions. They do not work. The Opposition could take its theory to a place where everything is perfect-I do not know where such a place exists. Perhaps it is the place where the phantom takes Diana for a long weekend-the Isle of Eden-where all the animals run around and lie down with each other. Under the Opposition's theory everyone can get on and talk about productivity but, although it is truly said in this world, that the lion can lie down with the lamb, only one of them gets up. That is the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill does not even apply now in terms of issuing directions in this dispute because the airlines no longer have any employees-they have resigned. I quote Senator Austin-`five-per-cent' Lewis when he introduced this legislation and said:
The chief advantage of this approach is that it would provide a quick and effective remedy to unacceptable industrial action.

How? Under the legislation which the Opposition wants to introduce, in terms of amending the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, a dispute will still have to go to the Federal Court. We have this thing called the separation of powers in our Constitution which means that such disputes will still have to go to the Federal Court and Senator Chaney, at least, is accurate enough to say that. How can one provide a quick and speedy resolution if the matter still has to be argued in front of the Federal Court in exactly the same way as one has to argue the sanctions of the Trade Practices Act in front of the Federal Court? There is no quick and speedy resolution.

Senator Chapman talked about the lack of sanctions to bring against unions. `No teeth' he said. I went through this yesterday. I ask Senator Chapman to listen to the sanctions that are currently available. He obviously did not listen yesterday, so I will go through them again. These are the sanctions that are currently available in this country against unions: sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, which deal with secondary and primary boycotts; common law industrial torts that permit actions for damages; sections 30j and 30k of the Crimes Act 1914; the bans clause procedures under section 125 and sections 181 to 186 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988; cancellation or suspension of awards under section 187 and deregistration under section 294 of that Act. Under a new provision in the 1988 Act the Commission may also refuse to deal with a matter raised by an organisation in breach of an award or direction of the Commission, and there is the discretionary power of the Commission to withhold national wage case increases from parties. It is a pretty hefty range of sanctions. As I pointed out previously, it is a greater range of sanctions against trade unions in this country than anything that Margaret Thatcher has brought in during her 10 years of administration. Margaret Thatcher has brought in legislation which provides that where unions take industrial action by means of a secret ballot, a limited immunity from common law action is provided and, further, a statutory limitation is put on damages that can be paid. There are no limitations of that kind in this country. We have a pretty hefty range of sanctions.

All this has to be argued in front of the Federal Court, and that takes time. I am very familiar with the Mudginberri dispute. It took two years of court actions to resolve that and millions of dollars in legal costs. The sanctions which the Opposition wants to bring in through the amendments it introduced this afternoon will still have to be argued in front of the Federal Court, and I do not know anything that will be fixed quickly in front of the Federal Court. If the interests of both parties are to be fully protected by the systems we have in our courts, it is very hard to imagine how it could possibly be any other way.

There has been some mention here this afternoon of how some remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have allegedly exacerbated this debate. There are two remarks I would like to make about that. Firstly, I would like to quote the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) in an interview-I might add, I totally agree with him-that he gave on 18 August this year with reference to a criticism about this legislation exacerbating the debate. The words of Senator Chaney can also be applied to the statements made by the Prime Minister. Senator Chaney said:

How in the world could you exacerbate this dispute; Pvu? I mean, the thing has got to the point where the pilots are imposing the most massive penalties on the community and on their employers, and it's hard to see that they could do any worse.

I say amen to that. I will tell the Opposition what will exacerbate this dispute. What will exacerbate this dispute is the totally irresponsible and disgraceful actions of the Opposition's conservative colleagues in the Northern Territory Parliament who, at a quarter past four this afternoon, gave themselves a 30 per cent pay hike. That is unbelievable. I say that with some degree of anger. We, in the Northern Territory, are probably affected by this pilots dispute to a greater extent than most of Australia. We have no alternative means of travel available to us up there. Frankly, I am almost in a state of total disbelief that the idiots who run the Northern Territory Government-I have known for many years they are idiots-could be so idiotic that in the middle of this dispute, while complaining at the dreadful damage this dispute is doing to our tourist industry-and the damage is becoming more serious by the day, I might add-they could debate a pay rise for an entire day in the Northern Territory Parliament and, at 4.15 this afternoon, vote themselves a 15.4 per cent immediate increase in their salaries with a further 15 per cent flowing on 1 January next year. It is beyond me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't they subject to a tribunal?

—They are not subject to anything in the Northern Territory. It is beyond belief that they have done this. The Opposition talks about exacerbating the dispute. Opposition senators might have a word with Northern Territory parliamentarians to see whether they can make them change their minds. I literally cannot believe what they have done. We are talking about a group of politicians-I was a member of the Assembly for 10 years-that has a Parliament that sits for 21 days out of 365. It has virtually no committee system, in the sense of having committees which work during the recess. To give one example, the town of Alice Springs, a town of 22,000 people, is represented by four State-if the Northern Territory can be called a State and, for all intents and purposes, it can-members of Parliament with average electorates of 2,500 people. That is fewer than most people on city councils in this country have got. Those politicians sit 21 days a year in Parliament and, in the face of what is potentially the most crippling and damaging industrial dispute-certainly for the Northern Territory, but also for Australia-they have voted themselves a 30 per cent pay hike. It is beyond belief. In terms of exacerbating the dispute perhaps honourable senators opposite could have a yarn to their colleagues in the Northern Territory and tell them to think again. To return to this legislation-
—That is a good idea.

—I do not know that it is, Madam Acting Deputy President, because this is such a lousy Bill. Getting back to this lousy Bill, Senator Chaney has argued that we have to have this legislation because it will result in the Commission being able to issue directions, and it will fix everything. Let us have a look at that proposition. Had the directions procedures set out in this Bill been enacted and then acted upon prior to the pilots dispute-prior to their resigning en masse on Thursday, 24 August-they may have led to the Federal Court issuing injunctions within, at best, a day or two of the Commission's direction having been ignored. If the injunctions were then ignored, action could be commenced for contempt and-I say this on the basis of the experience I had with the Mudginberri dispute-the hearing would take some months. This Parliament has not and should not have any direct control over how the Federal Court conducts its business. Litigation at this level, where this amount of money is involved, tends to become very lengthy, as it did with Mudginberri, and as it would with this dispute under the coalition's legislation, under this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Actions for damages could also be brought against the pilots, as Senator Chapman has said quite correctly. Again, this procedure would be lengthy. But these procedures are always lengthy. This sounds reasonably impressive, but in reality it is not. In this dispute the same remedies were available to the airlines under the procedures set out in the Trade Practices Act, section 45d, and under common law. Prior to the pilots handing in their resignations, the employers could also have opted to use the bans clause procedures which have been streamlined under the new Act. This may have been a useful tactic if the airlines had wished to avoid inflaming the dispute or if they had wanted to avoid creating some sympathy for the pilots that could flow from the imposition of the draconian penalties under the Trade Practices Act.

The existence of the directions procedures proposed by the Opposition, which are to solve everything, would probably only have prompted the pilots to bring forward their resignations to escape the extended operations of the Act under section 5. This may have had the somewhat perverse effect of further limiting the liability of the pilots to actions for civil damages by reducing the length of the period that they appear to have been in breach of their contracts of employment.

There are a lot of big holes in Senator Chaney's proposal. Given the apparent-and I am being kind-militancy of the union, it is doubtful whether any package of sanctions consistent with the existence of a free society would have produced a different outcome. In the circumstances, the most that can be said is that it may have persuaded the Pilots Federation to follow different industrial tactics. Not, I might add-having had a look at its history of industrial negotiations; and I canvassed it the day before yesterday-that it has ever done that. It might also be noted that the imposition of fines and penalties at any stage, but especially early on, may further complicate the matter and delay return to work and a final resolution of the actual dispute.

Having dealt with the pilots dispute, it is reasonable to consider whether this legislation would assist the resolution of disputes in other areas because, although everyone is concentrating on the pilots dispute, this legislation does not apply simply to that. It is extremely doubtful whether the Opposition's amendments to this Act would help in any other situations where employees have taken themselves outside the formal system of conciliation and arbitration. That is the big agenda that is being fought now and, if honourable senators doubt that, I recommend that they look at the history of industrial negotiations by this union since 1959. The big agenda is not just the 30 per cent pay hike, although, as I said the other day, the two constants in how this Federation operates are behaving like bloody-minded thugs and always going for double figures. That is its history.

The big argument is taking itself outside the system, not just our system but the Opposition's system as well. That point seems to have been lost on all Opposition members. That is the big agenda that the Pilots Federation is fighting at the moment, and has always fought. Other industries, with the exception of those mentioned in section 5, do not attract the extended jurisdiction of the Act, although it does cover waterfront employees and Commonwealth public servants. Where employees resign, unions cease to be registered or have their awards cancelled and they escape all of the procedures contemplated by this legislation. Nonetheless, they remain liable under the relevant provisions of the Trade Practices Act and the common law. At this point I think I could probably rest my case, but I will not.

It was also noted by my learned and erudite friend Senator Cooney that the Bill does not confine the orders that the Court may make to fines. It would be possible for the Federal Court to imprison those whom it found to be in contempt of its rulings. The honourable senator also drew attention to the fact that clause 187e of the Bill reverses the onus of proof with respect to persons and organisations who may have acted in breach of the proposed directions procedures. That is important to note. Neither of those deficiencies in the Opposition's Bill, I can assure honourable senators, commends itself to me.
The other matter that has to be looked at in respect of this legislation is the Opposition's approach to secret ballots. The industrial relations policy of the coalition, such as it is, states:
A Liberal National Party Government will strengthen the provisions in the Act relating to secret ballots to make ballots compulsory before industrial action.

It should be noted by the Senate that the coalition does not propose to mirror the Thatcher Government's Trade Union Act of 1984, which I have just mentioned, and which continued some immunity from actions for damages where a secret ballot had been held. In the present dispute the pilots have taken part in at least one secret ballot. This does not appear to have headed off the dispute. Indeed, in some respects it has given a degree of legitimacy to the pilots' action and has made it more difficult for anyone to say that the pilots are simply being led on-this is always the cry from the Opposition-by irresponsible union leadership. This Government believes that such ballots are desirable only when they may assist in the resolution of disputes and not where they can be used to harden the attitude of the parties. Hence, under sections 135 and 136 of the current unamended Act, the Commission has discretion to order such a ballot, and a ballot can be ordered even when requested by a relatively small percentage of the workers involved in the dispute.

The Opposition's stated policy encourages the creation of voluntary agreements-we have heard so much about this this afternoon-between employers and employees at the enterprise level, with wage increases to be based on productivity improvements and trade-offs. At the same time, the policy states that the Opposition will enhance the current array of sanctions available under the Act and maintain other statutory sanctions and common law rights of actions, such as all the ones I have just mentioned-and they are horrific. What the policy does not state-and I look forward to hearing it stated by the speakers who are to contribute to the debate later-is how a coalition government would, firstly, manage the transition from the present system to a more market-driven approach, which is what it says it is and, secondly, measure productivity, both at the economy-wide level and at the level of the individual enterprise. I might ask: which measure of productivity would a coalition government use-a total factor productivity or labour productivity?

A very salient point was made in this respect by Senator Macklin in debate the other day: how does one measure productivity, in terms of laying down rules for commissions or courts to apply productivity in a whole range of occupations? That is a big question. How would one then judge whether productivity agreements were genuine, and how would one determine which parts of the work force were entitled to opt out of it and which parts had to be kept within it by sanctions to avoid a wages break-out? There are a lot of big questions there, that no-one in the Opposition has so far addressed.

As I have said before, the basis of a free collective bargaining system is that sanctions are virtually non-existent. The only sanction on the parties is market forces. Indeed, I had some conversations with some of the market force adherents in the honourable senators' Party this morning who agreed with that. If, for instance, the pilots were to gain increases of 30 per cent, the discipline on them is that they may price themselves out of a job-which they would. In the absence of market imperfections, such as the two-airline agreement-and the trouble with our society is that there are so many imperfections in these lovely theoretical models-

TALK.START.PARA: —Adam Smith airlines.

—That is right. The only sanction necessary or appropriate is that the parties honour the terms of their existing contracts. Now that the pilots have brought their contracts to an end, they owe no duties and have no rights. I cannot understand why the Opposition seems to be unwilling to accept this proposition in the case of pilots but does accept it in the case of executive remuneration. What it boils down to, of course, is that one person's blackmail is another person's collective bargaining.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition may well argue that the existence of trade unions creates market imperfections and an unevenness of bargaining power, but so does the existence of so-called limited liability companies-not that that means anything. The problem for all sides is that the pilots are neither fish nor fowl-although they are pretty foul. They see themselves as executives but they want to employ the bargaining tactics of organised labour and capital. They are not unique in this. Doctors, engineers, salaried lawyers and most independent contractors have operated inside and outside the arbitration system at different stages in the past. In setting the price for their labour, such groups will be motivated by the desire to advance their own interests. Unlike most workers, however, their participation in the system is not necessarily linked to the support of the system. That is absolutely the case with the Pilots Federation, and it always has been. Indeed, professional groups, and this most militant of white-collar worker unions in this country, are totally antipathetic to the system-not only to our system but also to Senator Chaney's system too.

It is not altogether surprising that the pilots and the supporters of a deregulated labour market should blame the accord and the arbitral system for their current discontents. One can treat the accord and the system of industrial tribunals as a kind of social compact between various groups and interests in our society. One object of these social compacts is to reach market solutions-decent wages, full employment, low inflation, and sustainable rates of return on investment through non-market means. Under a market approach, it is possible to argue that the pilots should be given a wage rise-in other words, they should be given a greater claim on the community's resources-in the knowledge that this will lead to increased pressure on companies to ration their resources more efficiently between capital and labour so that in time work practices will change and greater efficiency will be achieved. That is how it is supposed to work. One problem with this approach is what happens in the meantime. The cost of bargaining, which is not just confined to the actual number of working days lost or even to the inconvenience caused to third parties, is a major reason for resorting to non-market arbitrated solutions. That seems to have been totally lost, I might add, on the Northern Territory Government.

Another justification for forcing parties to adhere to the system is that the system itself is a product of community goals and aspirations expressed by government. The pilots, as much as they might like to, cannot pick and choose between one system and another. Sorry, pilots. Income shares will be influenced by the ability of differing and competing groups to press their claims at the expense of others. Accordingly, the community has an interest in ensuring that free riding on the system-whatever the system is: accord or market based-is kept to a minimum. That, of course, is where the Opposition's heavy sanctions, as it keeps on saying, come from. This is not to endorse the so-called doctrine of comparative wage justice; it is merely to recognise the fact that there is a community of interest between all persons with a claim on the community's wealth. Merely stating, as the Opposition does, that its policy would encourage greater cooperation between employers and employees does nothing to resolve disputes where the parties cannot agree or where the agreement of one group leads to a widening of the dispute to new parties which see themselves as disadvantaged by the settlement that is struck by the original disputants. That is totally lost on the Opposition. It says, in the simple-minded approach, this Isle of Eden approach, it has to industrial relations, `Under our system, if one section of the market force, even if it is represented by an organised union, gets 30 per cent, no-one else will get it. There won't be a flow-on because we say it won't happen'. That is not how it works in this far from perfect world. It is human nature to say, `If you get it, I want it'. That is how it works. Under this system it will not function, it will not operate; it will break down because of that situation. Other people will see themselves as disadvantaged by this amicable settlement reached by the two people in the Opposition's theoretical model.

The particular problems that some critics ascribe to the existence of the accord and the tribunal system have arisen previously under different wage fixing arrangements. Changed institutional arrangements alter the means of dealing with the problem. Any approach which is based on consent is likely to strike difficulties where consent is hard to find. Where the parties are intractable, some form of sanctions may have to be resorted to to protect wider interests. This does not mean that the sanctions should be used as a first resort, nor does it mean that the whole of the employer-employee relationship should be fashioned to suit just one particular situation in the community. As I said before, for the Opposition to raise the proposed directions procedures in its legislation in this way, for the second time within a week, when existing remedies have not been fully tested and where the proposed changes would affect the rights of all employer and employee organisations, might not be seen by some critics as being a genuine attempt to resolve the current dispute. And, of course, it is not.

The reality is that nothing contained in this legislation can affect this current dispute. I wish to God that it could. If it could, I might well vote for it. But the trouble is that time has overtaken this legislation. We are now looking down the barrel of probably one of the most disastrous industrial disputes that this country has seen for some considerable time. I must say that, having had a very careful look at the history of industrial negotiations conducted by this union, it does not give one any encouragement whatsoever that there will be an easy resolution of this dispute. The problem is that the constants I have mentioned before are there for everyone to see in respect of all of the action that has been taken by the Pilots Federation. The first constant is a total disregard for the wider community interest when it conflicts with its own self-interest. The second constant is that the pilots have always gone for very large hikes in their salaries and conditions. The third constant is that they have always won.

The reason that this elite group has always won is that when faced with the absolutely crippling cost to the community it has always been able to inflict in past disputes, either one or other of the parties involved has quickly capitulated, buckled under, and paid up. Usually it is Ansett Airlines of Australia, for obvious reasons. Quite often it is the trade union movement itself, and certainly it is the government on every occasion. The result is that we are now in the current situation where the productivity of Australian pilots in comparison with their salaries is the worst in the world. As the Federation said last year-and I am not begrudging this highly professional group of extremely skilled people this position one iota-it has landed them in a situation where they have `the best pay and working conditions of any group of pilots in the world'. That is the trouble with this dispute. What the pilots want is the best plus 30 per cent.
