I must say that I am glad that the one piece of common ground which does exist and which appears to solidly exist-at least in the Federal Parliament-between the Government and Opposition parties is that, considering the pilots' current pay and working conditions and the current circumstances, it is an outrageous demand that should not be met.

I hope that this dispute will be resolved shortly. I commend once again the advice given to the pilots by Dr Blain in the policy section of his excellent work on the subject, that is, it is certainly not in the interests of this country-and it is not in the interests of the pilots either-to have any more prolonged disputes similar to the 28-day dispute of Qantas Airways Ltd in 1966 which resulted in disastrous consequences. I, like every member of this Parliament, am asking all of the parties in this dispute to bring it to some sort of resolution by one means or another and to do it quickly for the sake of the country and for the sake of themselves, not for the sake of any political party.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: LEAVE OF ABSENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave of absence be granted to the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) for the period from 4 to 7 September 1989, inclusive, on account of absence overseas on parliamentary business.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (DIRECTIONS TO STOP INDUSTRIAL ACTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1989 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in speaking in support of the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill 1989, the Bill presented in this chamber by Senator Chaney some weeks ago, rejected by the Government and the Australian Democrats, and now come back like the ghost of Christmases past to haunt us. If ever there were a Bill whose time had come, it is this Bill. The events of the last few weeks and the current pilots dispute have provided a perfect illustration of the powerlessness of the Industrial Relations Commission to enforce its directions. What Senator Chaney's Bill sets out to do is to put some sanctions and some teeth into the Industrial Relations Bill. Those teeth are quite effective.

SPEECH.PARA: At the present time we have a strike that is going on and on. The Government has no interest or ability to control the events. The pilots are not talking to the employers and the airline employers are not talking to the pilots. That would all be fine and well except that this country is losing millions and millions of dollars per day as a consequence of an outdated industrial relations system that the Australian Labor Party is persisting to support.

Not only is Australian industry, particularly the tourist industry, losing millions of dollars per day. We will also lose more money because of the great damage that has been done to our reputation and the tourist industry for years to come. When we think about the $10 billion or $12 billion-it is very hard to put an exact figure on it-that Australians have invested in not only building three, four and five star hotels on the tourist sites of this country, but also building all the infrastructure to support them-modifying airports, providing Customs services, transport services, entertainment and the other things that we have done that build up this industry-it is absolutely criminal that a situation should exist where we have no control over what is happening because of the persistence of the Labor Party with an entirely archaic system.

Senator Chaney's Bill will provide a means of applying sanctions in the Industrial Relations Commission. There are those people around in the Labor Party who do not want to be sanctioned in any way at all. They do not want to be brought under the rule of law. They want to rule without respect for their fellow man. Society is far too complex these days to indulge these little idiosyncrasies of living for yourself and having no thought for the welfare of the community about you. When we talk about putting sanctions into industrial relations, the Labor Party goes back 20 years or more to the days of Clarrie O'Shea and the way it was impossible decades ago to put any teeth into industrial relations. But if the Labor Party got out of its ivory tower and dealt with the real Australian community, it would find that there is a very different social attitude out there today.

Australians are tired of the way the archaic industrial relations system we have is dragging our standard of living down. They want something different; they know something different is possible; they know that there is a better way of doing it. The Liberal Party and the National Party have said that they do not mind unions, industrial relations and the Industrial Relations Commission remaining, provided it has the ability to enforce its judgments. But we are also saying in parallel with that that it is time Australia matured into an industrial relations climate where we had voluntary agreements that would be binding on both parties because they enter into them voluntarily. That is the way industrial societies are going for the benefit not only of the employer and the employees but for the welfare of the whole community.

One of the things that the Labor Party has fastened on in relation to Senator Chaney's Bill is the rather specious claim that it is our policies in practice that have produced the present situation. Nothing could be further from the truth. We are not in government, sadly, although it is only a few months away. The Labor Government is in power and it is its principles and support for the industrial relations policy that have brought all this about. It believes in a centralised wage fixing system. It believes that what an employee in Melbourne gets is the rate that someone should get in Darwin, Port Hedland or Longreach, irrespective of the profitability of the industry that is involved. It is locked in as inflexibly as the dinosaurs were four or five ice ages ago to a system which is now no longer applicable. In no sense is the present circumstance a consequence of our actions. It is very much a consequence of the Labor Party's actions.

The Liberal Party and the National Party do not support strike actions. We do not deny people the right to strike, but we do believe that there is a sense of responsibility that people must have in the Australian community. We are now far too complex a society and far too interdependent, one on another, to allow people to hold our society to ransom, and we certainly do not support the pilots strike. We certainly do not support any strikers who are holding the community to ransom and causing us a huge cost.

We would be right behind the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), if he would come out of his funk-hole, take the strikers on and do something effective. But in three weeks, apart from some intemperate and irrational abuse by the Prime Minister, we have not seen one constructive move by him to resolve this issue. The old superman from the trade union movement does not have the people on the ground that he used to have in the days when he was in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

We were plagued by strikes when Mr Hawke was President of the ACTU. The strike would get going, somebody would resolve it and Mr Hawke would come in and claim the credit. It seems these days that there is no-one around prepared to do the negotiating work for him, so nothing is coming out of Mr Hawke. The Liberal Party and the National Party would be right behind him if he took any constructive moves at all to resolve this issue. And we will be right behind him when when he takes on the waterside workers, the coal workers, the Transport Workers Union and all the people who put Senator McKiernan in here as their nominee. But we do not see the faintest sign of any balance or courage in what the Prime Minister and the Labor Party are doing.

Only last week when the practices of the waterside workers were under threat in the port of Brisbane on a grain loading exercise, the Prime Minister lent on the Queensland Grains Council to pull out its support for the move to get an efficient work force in loading that grain. Senator McKiernan is only one of the parliamentary spokesmen for Mr Hawke's vested interest, the trade unions. It is not a matter of the trade unions being a function of the Labor Party; it is a matter of the parliamentary Labor Party being the political wing of the trade union movement. It is when those interests are challenged that Mr Hawke does not do anything constructive about industrial relations in Australia. So we do not support the pilots and we certainly do not support any group that is holding the Australian community to ransom.

Let us reflect on some of the double dealings of this Hawke Labor Government. First of all I will refer to the use of strike breakers. Those of us who were in this chamber when we were in government know the enormous opprobrium and abuse that was hurled at us when we took constructive means to end a strike and get alternative sources of labour.

The greatest crime in the Labor Party trade union hagiography is strikebreaking. From day one, the Labor Party has been right up to its armpits in strikebreaking. First of all, it uses the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). The defence forces should not be used except in an emergency, and this is not an emergency. This is a matter that has arisen through the bungling of the Labor Party. But to get the Services to do what is essentially a political task in the way the Labor Party has done with the RAAF is absolutely an abuse of power. The Services will do it because they are loyal and disciplined. But the RAAF is not enjoying what it is doing one little bit. It is starved of resources. We heard today in answer to a question from Senator Reid that money is not going to the RAAF. There is a mickey mouse, fictional hourly charter rate on these services. When the RAAF finds that it is short of money, as I know it will, the Government will then try to shore it up by the use of supplementary estimates. The Air Force is getting nothing out of running these services around Australia. It is an abuse to be using the Services in a situation where no emergency exists.

Overseas airlines are interlining between the Australian States. Deeply in debt as we are to the tune of about $130 billion through the mismanagement of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, we are now losing millions of dollars a day by overseas airlines taking revenue out of the country. Charter groups are being licensed to fly in Australia although there is dubious surveillance of their safety standards. In fact, the normal procedures of the Civil Aviation Authority are not being followed because the Government is leaning on the Authority and putting the safety of the Australian travelling public at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under sessional order for consideration of General Business having expired, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of Government Business.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the adjournment of this debate at lunchtime today, I was drawing very important comparisons between the annual reports of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) for 1986-87 and 1987-88. I believe that I demonstrated to the Senate the very deliberate and nasty work of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in July 1987 when he took over the portfolio and the very radical and different changes that have been made since that time. I spent some time in the debate earlier today pointing out various issues and quoting various facts that, while perhaps unpalatable to the Government, certainly give those of us who represent Aboriginal people in our electorates, and people like Senator Peter Baume and Senator Chaney who have had ministerial responsibility in this area, a great deal of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the Senate to Senator Peter Baume's speech on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill on 17 August. I commend this speech to anybody doing research on this area. Senator Peter Baume has spent a great deal of time developing a very principled and detailed argument. In his speech Senator Peter Baume said:

. . . we shall oppose the emasculation of Aboriginal self-management and the nobbling of the Aboriginal Development Commission, and we vigorously oppose any attempt that might be made actually to dismember the Aboriginal Development Commission ahead of ATSIC arrangements being put in place.
Further on in the same speech Senator Peter Baume said:

My objective, and the objective of the Opposition, remains the achievement of better outcomes. Our objective remains the achievement of outcomes such as less illness, fewer Aboriginals in prison, more effective Aboriginal participation in education and the education system, greater Aboriginal longevity, more people housed, better housing, more people in employment, more Aboriginal people in senior administrative positions, fewer alcohol and drug problems, and so on. The question before the Senate now is whether or not ATSIC is the vehicle to achieve the outcomes. Sadly, it is not. This proposal is more likely to remove Aboriginal Australians from the mainstream of Australian life, to emphasise Aboriginal separateness, to require Aboriginal people to operate in a system different from other Australians and to make them into welfare recipients forever. If ATSIC proceeds, they will be the victims of a new paternalism. The damage which ATSIC will do to Aboriginal Australia may be irremediable; at the very least it will take a generation to fix.

I do not believe that any senator could make more profound or correct statements than those made by Senator Peter Baume when the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) debate was first brought on. As I said earlier today, in drawing out the differences between the operating years of 1986-87 and 1987-88, we are able to see that a very deliberate and political ploy was brought to bear by Mr Hand and the socialist Left which has a very different agenda in Australia. We need to recognise that there are many people working in the Aboriginal industries, if I can call them that-that is a correct term to use. Many fine Aboriginal leaders and many outstanding public servants in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission and other statutory authorities serving Aborigines and people in State and Territory governments around Australia have a very strong commitment to this cause.

In my ATSIC speech I quoted Charles Perkins, the former Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, who drew attention to the change in advice that the Minister, Mr Hand, gave when he came to the portfolio in July 1987. I again quote what he said, because it is most important and well worth restating. Charles Perkins was quoted in the Canberra Times of 15 August as follows:

The Minister had surrounded himself with advisers all of a similar character to himself. They knew what was going on. They were in constant contact and discussions with the Central and Northern Land Councils.

What we have now is a most unsatisfactory situation in terms of some of the people ripping off Aboriginal affairs . . . vagabonds and hooligans, self-elected and self-seeking, and pretending to represent Aborigines here and overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That was said by Charles Perkins in August of this year when he was reflecting on the administration of the portfolio since July 1987.
—Has he reflected on you yet?

—It certainly has not reflected on anything that I have done. It is also important to remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in commenting on the Menzies report, said that he was of the view that Mr Menzies had found `some cases of questionable practice' and that the final report `brings out some further shortcomings in administration in the area of Aboriginal affairs'. The Prime Minister further went on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there were deficiencies in systems and procedures going well beyond the realm of Mr Perkins' personal responsibility.

If they go beyond the realm of Mr Perkins's personal responsibility, they can only at that time have been sheeted home to the Minister, Mr Hand. The Prime Minister has caned Mr Hand in terms of the words that I have just read to the Senate.

I mentioned in the debate this morning that the Minister, Mr Hand, chose to sack the Aboriginal commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission in May 1988 because they had had the audacity to prepare an alternative strategy for Aboriginal self-management. The document that they prepared in March 1988, presented to the Minister very openly and publicly as part of this debate, makes most interesting reading. Of course, it has been hidden by the Government ever since. It has never been referred to; there has never been a critique made of it; there has never been any discussion; and it has never been put on the table.

Let me just refer to some of the points made in that document. This, I remind the Senate, was the considered document of the commissioners at that time, March 1988-all Aboriginal people working for the Government-reflecting on both the successes and the weaknesses of the system. They, of course, were responding to the ATSIC proposal that had been floated by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand. Let me quote the limitations of the ATSIC proposal that were outlined in the executive summary of this report:
The proposal creates a clumsy bureaucracy that will overly complicate the decision making process.
It offers no improvement in economic development or Program development.

The relationship of ATSIC to the Minister will be like that between a Minister and a Department. The autonomy, presently existing in the ADC, to decide upon philosophy, policy, procedures and funding will be lost. The Minister has a far reaching role in ATSIC.
Decision making powers of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders under the ADC Act, Aboriginal Hostels Limited and AIAS will be limited and replaced with advisory powers.

Although involvement for Aboriginal people at the local level is most desirable, the Regional and Zone Councils as proposes would be a recipe for destructive conflict. Their roles would be merely advisory.

Objectives of self-management, Aboriginal controls over program delivery and effective promotion of economic independence which are vitally important to Aboriginals and Islanders will not be achieved through ATSIC.

Social Welfare and Economic Development Programs will be integrated and lumped together in the same organisation thus creating a situation where the dissimilar objectives of each are likely to become confused at all levels.

Economic Development Programs will only be partially separated between the AEDC and ATSIC. This will fragment resources. Also, it will not allow the responsible integration of the program to the long term goals of financial self-sufficiency and self-management.
The proposal will create additional administrative expenditure which would be at the expense of Program funds.
The proposal has been created without the benefit of an overall strategy for the long term advancement of Aboriginal people.

The document `Foundations for the Future', which described ATSIC, is short on detail and long on generalities. It does not offer Aboriginal people a real choice in the creation of a structure that will affect their lives for years to come.
They were the criticisms that were so embarrassing to Minister Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —From whom?

—They were from the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission, who were all Aboriginal people, in March 1988. Because they had the audacity to put that on paper and to distribute it as part of the ongoing debate that the Minister had invited, they were sacked. They were wiped out and replaced with a bunch of stooges, all of the Minister's own deliberate choosing.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this document did not concentrate just on the limitations of ATSIC. It also went to develop, very properly, an alternative strategy which, as I said earlier, the Minister has hidden. This came from the Aboriginal Development Commission. That strategy that it put down outlined and was calling for: a new Aboriginal Services Commission; an Aboriginal Ombudsman; regional councils which are popularly elected; a national congress to replace the National Aboriginal Conference; retention of the ADC and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies as specialised agencies; increased self-management and control; a larger Aboriginal and Islander affairs portfolio; greater administrative efficiency and economies of scale; and improved program delivery and rationalisation. They were the positives.

This particular document was used by Mr Hand as the knife to get rid of properly effective commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission because he did not like it and it did not suit the political agenda of the socialist Left. The socialist Left did not like the fact that Aboriginal people had the audacity to come out with such a constructive document as part of the open debate. It may well not have been the final result, but the Minister was not even prepared to read it. He merely wiped these people off the face of the earth without even saying thank you. Certainly, as we have seen several times today, both in the debate on the ADC report and in my contribution earlier this morning, the 1987-88 annual report is a disgraceful document because of its omissions, because of the way in which Mr Hand has chosen to get into bed with so many different people with a very different agenda.

If we look at the Budget for this year we will see that once again the Minister has kept up this vendetta against the ADC. The budget for the Aboriginal Development Commission in the current financial year has been very heavily changed and constrained. Of course, even the new commissioners-the hand-picked commissioners-did not like this particular action and were proposing to put out a critical press statement on this. Word of it got through to the Minister's office, and the Minister's office called for the details. Maybe even his new group this year are under threat. He asked to see the draft press release that was to be put out and he summoned officers of the ADC to his office. He instructed them that they were not to go ahead in those particular terms-that the press statement could go out only if it was amended to acknowledge that the ADC was responsible for the error in the Budget paper, not the Minister's office nor the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, with whom the full and direct responsibility would then come back to the Minister's desk. It is interesting to note that the ADC did not put out a press release under such terms and conditions as this particular situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know about it?

—I have got pretty good sources, as you know, Senator. They certainly are good. Get your mate to come in here and deny that is the way in which it would go. I am concerned that in this particular debate we have not heard a contribution from the Democrats, and I am hoping that Senator Coulter later will show us where he believes that the proposals now before us are consistent with the stance and the views that he took in the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs last year and that the proposals with regard to the Aboriginal Development Commission are in line with the representations that Aborigines have been making to the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very surprising that the Democrats have been seduced by the Minister with regard to this particular legislation at this time. I would never suppose to think for a Democrat or think as a Democrat. My politics are far too removed from that. But I am surprised, because if I were a Democrat and were looking at this issue tactically, let alone anything else, and wanted to achieve outcomes that were better for Aboriginal people, there is only one condition on which I would agree to any of this particular legislation going through. That condition would be that the Government change the Minister, because all of the problems in this particular regard since July 1987 have been compounded by Mr Hand. How can any Democrat sit there and not believe that the ATSIC legislation is going to produce a dreadful umbrella and is going to be open to such manipulation and control by Mr Hand, as he has shown across this portfolio for the past two years? In all of the evidence that has come out in the Estimates Committee, in the Senate Select Committee last year, and in all of the inquiries that the Prime Minister and the Government instituted-and read every one of the recommendations of those reports-the responsibility comes back to the deck of one person, that is, the Minister, Mr Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it should.

—So it should, in some sense, but he is still there, and ought not to have been since October 1988. I cannot understand what control the socialist Left has over the Prime Minister in the time that he has retained Gerry Hand as Minister, because nothing is going to achieve any objective change of emphasis for Aborigines in Australia whilst Mr Hand remains in the position of Minister. If the Prime Minister has not got the sense after all of this time and all of this debate and all of this proof to realise that, then God help Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We in the Australian Labor Party are not controlled by the socialist Left; we are in fact all controlled by the Centre Left, the intellectual middle ground of the Labor Party which holds the balance of power and which is so well represented in the Senate by Senator Cook. I hope the Federal Opposition is on common ground with the Government in condemning, as they should be condemned, the airline pilots of this country for asking for a 30 per cent pay hike. I hope that Senator Tambling is as thundering in his denunciation of his shameless conservative colleagues in the Party that he belongs to in government in the Northern Territory for the outrageous 30 per cent pay hike they awarded themselves this afternoon in the Territory's Parliament as he has been in this debate of the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), but I would not hold my breath.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to comply with the time limit for debate this evening, but I would like to canvass a number of things that have been said by previous speakers. It is well known that the person for whom I have the most respect on the Opposition benches in the area of Aboriginal Affairs is Senator Peter Baume. However, with respect to Senator Baume, I have to say that I take considerable difference with him on the remarks that he made, as dramatic as they sounded, when he introduced his contributions to this debate and said that the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill that we are debating tonight was an evil and malevolent Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a perfectly justified opinion.

—It is not, actually. I refer Senator Baume and Senator Stone to the Hansard of the House of Representatives. They would see that we are debating the Bill because it was brought before the Parliament as the result of a commitment and a pledge which has been honoured. That commitment was given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives in April this year as a result of the evil and malevolent campaign that was waged by members of the Opposition and Senator Tambling, in particular, against Aboriginal people in this country and against particular Aboriginals. Senator Tambling is now, as always, vociferously denying-I was hoping he would-that he made any unjustified or unreasonable personal attacks on individual people. With some astonishment, I have heard him say that before. I did not have time to do more than go for a wander through the Hansard debates in this chamber and pull out a selection. I left aside all the appalling personal accusations he has made against Charles Perkins in the media and in the committees of the Parliament. It even made me blink a bit when I put the accusations together, because they have all been disproved. There is probably no better investigated person in Australia at the moment than Charles Perkins and the reports of all those investigations have been tabled in the Parliament. Quite correctly, Senator Tambling said that the buck stops on the Minister's desk; it certainly does. But has Senator Tambling uttered one word of apology? He has the hide to talk about the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs not saying, `Thanks fellas'-as I personally think he should have-to the sacked Aboriginal Development Commission commissioners.
—At least you can see that.
—Why would I not? I joined the majority report, along with my colleague, Senator McMullan, that said he should.
—But has he done so?

—Considering that the Minister adopted 90 per cent of the recommendations of that report, the majority does not have too much to be concerned about. But there is one person in this chamber who would have to have unmitigated gall to talk about not apologising to people and that would have to be Senator Tambling, as I will comprehensively demonstrate in a minute. Not one word of apology has Senator Tambling uttered about the absolutely appalling personal reflections he has made on Charles Perkins, despite the fact that we are up to our ears in reports saying that none of his claims was proven.

SPEECH.PARA: I add that in respect of the `black mafia' assertion, Senator Tambling himself admitted 10 minutes after he made it that it was false, but that he had to deliver it to attract the attention of the Press Gallery. Honourable senators should listen to some of the other things that Senator Tambling said in this chamber about Charles Perkins and think about whether they would like to have such things said about them. Earlier in this debate, a crocodile tears reference was made to the lack of an Aboriginal adviser in the advisers box in the chamber. Why would any Aboriginal person want to come into this chamber to listen to the personal vilification that has been put on Aboriginal people? If an Aboriginal person sat in here, he would probably find it very hard to resist the temptation to jump the bar and punch someone on the other side on the nose.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is total nonsense.

—I invite Senator Stone to listen. He is a man of some circumspection and integrity. He does not like unsustained and unjustified attacks on people. He likes to play with a straight bat. He is a man who likes to see the old school team play a good game of cricket. I invite him, then, to listen to this and tell me, in light of the evidence that is presented, whether he thinks this is cricket. I refer to the accusations that Senator Tambling has made about Charles Perkins in this chamber and for which not one word of apology has been made. The references are in chronological order.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling has accused this individual Australian of `nepotism and cronyism; associating with criminals; lousy and inefficient administration; suspicious behaviour; being in control of a black mafia; being responsible for scandals and rorts; being a confidant of unsavoury persons; running a network of mates and cronies; appointing his crony to be the manager of the ADC; setting up gangs of lefties around Australia and suspicious networks; disgraceful administration; poor administration; conducting a lot of funny business at the crossroads; suffering from amnesia; and running an unguided missile of an administration'. That is not a bad selection of personal reflections on an individual who was cleared in the numerous reports produced as a result of that evil and malevolent campaign. The Opposition has a hide to talk about evil and malevolence. Despite the fact that not one iota of evidence was found to substantiate the claims-the Opposition in its statements in the Parliament on those reports has accepted that-there has not been a single word of apology from Senator Tambling. What we have had in here has been the sight of Senator Tambling-today and in his speech on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill the other day-quoting Charles Perkins with approbation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did it again just a few moments ago.

—He did. Charles Perkins has now become a paragon of virtue, someone who can be quoted and used as a source of authoritative comment against the Government, although not so long ago he was an associate of criminals, a confidant of unsavoury persons, someone running rorts and indulging in nepotism, cronyism and funny business at the crossroads. I have been in Parliament for almost 13 years-it is as rough and tumble in the Northern Territory Parliament as it is here-but I have not seen such a collection of gross personal reflections on an individual, totally unproven reflections, as when I did this little exercise only an hour ago. It is a disgusting vendetta and an evil and malevolent personal attack on an individual when we consider the fact that the proof that every one of these charges is totally unjustified has been tabled in the Senate. Having put this collection together, I feel that my contribution to the debate this evening is overdue. I did not have the time to look at the Hansard transcripts of the committee proceedings, but I know that in them are a lot more accusations just as nasty, just as vicious, just as evil, just as malevolent and just as wrong as these. Senator Tambling has still made not a single word of apology for having absolutely slandered this person in the chamber on totally unproven charges.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I have listened very carefully and I do not like interrupting my colleague, but when he says that Senator Tambling has slandered someone he is now transgressing standing order 418.
—I withdraw that assertion.
—There is no point of order, anyway.

—I withdraw the assertion anyway, because I think the facts stand on their own pretty well. I have listened to Senator Tambling and others make thundering denunciations against the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because he terminated the contracts of a number of people whom I had a hand in appointing, to my regret, to the ADC. That is a matter for judgment as to whether he should have let them run the six weeks or not. But I have got to say this: when one stands that alongside this garbage, it is pretty small beer. What I would like to say this afternoon is this: in the adjournment debate this evening I would like to hear Senator Tambling apologise to Charles Perkins for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing this evening two Bills: a Bill to amend the Aboriginal Development Commission Act to restructure the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) temporarily because the ADC will disappear under the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation and a Bill to restructure the Institute of Aboriginal Studies. I wish to address my remarks entirely to the first of those two Bills, the Bill dealing with the restructuring of the ADC. I draw attention to the fact that the ADC, of course, was an instrument of the Opposition. When in government it set this body up; and one can only applaud the criteria which were used to create that body. It was created in recognition of prior Aboriginal occupation of Australia and dispossession and it was set up to do a number of things for Aboriginal people by Aboriginal people who were appointed to the board controlling ADC. Indeed, it is the only piece of legislation which actually contains specific reference to that prior Aboriginal occupation and dispossession. The then Government, now the Opposition, created a capital fund in recognition of that fact and that capital fund was to be augmented as time went on, essentially as a compensatory fund for that dispossession.

SPEECH.PARA: I totally applaud the motivation and the ideas that went into the creation of the ADC. Indeed, when the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs was considering the ATSIC Bill, one of the recommendations that it made was that that particular clause in the ADC Bill which gave that recognition to Aboriginal people should be carried over into the new Bill because it was recognised that the ADC Bill would be revoked and that, if that were the case, there would be no legal recognition in any piece of legislation. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has accepted that and that clause has been carried over into the amended ATSIC Bill.

However, the Government has also sought to change one of the very significant impediments to the use of that capital fund. I would just like to pick this up for a moment, because clearly it affects the ADC Bill very much and the future operation of that part of the Commission's activity which will be picked up by ATSIC. The Government has sought to ask the new body, the ATSIC Development Corporation, to pay both a dividend on earnings from the capital fund and tax on the earnings from the capital fund. It seems to me that, given the recognition of the original purpose and intention of that capital fund, it is quite unconscionable that the Aboriginal people should be asked to pay either a dividend or a tax on that fund. It is not money to which, by way of a grant or anything else, the rest of the Australian population has some right. It is, indeed, a fund which was set up clearly in recognition of dispossession and was recognised as a compensatory fund. I would like to return to that later on.

The ADC, when it was first created, clearly had a mix of purposes which were not carefully thought out. The ADC had a social welfare function and an economic development function. Those roles, not properly and carefully defined, led to the funding of a number of proposals which were not successful as economic development attempts and that, in turn, led to the House of Representatives setting up an inquiry which reported in 1984, in an interim way, and in 1985 and which recommended that the ADC should take on a more specific economic development function and that its role in social welfare should be downplayed.

I believe that the way in which the ADC set about changing that role and redefining its task, particularly under the chairmanship of Mrs Shirley McPherson, was done in an extremely good and sound way. I would certainly like to record that, in my experience of Mrs McPherson, she is an exemplary person who did an excellent job in her position as Chair of the ADC. Indeed, under her chairmanship, the ADC went a great distance toward implementing that recommendation of swinging the ADC towards economic development-type work.

Of course, as we all know, when the ATSIC proposal came along the ADC, recognising that there was merit in keeping the social welfare and economic development functions separate, made representations to the Minister that that separation should continue. It made an alternative proposal to the Minister that, whatever the new body was to be called, it should take on that economic development function, to be kept separate from the social welfare function. As we all know, the Minister did not accept that and that, in turn, led to the dismissal of the ADC commissioners. I have expressed before the view-I think shared by many in this chamber-that that was indeed a very sad and sorry time in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. I believe I have reflected before, as has the Opposition, on the ungraciousness of the Minister in not recording the good work which those previous commissioners had done.

We are now faced with the creation of two new bodies, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and a body which will be known as the Development Corporation. The role of the ATSIC Development Corporation, I believe, would be more appropriately broadened to take on more of the economic development-type functions, as has been suggested by the former ADC commissioners. The Minister, I believe, in this respect does have a hidden agenda. I believe that, having taken a strong stand against the ADC, he is unwilling to accept the merits of the case which they put. I think this is most unfortunate, but I believe that to be the case.

Interestingly, the Minister is attempting to give to the new body a very restricted role. It will behave very much like a bank, applying the same rigid criteria for assessment of proposals and for lending. In view of the particular nature of many of the Aboriginal proposals for economic development, a more liberal approach to those proposals would be appropriate. I have suggested that to the Minister on several occasions. The words which he used in his second reading speech with respect to the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill now before us were:
That the Commission-
he is referring here to the Aboriginal Development Commission in this interim period-
will be required to satisfy itself that the enterprise is likely to become or continue to be commercially successful.

It seems to me that that is the more liberal criterion that the Minister should have carried that over into this new body. There may well be proposals which in the first instance would not be of such a robust nature that they would be financed by the bank; nonetheless there is a reasonable expectation that eventually they would become commercially viable. That was the intention at the initiation of this proposal. In discussions with the Minister, I have likened this situation very much to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) where the Government set up a body deliberately to provide finance to those organisations having proposals which in their first attempt to get finance were not likely to do so from regular sources. Nonetheless, there was a reasonable expectation that over time those proposals would become economically viable. As we all know, the AIDC has been successful and recently the Government has hived 30 per cent of that body off to private interest. The Minister had not accepted that view. I think that is unfortunate.

I would have preferred that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission would have a greater role along the lines that I have suggested. Unfortunately, this is not achievable, I believe, with the present Minister. I will, however, when we get to the debate on the clauses of the ATSIC legislation, in the committee stage, be moving an amendment to seek the removal of the requirement that the ATSIC pay dividends and tax on earnings from its capital fund. The Government in its answer to that proposal has said, `Well, of course, the Government can simply pay less money into the capital fund'. I cannot help but reflect that this Government has paid no money into the capital fund since 1983, so that would not be at all unusual. It is clearly more honest, recognising that this fund is a compensatory fund, for the Government not to charge dividends and tax against the earnings on that fund and to put less money in-at least that is open and clearly seen for what it is-rather than to put the money in and to claw money back by way of dividend and tax.

There are some amendments which the Opposition is proposing to this Bill which seem to me to go very much to the matter of self-management which the business is supposed to be about. I will listen with a great deal of interest to Senator Peter Baume when he puts those amendments. It seems to me that some of those amendments will be acceptable to the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must commence my remarks on the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989 and the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill 1989, which we are debating cognately, by referring to what I can only call the intemperate outburst earlier this evening by Senator Collins from the Government side of the chamber.
—It seemed to me he had good cause.

—I nevertheless regard it as an intemperate outburst. Senator Collins picked up the phrase which apparently was used-I did not actually hear it-by Senator Peter Baume in opening the second reading debate for the Opposition on these two Bills when he referred to the Bill relating to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), apparently, as a malevolent and evil Bill. I would have to say, without necessarily wanting to spend too long on particular choices of words, that, whether or not this particular Bill is a malevolent and evil one, there is not the slightest doubt in my mind that the whole construct which this chamber has now had before it for debate in the last few weeks-namely, the construct of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill and the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill and the companion Bill which we are debating now-is undoubtedly a malevolent and evil construct. I think that, in choosing such words earlier today, Senator Peter Baume in that broader context spoke no more than the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators on this side have already spelt out at some length in the earlier second reading debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, we have before us in this package of Bills, including the main one, a set of proposals which is designed to create the greatest upheaval not only in the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country but also in the relationships between Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people in this country. That is why such respected authorities as Professor Colin Howard to whom I have referred in my own earlier remarks in the second reading debate on the ATSIC Bill-a man not given to extremes in his language-should have chosen to refer to the likely divisiveness of that Bill and of this package of Bills as a whole in terms of their future effect upon race relations in this country.

Irrespective of how one chooses to describe this particular Bill-I was not present in the chamber to hear Senator Peter Baume's elaboration of his thesis on that but I have no doubt that he has good reason for using those words about that particular Bill-and whatever the facts may be about this particular Bill, there is not the slightest doubt that the phrase is eminently and entirely justified so far as it concerns the whole package of Bills.

I also remark on the fact that, in his intemperate outburst, Senator Collins at no time referred to the Bill before the chamber. He may have referred to it by name or by title on one or two occasions-no doubt to retain your indulgence, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker. I am not in any way complaining about that indulgence. There is a lot of indulgence given by the Chair in this place and properly so. I think it is fair to say that Senator Collins usually contributes-I do not necessarily agree with him-to debate in this chamber when he rises to speak. What was noticeably absent from his remarks tonight was any such contribution. His remarks tonight consisted simply of a furious attack more notable for its passion and the loudness with which it was expressed than for any relevance that it actually had to the Bill before the Senate.

I would like to go further in relation to a particular remark that Senator Collins made when referring not so much to the sacking of Mr Charles Perkins but to the recent history of Mr Charles Perkins. I do not want in any way to reflect here upon Mr Perkins. Mr Perkins has been a public servant in this city for many years. I would have to say, and I hope it will not be taken away, Mr Acting Deputy President, that he has not been the most distinguished public servant in this city. I would equally have to say that he has not been the most undistinguished one either. I simply want to say of Mr Perkins that, at the end of the day, and after all these investigations have taken place, he has not been reinstated to his previous position by the Minister and, indeed, I understand that Mr Hand has said that he would not re-employ Mr Perkins. I think that leaves us-and, if I may say so, Senator Collins-with a small difficulty that either Mr Hand is right, in which case Mr Perkins can hardly be, or that Mr Perkins is right in which case Mr Hand can hardly be. I suspect that in fact Senator Collins's impassioned defence of Mr Perkins, admirable though it undoubtedly was from one point of view, amounted in effect to and, indeed, may very well have been motivated by an equally impassioned denunciation of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, because that is the only logical conclusion one can draw in all the circumstances.

I simply want to leave all that there and rather regret that I have taken eight minutes of the Senate's time to respond to remarks that I suggest need not have been and ought not to have been made by Senator Collins earlier. Incidentally, I wish to correct now something I said a moment ago when I said that Senator Collins had made almost no reference to the Bill. I think that last is true. He did make almost no reference to the Bill. But at one point he did, I agree, refer-I now recollect that he referred-to Mr Hand's actions in sacking all of the commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission except the Chairman, Mrs Shirley McPherson, and the only reason he did not sack her was that it was not at that time in his power to do so. Senator Collins did, as I say, glancingly refer to that incident.

I want to spend a little more time, and not in a glancing fashion, in doing likewise. Why we have this Bill before us, of course, is because of the particular attitude, the malevolent attitude certainly-whether it be evil could be debated-which this Minister has brought to the Aboriginal Development Commission. That malevolence was thoroughly reflected in this Minister's decision to sack every commissioner of the Aboriginal Development Commission whom it was in his power to sack. And why was that? It was because those appointed persons, in attempting-not I think wholly efficiently, and that is a point I will return to-to discharge the duties laid upon them by the Act of Parliament under which they operated, were simply not willing to do the bidding of the Minister. That is why they were sacked.

As I said, although I in no way condone the action of the Minister in dismissing the people concerned and putting in their place the bunch of stooges-I do not want to be unduly harsh but I think it is a fair word in this context-whom he has subsequently appointed, the fact is that the record of the Aboriginal Development Commission did indeed leave a lot to be desired. The various reports from the office of the Auditor-General in particular, which have been subsequently received by the Senate, have highlighted the many deficiencies. I am thinking particularly of the report into the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission itself by the Auditor-General's Office. It highlighted the many deficiencies of the lending processes of the Commission. Time after time that report by the Auditor-General sets down in dry, but nonetheless compelling prose, the failure of the ADC even to observe the straightforward legal conditions under which it was required to lend. Nevertheless, grave though I think it is fair to say those deficiencies were, it is fair to add that there was at least some form of control, some form of public accountability with the ADC as presently constituted, as the very reports and inquiries which I have just been referring to demonstrate-the estimates processes of this Parliament, for example.

What will happen when these functions are handed over to this new monster, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which the Parliament is in the process of allowing the Minister to create? Can honourable senators imagine the handing over of, let us say, for example, the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank to the politicians who make up the Parliament? Imagine what would be the result if the Parliament were given the responsibility of running the Commonwealth Development Bank with very considerable funds at its disposal and powers to lend. I do not want to impugn the integrity of any member or senator in this place, even in the general sense, but I have to say that it would be enormously surprising if, on the basis of all experience, not just of Australian parliaments but all legislatures, the most notable result of that process were not to be that a great many bad loans would be made, a great many cronies of parliamentarians would suddenly find themselves favoured and we would have the sort of pandemonium arising from that which that kind of process would be bound to lead to. However, when one actually looks into it, that is not very far different from what the Government is now seriously proposing under the terms of the legislation before us. The Government is proposing to abolish the present Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). However poorly or, let me use a kindly word, imperfectly, it may have been administered in the past, it has at least a proper framework of legislative control under which that administration is supposed to occur. Therefore, it provides a framework for public accountability when those controls are not observed. I am afraid that under what is now proposed we will not have that kind of situation at all.

Recently in Queensland we have had a lot of nonsense about the operations of the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. All sorts of wild allegations have been thrown around about loans having been made to members of the National Party, and nonsense, for the most part, of that kind. Imagine what it will be like when this new body is set up, clothed with full statutory power, given a budget-given cash from the public purse, from Australian taxpayers-and can, in effect, make decisions to acquire land and other property and so on.

At one point in his remarks Senator Coulter seemed to be arguing-I trust I have interpreted his remarks correctly, and he will correct me if I did not-that the role allocated to the development corporation within the new Commission had been unduly narrowed and it would have been better for it to have been expanded. Senator Coulter read into that what he called a hidden agenda on the part of the Minister. Far be it from me to suggest that Minister Hand does not have a hidden agenda, but I am inclined to wonder whether narrowing the role of the development corporation part of the Commission provides evidence for that. It is an interesting point put forward by Senator Coulter and I look forward with interest to his developing it, as I imagine he will do, in the committee stage of this Bill.

In reality, I have to confess that nowadays one is cynical enough to wonder whether it really matters very much. The fact is, as history shows, that as long as we have the present Minister, and that is the key point, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will do as it wants anyway. There will not be any great regard, as past experience shows, for legislative constraints because there is a view about that there is a different rule for the administration of these matters where they involve Aboriginal affairs. Whereas in non-Aboriginal areas we have principles of public accountability, and all those things which make up part of the Westminster system of government and which are at the heart of public propriety, somehow, when those rules are breached by actions occurring in the area of Aboriginal affairs, that can be waived away as something that must be expected. That is essentially a racist attitude-much more racist than the views of many people who, when discussing Aboriginal questions, are accused of being racist. What could be more racist than the kind of condescension which suggests that because a matter occurs in the area of Aboriginal affairs, therefore, the same standards of public accountability, care for public moneys-care for the public purse-should not operate or, at any rate, should not be enforced with the same degree of rigour as they would be in other areas?

I conclude by saying that whether this is an evil Bill or not which is, I understand, part of the description applied to it by Senator Peter Baume earlier, as reported by Senator Collins-and I have no doubt that if Senator Peter Baume did say that he had good reason for doing so and was fully justified in his comment-it is certainly a malevolent Bill. It is a malevolent Bill which, as I said earlier, undoubtedly forms part of a malevolent and evil package of Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is engaged in a second reading debate on two Bills, the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill 1989 and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989. I do not intend to take a great deal of time in responding to the various second reading contributions made by senators for fear of traversing ground that has already been well-tilled by my colleagues from this side, and more than well-tilled by those on the other side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in relation to the superseding of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) by the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), there was some suggestion by Senator Peter Baume that one of his concerns was brought about by the fact that this seemed so unnecessary. I think he said that within a matter of hours of the passing of the ATSIC legislation the Aboriginal Development Commission will no longer exist and, therefore, the passage of this Bill might have some symbolic significance, but was really not justified, given that short time frame.

Of course, it will be the fact that even with the passage of the ATSIC legislation, should it be the wish of the Parliament that that should occur and its being given royal assent, the legislation does not commence until a date fixed by proclamation or six months after royal assent, whichever is the sooner. That is made clear in clause 2. Just a look at clause 2 indicates that the Aboriginal Development Commission will have a significant role to play over the next few months, although not as significant in terms of the length of the contribution it might make as would have been the case had it been passed in the autumn session of the Parliament this year. Nevertheless, there is a role for it to play for several months and the Government believes it is important that that role be readjusted in the light of various undertakings given by the Government. It is quite clear, for example, from the statement made by the Prime Minister on the administration of Aboriginal affairs, a statement made to the Parliament on 11 April 1989, where his commitment lies in relation to the various reports on the administration of Aboriginal affairs, which was revealed to be deficient in many ways. The Prime Minister had this to say:

We have, moreover, considered to what extent the thrust of those recommendations should apply to the ADC while it continues to function in the lead-up to ATSIC, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will indicate in his statement.

As I say, to fill in the time before the coming into operation of ATSIC a need was felt to carry through the various recommendations of the reports into, some would say, the maladministration that had characterised some parts of the various organisations which delivered services to the Aboriginal people. For example, in the statement made by the Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Gerry Hand, on that very same day, 11 April 1989, he said:

ATSIC will not be operational for some months but there is clearly a need identified in the reports of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General to act now to remedy deficiencies within the present structure.
The report of the Department of Finance on the financial management of the Aboriginal Development Commission of March 1989 recommends on page 17 of the report, recommendation No. 11.1:

It is recommended that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs exercise greater ministerial authority over the Commission. In respect of the approval of the Commission's estimates, this would have an immediate effect on the operations of the Commission and would ensure that the Commission's programs at least reflect the priorities of the Government's policies. It is therefore recommended that the Minister for Finance write to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs suggesting that he consider:
(a) the means by which the Commission may be required to provide him with estimates for approval, including for the remainder of this financial year;
(b) advice of the financial policies to be followed in the administration and control of the Commission's programs and;
(c) a corporate plan for endorsement.
The Minister should also request that the Commission provide him with quarterly reports on program activity or performance.

There one has an indication from the Department of Finance, following its examination of the financial management of the Aboriginal Development Commission, of certain matters which ought to be taken up by a government wishing, as the Prime Minister and the Minister indicated is the case, to implement the changes which are required, even if it be only for a matter of some months. Once again, the Auditor-General's special report on the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs had this to say at page 60, paragraph 2:10:12-

The Minister's powers to obtain information are limited. The ADC is required to provide him with annual estimates of proposed expenditure in such form as he directs, but it is not required to obtain his approval of the estimates. The estimates that have been provided are in broad terms, but it would be open to the Minister to require the estimates to be in detail, even to the point of identifying particular projects and the amounts proposed to be spent on each during the year.

I think there is reason to try to ensure that, if the Aboriginal Development Commission is to operate in this interim period over the next several months, it ought to do so in a way which carries through those types of recommendations. That is, indeed, the simple aim of this Bill.

In relation to the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989, the Government is concerned that the Institute operates very much as the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS) currently operates and, of course, to carry out its very important function in undertaking for itself, and promoting, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies and to encourage and train research workers, particularly Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander researchers, and to undertake research in its own right.

It is important to recognise that the Government wishes the Institute to operate in a way which reflects the high professional standards and the integrity of its operations which, of course, is a concern for those who believe that it has a real role to play in relation to the understanding of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their culture and history, by themselves, by the rest of Australia and, indeed, by the world community. For that, a level of integrity and scholarship is required and certainly the Government wishes to see that continue.

In relation to the various amendments proposed by Senator Peter Baume, I indicate that the Government is going to be fairly responsive to many of them but I would like to await the commencement of the committee stage because I understand from private conversation that he intends to delete one or two of his proposed amendments. Once those amendments are clear on the record, I will then be able to indicate what the Government intends to do in relation to other amendments which he has proposed.

In relation to the Institute, it is true, as Senator Peter Baume has pointed out, that the Government has not proceeded with appointments to fill the existing six Governor-General appointed positions on the Institute of Aboriginal Studies Council. Now that there has been a reorganisation of the Institute in the offing, should the Parliament so desire, with different arrangements for the membership of the Council, it is not considered appropriate to proceed with recommending appointments to the Governor-General for the six vacant positions at this time. I have indicated privately to Senator Peter Baume that the Minister was prepared to make appointments earlier this year but, for a particular reason, had not proceeded with a particular matter. Now that we are at the stage of altering the way in which the Institute of Aboriginal Studies is organised, the Minister believes that it would not be appropriate to proceed with those intended appointments. I commend both Bills to the Senate and I seek the support of honourable senators for their second reading.
Question put:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 17 August 1989 the Committee is considering the three Bills in the following order: the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill, and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill. The first Bill to be dealt with, therefore, is the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill. Is it the wish of the Committee that the Bill be taken as a whole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, before you put that question may I make a submission to the Committee? I would like the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill to be considered first by the Committee. I think it is with the agreement of Senator Peter Baume and Senator Coulter.

—That is contrary to the order of the Senate. I suppose we can do it by leave of the Committee. Is it the wish of the Committee that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill be taken as a whole? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

—I thank the Committee. I table the explanatory memoranda to the Bills, which relate to the proposed amendments and proposed new clauses to be moved on behalf of the Government to the Bills. They have already been circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 16, clause 50, lines 5 to 10, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Interim Council
``50. (1) This section applies in spite of anything in Part 5.
``(2) The persons who, immediately before the commencement, were members of the Council of the old Institute hold office as members of the Council of the new Institute during the transitional period.
``(3) Appointments of persons to the Council made under paragraphs 12 (1) (b) and (c) during the transitional period take effect at the end of the transitional period.

``(4) If, immediately after the transitional period, not all positions on the Council have been filled, then, until persons have been appointed to all positions on the Council, the quorum at a meeting of the Council is constituted by a majority of the number of members of the Council holding office on the day of the meeting.
``(5) In this section:
`transitional period' means the period starting at the commencement and ending:
(a) 3 months later; or
(b) when the results of the first elections held under paragraph 12 (1) (a) are declared;
whichever is earlier.''.
(2) Page 17, after clause 54 insert the following new clause:
Research Advisory Committee

``54a. (1) A member of the Research Advisory Committee appointed under paragraph 31 (1) (a) during the transitional period ceases to hold office as a member of the Research Advisory Committee at the end of the transitional period.

``(2) Until persons have been appointed or elected to all the positions on the Research Advisory Committee covered by paragraphs 31 (1) (a) and (b), the quorum at a meeting of the Research Advisory Committee is constituted by a majority of the number of members of the Research Advisory Committee holding office on the day of the meeting.
``(3) In this section:
`transitional period' has the same meaning as it has in section 50.''.
(3) Page 19, after clause 60 insert the following new clause:
Operation of Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act
``60a. (1) The Superannuation Act and any related law apply in relation to any person who:
(a) before the commencement was employed by the old Institute; and
(b) after the commencement, is employed under the Public Service Act 1922 in the new Institute;
as if:
(c) the person's employer was in each case the same body; and
(d) the continuity of the person's employment had not been affected by the abolition of the old Institute and the establishment of the new Institute.
``(2) in this section:
`related law' means any law of the Commonwealth, to the extent that it relates to the superannuation benefits covered by the Superannuation Act;
`Superannuation Act' means the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act 1988.''.

These amendments are required to streamline the arrangements which will apply in the transition from the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies established by this Bill. The ramifications of the changes to the staffing arrangements for superannuation entitlements are also dealt with in the proposed new clause. The explanatory memorandum, I think, indicates the very technical nature of the amendments proposed. Rather than bore the Committee by repeating the content of the explanatory memorandum, I commend the amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the three amendments which have been moved together by Senator Tate. However, we make one observation. The first piece of legislation in this package appeared before us in late 1987. I am not sure exactly when, but it is some considerable time ago. The Bill has appeared in at least three or four different forms since then. It was amended by the Government in the House of Representatives, under guillotine, some months ago. Yet here we are tonight-the first time we have considered the Bills in committee-considering Government amendments to each of the pieces of legislation. This bears out what many of our Aboriginal constituents have told us.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to go back and re-open the second reading debate because we have agreed to the principles of the legislation. The Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who talked to us said that they agreed to an idea in principle, but that they did not see or have a chance to agree to or consider in their communities the clauses of the legislation. The fact that amendments continue to appear from the Government at this late hour would seem to support their concern on this matter. They are just not certain whether this legislation in all its detail is what they want. Having said all that-and, I may make the same point again when we come to the Government amendments on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation-the Opposition will not oppose these amendments.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has circulated a proposed format for dealing with its amendments in groups. The first group proposed to be moved by the Opposition concerns the ATSIC Chief Executive Officer.

—It would shortcut a lot of debate tonight if Senator Baume were able to indicate which of the groups he intends to proceed with this evening on behalf of the Opposition and then, when I am clear as to which groups are left for pressing by the Opposition, I will be able to make a response.

—The difficulty that arose is that we originally had extra amendments. We decided not to move them all, but the amendments which have been circulated, now I have checked it through, are all amendments which we are moving. The ones which we removed in fact did not appear on the schedule. So you can proceed, Mr Chairman, confident that we will move all the amendments which you have before you on the schedule.

—I ought to advise the Committee that, having had some discussion with the Minister in relation to the amendments appearing in the form that Senator Baume has indicated, it is the intention of the Government to accept all the amendments to this particular Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, definition of ``Chief Executive Officer'', lines 11 and 12, leave out the definition.
(2) Pages 8 and 9, subclauses 23 (10) and (11), line 37 (page 8) line 3 (page 9), leave out the subclauses.
(3) Page 2, clause 3, definition of ``Commissioner'', line 17, leave out the definition.
(4) Page 5, subclause 12 (2), lines 17 and 18, leave out the subclause.
(5) Page 7, subclause 21 (3), lines 31 and 34, leave out the subclause.
(6) Page 8, subclause 23 (4), line 15, leave out ``including at least one Commissioner''.
(7) Page 10, subclauses 31 (2) and (3), lines 20 and 24, leave out the subclauses.
(8) Page 3, after subclause 6 (1), insert the following new subclause:

Money payable to the Institute

(11) Page 11, before clause 39, insert the following new clause in Part 10:
Certain information not to be disclosed

``(2) The Institute or the Council shall not disclose information or other matter held by it (including information or other matter covered by subsection (1)) if that disclosure would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.''.

Informing Minister and Commission about general conduct of Institute

I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) very much for the response, which I think is appropriate. The Government, I think, is acknowledging that the Opposition, having been defeated in its attempt to have the Bills defeated on the principles, has now proceeded to move some helpful amendments to the legislation. We have been genuinely concerned that only half the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, from which we have worked, were met in the Bill which we have before us. The amendments which we have moved now in fact will provide for some other necessary amendments to give to the Institute the separation and the independence which we believe it should have, in keeping with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee.

I do not intend, as I had wished originally, to argue each of the amendments in detail. The fact that the Government has determined to accept these amendments has given me great heart and it pleases the Opposition. I do want, however, to return to one matter. The Minister in his summing up was courteous enough to respond to my concerns about the failure to appoint certain commissioners to fill certain vacancies which have existed. I thought the Minister made a fair enough case as to why the Government did not intend to make those appointments now. I do not question that. What the Minister and the Government have not explained, is why the vacancies have been there for so long. I am informed that some of the Governor-General's vacancies in the Institute Council have existed since 1985. If that is the case, that would be almost four years that there have been vacancies in the Council which have awaited only action by a Minister putting a recommendation to the Executive Council for those appointments to be made. I do not question the explanation that was given to me by the Minister as to what the present problem is, but it does not explain why these vacancies have existed for so long. Would the Minister please let us know the reason for the length of time that there have been these vacancies?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will also not be objecting in any way to these amendments proposed by the Opposition. I would ask the Minister a further question, in a way related to the one asked by Senator Peter Baume: I understand that there were two senators on the Institute Board. Could the Minister indicate who they were and what their attendance record was in relation to meetings of the Institute Board? The only other point I want to make is to draw attention to what I see as the philosophy lying behind many of the Opposition amendments, that is to give effect to self-determination and self-management in a way in which some of the clauses in the Bill which have been deleted clearly denied. I want to make that point, because we will shortly be going on to discuss amendments in relation to the other Bill before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the membership of the Institute Board by senators, I believe Senator Collins and Senator Teague are the two senators who sit on that particular Board. I am unable, of course, to provide an attendance record. I could undertake to provide that from records held by the Institute, no doubt, but perhaps not before the conclusion of the consideration of this particular Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Peter Baume's question about seeking the reason for the failure of the Minister to fill certain vacancies on the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, the fact is, as I indicated, I believe that the Minister was prepared to fill a number of vacancies which had occurred over a period-I think from 1987, but the honourable senator may be right in relation to pointing to one vacancy from 1985; I have no information on that. I know that four of the Governor-General appointees' appointments did expire on 30 June 1987 and that another member resigned from the Council on 19 October 1987. The remaining member, Mr Michael Williams, resigned on 20 May 1988 to become an elected member of council. That is the sequence that I have, but the honourable senator may be right. That is the information I have.

The Minister, as I say, was willing to make some new appointments earlier this year. He was concerned to ensure that all those appointments could be put to the Governor-General without any shadow or unmerited cloud hanging over any of the persons to be appointed by reason of any of the inquiries being undertaken into matters relating to the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country, of which there were many going on at the time. I think, really, that is as much as I can properly say in relation to this matter, because quite clearly, without the names having been forwarded to the Governor-General, it would be wrong for me to name any particular person or persons in relation to the general point which I am making.
