In relation to the Government's position in accepting the amendments proposed by the Opposition to this particular Bill, I think it is important that I indicate that they are accepted as a token, I believe, of the good faith of the Government-naturally to maintain its own policy, which has now been accepted by the Senate in relation to the passage of the second reading. In those matters where some accommodation, some flexibility, can be shown, the Minister has been prepared to consider the amendments put forward in good faith and he has certainly demonstrated that in relation to his acceptance of these amendments. That does not mean that some of the comments made, if I may say so, in the second reading debate in relation to this Bill are accepted at all by the Government, in particular the thought that there was an attempt by the Government to enshrine a dominance and control by ATSIC over the Institute and its affairs. That is not accepted by the Government as a valid characterisation of what it was attempting to do in seeking a greater coordination and role to play in relation to the membership of the board by persons who are also members of the Commission.

I believe that we now have a situation where the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies will be able to operate in a way which ensures that its high reputation is maintained. The integrity of its research and its contribution to an understanding of the history and culture of the Aboriginal people will be furthered by those who supervise its work. I believe that the Senate can now look forward with confidence to giving a third reading to this Bill.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take very long. I advise the Committee that there will now be, as a consequence of the action we have just taken, a need to include a number of consequential amendments in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. I understand that those consequential amendments have been circulated. I indicate that when we get to the ATSIC Bill we will propose those consequential amendments which are now necessary to change certain words and syntax.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has, by leave, amended the sequence of the consideration directed by the Senate. Is it the wish of the Committee that the Committee now turn to the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, after subclause 13 (2), add the following new subclauses:
``(3) The Superannuation Act and any related law apply in relation to any person who:
(a) before the commencement, was employed by the Commission; and
(b) after the commencement, is employed under the Public Service Act 1922 in the Commission;
as if:
(c) the person's employer was in each case the same body; and
(d) the continuity of the person's employment had not been affected by the changes made by this Act to the staffing arrangements in respect of the Commission.
``(4) In subsection (3):
`related law' means any law of the Commonwealth, to the extent that it relates to the superannuation benefits covered by the Superannuation Act;
`Superannuation Act' means the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act 1988.''.
(2) Page 7, clause 15, proposed subsection 39a (3), line 37, after ``Minister'', insert ``for Finance''.

The first amendment is required to ensure that relatively small amounts of money which have accrued to staff under the 3 per cent productivity related superannuation agreement between the Government and the unions do not become payable because of the change in staffing arrangements which apply to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as a result of the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill. The Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act 1988 provides that an interim benefit is payable to staff in civilian public sector employment when there is a change of employer. This will occur as a result of the ADC Bill as staff of the ADC will become public servants. Accordingly, the amendment deems there not to have been a change of employer for the purpose of the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act 1988.

Amendment No. 2 simply clarifies that the reference to the Minister in clause 15 is in fact to the Minister for Finance. They are rather technical matters, but clearly the Government seeks the support of the Committee in relation to the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Bill, as amended, be agreed to. The Opposition has circulated amendments in six groups. With the concurrence of the Committee, I will allow the Opposition to move its amendments group by group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, paragraph 4 (a), lines 13 and 14, leave out ``on any matter specified by the Minister'', insert ``about the operations of the Commission or about this Act''.

The clause as it stands at lines 13 and 14 permits the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to seek information on any matters specified by the Minister. Let me draw a reduction ad absurdum. The Minister might want to seek information on what shopping someone did for their groceries the previous week. As the clause is drafted, the Minister would be permitted to seek that information. He could seek information on any matter. Our amendment does not seek to prevent the Minister from asking that information or from advice being provided. It merely seeks to say that that information should be information about the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) or about this Act. In other words, if I were now an officer of the Commission, the Minister would not be permitted to ask me about the activities of my nephew but he could ask me about activities relating to the Aboriginal Development Commission or about the Aboriginal Development Commission Act.

Our amendment will take nothing away from what the Government has sought to achieve with the drafting, but it is not desirable that the Minister's powers to obtain information from the ADC be unlimited. It is desirable that the Minister's powers in this matter be limited to matters known to the commissioners or staff in the course of their official duties under the Act. It is a perfectly reasonable amendment which in no way detracts from the purposes which the Government is seeking to obtain, but makes quite clear that the advice or information which is sought must be reasonable and relevant. I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting that Senator Baume prefaced his remarks by using the words `reduction ad absurdum'. I find his example somewhat absurd and somewhat extreme. However, I accept the argument he has put that the amendment fully indicates the intention of the Government. I would have thought that the words which are already in the clause imply exactly what he was saying. In a sense, I am somewhat neutral on the Opposition's amendment. I find it extremely unlikely that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs should seek to find out what somebody did in a shopping expedition or something like that. But I have no objection to the words which he chooses to put in. I accept that they do mean what I think is meant, or intended to be meant, by the words which he seeks to delete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Opposition's amendment has been moved in good faith out of an abundance of concern or some sort of caution that somehow a request could be made for information which is really outside the competence, legitimate capacity or ability of the Aboriginal Development Commission to provide to a Minister. However, I think it is perhaps going too far to try to read into this clause some hidden agenda on the part of a Minister to use the Commission to obtain information on matters which really fall outside its true jurisdiction and competence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government could probably accede to the amendment rather than have a division on it. However, it should be clearly understood that the powers and functions of the Commission, as set out in sections 8 and 9 of the Act, cover a tremendous range of matters. In that situation I would think that the ability of the Minister to request information relating only to the operation of the Commission or about the Act-the Act is, of course, much wider than even those clauses I have referred to relating to functions and powers-does give a very wide range of matters which the Minister could usefully seek information from the Commission on. Therefore, the Government will not oppose, if I can put it that way, this particular amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, first may I thank both the Government and the Australian Democrats. That amendment has been agreed to, but I say to Senator Coulter that we look at the words before us in the Bill and I am grateful to Senator Tate and to Senator Coulter for their support. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 2, clause 5, after proposed subsection 10a (3), add the following new subsection:
``(4) The Commission is not required to comply with any direction given by the Minister about the contents of the corporate plan.''.

We have put this amendment under the heading of `Corporate Plan'. It is an amendment to clause 5 on page 2 and we seek to add a new subsection to proposed section 10a. If one reads the proposed section 10a without our amendment, it leaves open the possibility that the Minister might be able to direct the Commission about the contents of its own corporate plan. Whether or not Ministers should direct a statutory body about its corporate plan is not really relevant. This is a very special statutory body. This is a proposal by a government that has made a lot about its belief in self-management. It would make a mockery of self-management as the ideal if it were possible for the government of the day to direct the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as to what should or should not be put into its own corporate plan.

I am not questioning the right of a government to issue ministerial directions. I am not questioning some of the other rights which a Minister has; but if we believe in self-management, then the writing of the corporate plan by the Commission should be something which is the Commission's duty, right and job, and no-one else's. So we have merely proposed to add certain words which would make that point quite clear. The corporate plan, when it is being drawn up, has to be drawn up consistent with the statutory base of the ADC. The commissioners have no right in drawing up the plan to go beyond that statutory base. They are limited by the statute; they always have been; they would be limited by the amended statute which emerges.

There have now been five Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs who have dealt with the Aboriginal Development Commission. No previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has found it necessary to put controls of this kind on the ADC. It is not proper that the corporate plan, whose limits are set by the statute anyhow, should be capable of being directed by the Minister. The Minister should adopt the corporate plan within those limits. The fact that things went wrong last year has nothing to do with this; it does not create the circumstance in which a Minister should now direct the ADC about the contents of its corporate plan. The reason things went wrong last year was because of a different set of problems. They are problems which we have discussed in extenso in this place. They have been the subject of a number of investigations and we believe that the addition of the new subclause (4) to proposed section 10a would make it quite clear that the Commission would do all the things which are proposed in the Act, as amended, after the passage of this Bill and after it receives royal assent. It would also make it quite clear that in drawing up the contents of the corporate plan provided for in section 10a, the Minister would not give a ministerial direction. I commend the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the amendment moved by my colleague, Senator Peter Baume. We have heard much over the past six or eight months about self-management and bringing the Aboriginals into a self-management plan. I feel that the Bill as it now stands, without our amendment, really deprives Aboriginal communities of that right to manage their own corporate plan, the right to lay down their particular needs as an Aboriginal community and the ability to make their business decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are-to use a colloquialism-fair dinkum about self-management, we have to let these Aboriginal departments and commissions have their own way and make their own plans. Sure, there are going to be mistakes made. The only reasons mistakes will never be made will be if people are never allowed the opportunity to make decisions. We all have to accept that in bringing a minority group to self-management there are going to be mistakes made. I think we all have to be patient and say, `Yes, that is on the cards and we have to accept that'. But to take people's rights away and say, `You really have not got the ability. You really have not got the experience. You really need someone in the Minister's office to tell you what to do', is really not self-management at all, and I hope Senator Tate can accept this amendment.

I know he realises that there have been mistakes made in the ADC and that that is going to happen again. Next year there will probably be a few less mistakes than there were the year before that and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, under Mr Hand's administration and this Government that does not really seem to be the case.
—I say to Senator Stone that we have to be a little patient with these Aboriginal people. They are going to make--
—I am quite patient with them. I am a bit impatient with Minister Hand, though.

—I do implore Senator Tate to accept this amendment because, really if we try to stifle Aboriginal self-determination and self-management at this stage we are going to put the Aboriginal communities into reverse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Opposition is really being overly nervous in this regard and reading far too much into the legislation to say that this particular clause somehow could counter the attempts to bring the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to that position of self-management which Senator Boswell certainly wishes to nurture and bring to fruition over a period of time. I think he is right in indicating that in coming to that situation-as with other members of the Australian community-mistakes will be made. But when honourable senators read the proposed clause 5-new section 10a-they will see that it is quite clear that the responsibility for the preparation of the corporate plan rests fairly and squarely on the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is to prepare the corporate plan in consultation with the Minister. It is not envisaged that the Minister could give directions; it is a simple matter of consultation. The clear statutory intention is that the responsibility, indeed the obligation, shall be on the Commission. It is mandatory for the Commission to prepare a corporate plan. That is evident from the use of the word `shall'. The full responsibility for that-quite rightly, and in the context of what the Government's policy attempts to achieve-is borne by the Commission in the various ways that were outlined in proposed new section 10a (1) (a), (b), (c) and (d). A review mechanism is also required of the Commission. Within that framework, the idea that the Minister could give a specific direction as to the content of the plan has no legal base within proposed section 10a and, as I say, it indicates that in trying to question how fair dinkum the Government is, the Opposition is perhaps reading too much into the proposed section that is just not there.

As Senator Peter Baume would know, because no doubt he operated with section 11 of the principal Act, the directions that can be given are general directions. I cannot believe that they would be of the kind that would dictate the content of the corporate plan, so I do not think there is any fear from the structure of the Act or the amending Bill that would lay a real basis for the amendment moved by the Opposition. Therefore, the Government will not accept the amendment. I reiterate that the Government's reason for not accepting the amendment is not that it is its intention to give a direction as to the specific contents of a corporate plan, but simply that we believe that on a fair reading of the Bill that will not occur anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, we are guided by the words that are before us. It is not a question of intent. We have to get the words as right as we can. As I say again, we understand that the second reading has been agreed to. We do not contest that now; our job is different. Our job is to examine the clauses and try to get the best we can from them.

SPEECH.PARA: I have before me a copy of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. Unless section 11 has been changed, a reading of section 11 suggests to me that the Minister could give such a general direction in relation to the contents of the corporate plan if a Minister so wished. Section 11 of the ADC Act has four subsections. Subsection (1) reads:
The Commission shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

I interpolate there that those general directions are unspecified; that is to say, we cannot say that in relation to an application for housing by Senator Boswell the Commission shall make this or that decision-that is not permitted-but a general direction is permitted. Sub-section (2) limits the Minister's power. It states:

Subsection (1) does not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice, information or recommendation that may be given by the Commission to a Minister, Department or authority of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.

It does not say that the Minister is not empowered to give directions relating to a plan drawn up by the Commission. It outlines certain things the Minister cannot do. The Parliament has seen fit in times past to limit the power of a Minister. That has happened from 1980 onwards. It is not as if the proposed amendment is in any way unusual. As we read section 11, we find the capacity of the Minister to issue general directions which we believe could encompass the situation which we are looking at now and we find certain limitations which do not include a limitation on the matters we are considering now. The last two subsections of section 11 relate to certain obligations upon the Minister: an obligation to acquaint the Parliament of directions given by the Minister and an obligation on the Minister not to disclose any matters held to be sacred by Aboriginals. I indicate that we are grateful that in the previous Bill the Committee considered the Government accepted our amendment in relation to the revealing of sacred material.

I come back to this amendment. The Minister's argument seems to have been that he thinks it is unnecessary. I ask the Minister a different question. I invite him to give to the Committee some reasons why we should not support the amendment. I think it is quite harmless. I cannot see any way in which it could cause difficulties or in which it could limit the proper actions by the Minister. If section 11 of the Act has the meaning which I think it has-unless there are subsequent amendments to section 11 of which I am not aware immediately-this is a proper amendment to seek to include in the Bill. I invite the Committee to read our amendment not only in association with proposed new section 10a, but also in relation to the existing section 11 which relates to ministerial directions under the ADC Act. I say to the Minister that I can see no harm in it. It is consistent with the limitations already placed on Ministers within section 11. I can see no downside whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a somewhat different position from that of both the Minister and Senator Peter Baume in that I think we need to recognise that the situation with this Bill is somewhat different from that which obtained throughout the life of the Aboriginal Development Commission. This legislation is to cover a transitional period. Therefore, I am not convinced by Senator Baume's argument that the previous Ministers had not found it necessary to issue such a direction. The period anticipated by this legislation is a period of transition in which the ADC as presently constituted will disappear and a new body will come into existence. I am rather surprised that proposed new section 10a (2) says that each corporate plan shall relate to a period of at least three years and not more than five years, because my understanding is that under this legislation the ADC will disappear long before three years have elapsed and certainly well before five years have done so. Therefore, I am surprised that Senator Baume has not sought to amend that section.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw Senator Baume's attention to an amendment which he intends to make to proposed section 39a (4). It reads:
The Commission shall comply with an approved Finance Direction even if it is inconsistent with the corporate plan.

It seems to me that, contrary to what the Minister said, in the transitional period in which the ADC is being wound down in preparation for another body taking over, it may well be necessary for the Government, through the Minister, and the Commission, to work quite closely together. I am therefore a little concerned and I am minded not to support the Opposition's amendment because it would be unwise to constrain the process by which that winding down should occur and that may indeed involve some more specific cooperation between the Minister and the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that the Opposition has moved is to add after the words, `the Commission shall, in consultation with the Minister, review the corporate plan regularly', the following new subsection:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is not required to comply with any direction given by the Minister about the contents of the corporate plan.

Senator Coulter presents an argument to the Committee that this legislation will be defunct in a matter of time. That may be the case, but the facts are that we have no crystal ball and we do not know what is going to happen in the future. We are debating the legislation before us at the moment. I believe that the amendment that we are asking the Committee to carry takes away any contention that the Minister, whether in consultation, by direction or in any other way, can interfere with the corporate plan. The amendment gives to the ADC the right to manage its own corporate plan. I do not think there is anything wrong with our amendment.

One thing about the debate that has raged over the past eight months is that both sides of the Parliament and the Democrats are in agreement that self-management, self-determination, is the right way to go for the Aboriginal and Islander people. There is no argument between us. There is an argument as to how we reach the goal. The amendment that we are now asking the Committee to carry is going to make that goal so much easier. It is going to take away any fear, if I can put it in those terms, that the Minister might be able to interfere with the corporate plan. I ask Senator Coulter whether he would give further consideration to supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would similarly like to ask the Democrats to seriously consider the difference between a corporate plan that has been properly developed and constructed by the Aboriginal members of the Commission and a finance direction, which is a matter determined by the Minister and a matter of accountability for the Government. Because the Minister may have to impose, because of Government finance direction reasons, a specific finance direction, there is a very different point of policy and principle involved. Like Senator Boswell, I would invite Senator Coulter to consider the very deliberateness in the amendment, particularly as the corporate plan itself is to be prepared by the Aboriginal members of the Commission, whereas the finance direction is a parliamentary function.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just answer that point. Senator Baume has made great play, and correctly, of the proposition that we should look at the words. The words which he chooses to attempt to introduce are:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is not required to comply with any direction given by the Minister about the contents of the corporate plan.

It seems to me that Senator Tambling would have us introduce a clause which is inconsistent with a clause which he will later try to introduce. Let us be careful of the words, as Senator Peter Baume has warned us to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, we might be able to vote on this before 10.30 p.m., so can I simply say that I am resisting so vehemently this particular Opposition amendment because it appears to say of the Minister-and people are being quite personal-that he is the sort of person who would give a directive.
—Yes. Of course, he is.

—I thought Senator Stone might say that. In fact, of course, as I have indicated, that is not the case and there is some evidence that it is not the case. Senator Baume quite rightly looked to section 11 of the principal Act, which empowers the Minister to give general directions, in writing, which, of course, must be tabled in the Parliament and therefore are subject to full scrutiny. I do not know whether he dwelt enough on subsection (2), which indicates that the Minister is not to give directions relating to the content of any advice, recommendation or information that may be given by the Commission to a Minister, department or authority of the Commonwealth or of a State or a Territory. I do not want to make an argument, because I am not absolutely sure, that a corporate plan would fall within the definition, of `advice, information or recommendation given by the Commission to a Minister'. If it did, then quite clearly the Minister could not give a direction as to its content.
—Is it not an internal document?

—If it were that clear, I would make a stronger argument, but I am prepared to simply say that it is in the spirit of 11 (2), given the structure of proposed new subsection 10a which puts the responsibility for the formation of the corporate plan's preparation squarely on the Commission, that we confidently say that the Minister is not about to give the specific directions as to content which are feared apparently by the Opposition. Indeed, I might just read the Aboriginal Development Commission Act directions under section 11, already tabled in this Parliament, in relation to the corporate plan:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission shall provide to the Minister a copy of the corporate plan endorsed by the Commission and shall consider making any amendments to the corporate plan that are, within a reasonable period of time, provided to the Commission by the Minister. The Commission shall, before making any variations to the corporate plan endorsed by the Commission, in so far as the plan relates to the performance of the Commission's functions or the exercise of its powers, request the Minister's views on the proposed variations and take into account any views that are, within a reasonable period of time, provided to the Commission by the Minister.

Quite clearly, what is there set out is not a direction. What is provided for is the capacity of the Commission to take into account any views that are forwarded by the Minister. That would be the spirit, I am sure, which lies behind the drafting of new subsection 10a, which speaks of the Commission taking responsibility, being required to prepare the corporate plan, in consultation with the Minister-but merely in consultation-and not subject to the direction of the Minister. The fact is that the Government, as I say, resists this amendment because of the inference that lies behind much of the debate on it from the Opposition side. It is not the intention of the Government to direct the content of the corporate plan, but that would become evident, even if this amendment were carried. We could live with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for what he has just read out, which I take it is the directions the Minister is going to give in relation to the corporate plan.
—Has given.

—That is reassuring. But there are several problems. First of all, that could be superseded at any time by a different direction. While a capacity exists here, and if someone could say that the Parliament refused to agree to an amendment such as the one we have moved, the Minister could easily change that direction, if he so wished. Any Minister could. I am not mounting an ad hominem argument at this moment against this Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
—Why not?

—Because it is not necessary at this moment. There are two other matters that arise out of what has been said. The first thing that I put to Senator Coulter is that he has made a very telling point, I think, in suggesting that I was at fault in not saying a `general' direction in the amendment. If Senator Coulter wished to suggest to us that we should seek leave to vary our amendments by adding the word `general' to make it clear that we are restricting ourselves in the amendment to the Minister's capacity to give general directions-that is, section 11 directions, as they are known around the portfolio-I would like him to indicate that to us.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

DEBATE.TITLE: ADJOURNMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Cedric Wyatt-Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme-Environment-World War Memorial Fund-Very Fast Train Project-Northern Territory Politicians: Pay Claim

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that I am the first speaker in a long adjournment debate, so I shall be brief. I refer to a comment which I made in a speech in this place on 9 March 1988 and which stimulated a response from the member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, on 29 May 1989, when Mr Campbell in an adjournment speech said that he knew Mr Cedric Wyatt. Mr Campbell said, referring to Mr Wyatt:

SPEECH.PARA: Until recently he was the Director of Aboriginal Affairs in Western Australia.
Mr Campbell made some kind comments about him and continued:

. . . It was most disappointing to hear him attacked by Senator Crichton-Browne during a Senate inquiry. I took up this matter with Senator Crichton-Browne who, I think, now concedes that he might have been a little intemperate.
While the language may have been persuasive, I resile from nothing which I said then and, so that there is some continuity, I place on the record what I said on 9 March:

. . . It is not without significance to note that in Western Australia, when we had this absolute imbroglio, confusion, chaos, incompetence and, in some cases, corruption, the department head was Cedric Wyatt, who for his sins was promoted by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, to the position of General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). At a time of apparent crisis in the ADC, when new, competent and efficient management was needed, it got a personally hand-picked appointment who had reigned over the Department in Western Australia, which the Auditor-General referred to in the report in a most scathing way. I put it down as nothing higher than gross inefficiency and incompetence. It certainly reflects on the Minister's judgment in his choice of people. It indicates to me that he is concerned more about the politics of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs than he is about the Aboriginals involved and the assurance that they receive the funds which are allocated by the Department.

I stand by those words. They have since been vindicated by a number of internal inquiries in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. As I say, Mr Campbell was suggesting, as a result of a conversation with me, that he thought he had learned that I had changed my mind. Of course I have not and what I said on that occasion still stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention to the decision by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to slash dispensing fees for pharmacists by 23 per cent. This action is to be deplored. In fact, the entire viability of the pharmaceutical industry is now at stake. We have a Tribunal which has shown that it is clearly out of touch with reality. I believe that the current Tribunal should be recalled and be told by the Labor Government that its decision is detrimental to the community and also to the industry. This Government has the power to recall the Tribunal and to advise it on this matter. The Government should go one step further and should replace the present members with people who have a greater understanding and a greater depth of knowledge of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of this present Tribunal have no special expertise in the area of health care. That is absolutely disgraceful. Not one member is a pharmacist or has any dealings with the pharmacy industry. Appointees to the Tribunal should be people who have expertise in the pharmacy or related professions. It is not as if such people are not available. According to Mr Peter Ware, President of the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, there are a number of combined pharmacists and barristers or pharmacists and accountants who are available. A senior member of the Small Business Development Corporation is a combined pharmacist and accountant. Yet not one member of the present Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal has in the past had any pharmaceutical background or even connection with the pharmaceutical industry. We have to look at that in light of the Tribunal's judgments which will have drastic effects upon the income of many pharmacists. It is no good for the Government to say that it is an independent Tribunal. It is no use having an independent Tribunal if that Tribunal is made up of incompetent people who lack knowledge and background of the industry. It is no wonder that the Tribunal is coming up with such stupid decisions.

The pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) prescription fee will no longer be related to or made up based on the cost of goods sold. It will only be a fixed fee related, firstly, to labour costs, and secondly, to non-labour costs. A fixed fee of $3.50 will now apply.

It is interesting that the comparison on which the Tribunal based its salary cost for pharmacists was right out of line with the amount the Government pays pharmacists in public hospitals. Meanwhile, the pharmacists who are in business have had to fund salary increases-usually on a percentage-and a 3 per cent superannuation award. This mark-up is especially worrying as pharmacists will no longer be able to afford to have a holding stock.

What could eventuate is that a prescription will be given to the pharmacists on one day and it will be sent to the wholesaler who will supply it and, in all probability, it will be dispensed the next day, at the earliest. So we will have a delayed problem so far as the patient is concerned. What about the aged who will have to come in the next day-another bus trip, another taxi fare, just to pick up the prescription? This may be the situation for the common, every day prescription and it will almost definitely be the case for the rarer prescription. The health care of the individual, particularly the elderly, therefore is very much at stake.

The Pharmaceutical Society of Tasmania noted an anomaly that exists: the proposed Tribunal charges will add to the hardship. The majority of wholesalers are already charging 3 per cent higher wholesale prices than recommended by the Federal Government, but the Government does not take into account the wholesaler's price; it takes into account the recommended price in payments to pharmacies, which is a difference. The pharmacist's margin is continually being whittled away.

The Pharmaceutical Society estimates that up to one-third of Australian pharmacists could go out of business. That is over 1,000 people, all small businessmen. This is part of the Government's attack on small business. The average pharmacy could lose $26,000 a year because of the cuts; that is, a small pharmacy would lose $500 income a week at a minimum. Larger businesses could lose $100,000 annually. At the same time, these same people have to fund heavy overdrafts with high interest rates to carry on their business because of the high overheads which they have to sustain. As I have mentioned on previous occasions, there are approximately 5,200 pharmacies in Australia. They are not only a major component of the small business sector but also a major employer of women. It is worth reminding the Government that 60 per cent of pharmacists and 99 per cent of pharmacy assistants are women.

TALK.START.PARA: —And most of their customers are women, too.

—That is right. I think it is appropriate at this stage that I should comment that I have a vested interest in this matter because my wife is a salaried pharmacist on a part time basis. Certainly these pharmacists, including my wife, will remember the Government's action when they next vote. Many pharmacists are already struggling as a result of the previous Federal Government's move and this latest blow will send many to the wall. With this proposed loss of income many pharmacists will find it easier just to close their doors. Those pharmacies that do remain will have to substantially restructure and curtail their costs. This can only be done through reducing staffing levels and also reducing stock levels. It is feared that many pharmacies will no longer be able to keep stocks of rarely used medicines. Again, this will detrimentally affect the elderly.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be pointed out that the Federal Government estimates it will save $20m by implementing its decision but I think every reasonable person who has looked at this so-called $20m saving must query its validity. So if over 1,000 pharmacies go out of business it means that in practical terms 1,000 businessmen who usually provide an income for possibly two or three people or more will have to find other jobs in a difficult market, adding, perhaps, to unemployment and other costs. People can no longer save or spend the same amount of money as previously.

The effect will be multiplied through the community. Studies are being conducted as to the multiplying effect of the loss of jobs in one industry in relation to the loss of jobs in other industries. For example, in the mining industry in the early part of this decade it was estimated that for every one job lost, four were lost in the related industries of transport, construction or manufacturing.

The point that I am making is that if the Government is going to close 1,000 pharmacies it is going to have a downstream multiplier effect greater than that across the economy. The situation is such that in the pharmacy industry we will see a practical out-working of the economy of this country if the decisions of the Tribunal are carried out. There will be a substantial loss of jobs and it will be detrimental to health care. The unfortunate fact is that many of the pharmacies forced to close their doors will be the very ones offering the most needed service. I refer to the pharmacies in the small towns and in isolated areas.

The Tribunal has not considered the cost to the community of the widespread pharmacy closures in these areas. The local pharmacist is often called upon to dispense free on-the-spot advice and because he or she is a health care expert the pharmacist can dispense that advice. Pharmacies continuing to operate will, of necessity, need to make staff cuts. There will no longer be room for on the spot advice in the larger urban areas. In those areas where the pharmacy has closed no such pharmaceutical advice will be available. In other words, the Tribunal's decision will set us on a path towards the lowest common denominator level of pharmacy practice in Australia.

People will go to the doctors and there will be greater cost to Medicare and to the nation. They will seek advice through a more expensive medium-through the doctors and not through the pharmacists. This will cause greater costs through wasted drugs, diseases caused by incorrect self-diagnosis or unnecessary demands on other parts of the health system. The Government just has not thought through the consequences. We have heard of unintended consequences resulting from tax decisions. We are going to have a lot of unintended consequences if this Tribunal's decision is carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to socialise medicine.

—As I mentioned, a visit to the doctor could now be necessary if there is no pharmacist in the local area-a much greater expense than to chat to your friendly pharmacist for no fee. Preventive medicine will not be practised to the same extent that it is practised at the present time. Expensive hospitalisation as well as lost productivity and unnecessary human suffering will be the result. The findings of the Tribunal talk about a special rate for pharmacies that may not be economically viable but are essential as contemplated under the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The response to that is that Mr Peter Ware of the Australian Pharmaceutical Society feels that in country areas the supply of medicines outside normal business hours could well be jeopardised. The essential pharmacy allowance will not necessarily cover the costs involved. Many country hospitals throughout Australia do not have their own pharmacies. They rely on the local pharmacist to supply their medicines. The special rate here need not apply. Thus some country pharmacies may not even be able to obtain the special rate. Even so, the special payment of 35c an item on the first 1,000 prescriptions each month will do little to compensate for the much after hours activity that is often required by a country pharmacy practice. Quite often the pharmacist has to pay for the cost to put the particular prescription on a bus to go out to an isolated area. Overall the Tribunal's findings are a catastrophe for the community and for pharmacies.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about aged people on pensions?

—I have already covered those. It is going to be quite detrimental to the aged, particularly if they live in country areas. So the decision has been based on flawed information, on limited terms of reference and with little knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier I referred to the Tribunal's lack of expertise, lack of background knowledge and experience in the industry. Even honourable senators on the other side of this chamber are expressing concern about the decision but presently they have been muzzled. I believe that the Minister has to head off a back bench revolt. Indeed, he has to head off a community revolt on this issue. The Government is becoming oblivious to the concerns within the community. It is becoming blind. It is like the ostrich. The Opposition knows that because people are suffering, businesses are suffering. But the Government is becoming blind to the consequences of its actions over such a wide spectrum nowadays.

I still say that the Government should heed the warnings sounded by its own backbenchers. For example, neither this uncaring Labor Government nor the Tribunal has recognised the productivity improvements of pharmacists as a result of computerisation. The promises by government on issues such as quick payment are, for some pharmacists, honoured more in the breach than in the observance. The only recourse is to recall the Tribunal and to admit the Government's grave concern about the decision handed down. The Tribunal should then be advised to reconsider its findings in the light of the present reaction of the community and the pharmacy industry. Not only should that decision preferably be overruled but also the Tribunal should have placed on it competent employees. It will be too late to correct the effects of these findings if we wait too much longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I commence my brief remarks this evening simply by saying how much I endorse the comments made by my colleague Senator Watson and indicate that I have no doubt that during the course of the next week or so this will be a matter of very lively debate.
—That is not what you told me about him.

—It is precisely what I told Senator Bolkus about him and if I promise to do nothing but tell the truth about my own back bench colleagues I will test Senator Bolkus's capacity to do likewise. The point which I wish to raise this evening, Mr President, is simply to indicate that on 19 August the Liberal and National parties conducted a seminar on a series of questions involving the reconciliation of the tensions which frequently exist between the need for economic development and environment protection. That seminar was held at the technical and further education college at Box Hill in the electorate of Chisholm, arranged in part by Dr Mike Wooldridge, the honourable member for Chisholm. It was a particularly successful undertaking. At that seminar a number of important papers were given and apart from a major speech by the Hon. Andrew Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, entitled `Millennia Milestones' and one by Mr Bruce Lloyd, the shadow Minister for primary industry, entitled `Sustainable Agriculture', papers were sought from outside experts.

SPEECH.PARA: Papers were presented by Dr Keith Boardman, the Chief Executive of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation; Dr Judy Lambert, one of the campaign officers of the Wilderness Society; Mr Phillip Toyne, the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation; Mr D. R. O'Neill, the Assistant Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council; and Mr Rick Farley, the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation. Those papers, and the two speeches to which I have referred, are very significant contributions to the environment debate and I believe it would be useful for honourable senators to have access to them. Therefore, Mr President, having shown them previously to Senator Bolkus I simply seek leave to table them this evening.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the fiftieth anniversary of the commencement of World War II being remembered this weekend, I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to the work of a friend and constituent of mine who is at present representing Australia in Paris. The Reverend John Fincher, from Quirindi, who is still an active priest in the Anglican church in my local town and a local shire councillor, was an airman serving in the Royal Australian Air Force in England during World War II and he actually survived a crash in a Lancaster during that war. He has worked extraordinarily hard for a number of years to establish the World War Memorial Fund. This is a fund conceived as a living memorial to the victims of world war and to future victims of natural disaster, be it flood, famine, bushfire, storms, droughts or earthquakes. The fund was initiated by Group Captain Leonard Cheshire, another extraordinary man who was actually in this place on the night before the last Anzac Day celebrations in Australia. It was the belief of these two men that this year, the anniversary year of the outbreak of World War II, would be an appropriate time to establish such a fund.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall Reverend Fincher bringing this idea to me quite some time ago and I am pleased that he has achieved his goal in engaging interest in its establishment in Australia. Indeed, the Australian patrons of the fund are the leaders of the four major political parties, and I think that says a great deal for those people. Reverend Fincher is currently in Paris planning the appeal on a world basis. The countries being represented at these talks include the United States of America, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, West Germany, Japan, Canada, India and Italy. It is also intended that the group will meet with the Secretary-General of the United Nations, General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

The World Memorial Fund for Disaster Relief appeal will run from tomorrow, 1 September, for a period of six years-equal in length to the Second World War. It seeks to raise $10 for each life lost in war in this century. Over 80 million people have been lost this century, both civilians and military. The date of 1 September was chosen as it was the date on which the Germans invaded Poland, although Britain and France did not declare war until 3 September 1939. The capital collected for the fund will be invested in the country in which it is raised. Decisions on allocations for disasters from the accrued interest will be made by the Secretary-General of the United Nations.

The whistle used in the trenches in World War I to send men over the top will be the fund's symbol. They are now used to summon help and this emphasises the central objective of the appeal. It is hoped that on 1 September, which is tomorrow, people will blow whistles for this very good appeal. The central objective of the fund will be that for every life lost a life will be saved. Tonight I would like to urge all honourable senators and, indeed, every Australian to contribute to this most worthy appeal. I pay tribute to the fortitude and compassion of people like Reverend John Fincher, who have committed so much of their lives to establishing this fund, and getting a reconciliation of all the people who fought in the wars. I am confident the fund will be an international success and provide much needed emergency relief in years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate some aspects of the very fast train (VFT) project that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Richardson seem to have wilfully ignored in their recent advocacy. I say `wilfully ignored' because they rejected the advice of the large majority of the members of the study group they set up to advise them. I notice with some gratification that, according to the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 August 1989, this select group of public servants from a number of departments arrived at many of the same conclusions that I did after reading the VFT concept report. I presented my observations on the project to a group of concerned citizens at Bowral on 7 July this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been claimed for the very fast train. It will be very fast, fuel efficient and weather resistant. It will go to exciting places like Canberra and the snowfields. Fares will be cheaper than those of the airlines, the system will be privately funded and will return a profit. Jobs will be created in construction, maintenance and operation of the system and it will interface well with existing systems. Unfortunately, this is not true. The very fast train is a silly and untimely project. It promises to be a practical and financial embarrassment if it is put into effect. If one still possesses the innocence to wonder whether four large companies, the New South Wales Government and now the Federal Government could propose and support a scheme that will fail to met the technical standards necessary to yield a profit, the answer is yes, they could, and would. Examples of such silliness abound.

Some time ago I saw a program called Beyond 2000 which dealt with a massive hydro-electric scheme on the border of Czechoslovakia and Hungary. Those countries are going to dam the Danube at enormous expense and with environmental effects that will seriously damage agriculture and degrade water supplies in the region. They borrowed money from Austria to finance the project and nearly all of the first 20 years of electricity production will go to Austria to pay off the loan. It is a real fizzer, but they are in too far to stop. The World Bank--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, with the greatest respect, I seek to raise a point of order. It goes to the question of the speech that the honourable senator is making, canvassing the issues of the very fast train project. Now that this matter is before a committee of the Senate, by resolution of 17= August, when it was referred to the Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee for its examination and report, I wonder whether the canvassing of such a matter is entirely in accordance with the provisions of the Standing Orders.
—I must rule according to the Standing Orders. This is not anticipating debate, and I will let Senator Dunn continue.
—You are at a loss for words.

—No, I am not. The World Bank finances hydro-electric schemes in the Amazon which inundate vast areas of forest, drive out the inhabitants and clog up with weeds and silt shortly after producing the first watt of electrical power. In the case of the VFT I believe that the companies involved know what they are doing and the Federal and State governments are the bunnies, or rather, as always, we are the bunnies, who will have to pay the real costs of this extravagant project.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an article titled `Why the VFT Project Won't Work' by John Nestor. John Nestor is a former passenger business manager with the New South Wales State Rail Authority (SRA). He provides an excellent summary of many of the problems with the project and demonstrates that it cannot possibly pay its way. However, at the end he suggests that the consortium should have the freedom to go ahead with the project on the clear understanding that there should be no government bail-out if there are difficulties. I believe that this would be a serious mistake.

Imagine this situation three years into the project: land has been resumed, mountains levelled, a great swathe has been cut through the landscape from Sydney to Melbourne and perhaps one rail and some fences have been installed. Most of the $4.8 billion has already been spent. The companies in the consortium are crying poor because of unexpected cost overruns, union problems, the state of the economy and so on. Meanwhile, the public will have been bombarded with skillfully made television advertisements along the lines of `The quiet, big over achiever'; `Into the 21st century', `Australians working for a better Australia'. Stirring stuff! The 25,000 workers employed on the project are about to be thrown out of work. Interest rates have risen to 21 per cent. It seems that the rest of us will never have the pleasure of riding on the new toy. National pride will be involved.

Which government could afford to let the project die? Some formula would be found and the Government would accept an invitation to invest in the project, or some complicated loan formula would be found to hide the direct cost to the community. When the system goes into operation there will be teething problems, requiring more public money. After the novelty has worn off it will be found that the system is not attracting enough custom, it is too slow, with high fares, and more government-sourced money will be needed to try to build up patronage. If we have not achieved full banana republic status by this stage, the VFT should be enough to tip us over the edge. The time to stop the project is now. Governments are already being sucked into the project by their collusion in the land resumption program.

Let us look at some of the problems of this project in more detail. The consortium obviously strongly favours the Snowy-Gippsland route, which would traverse the Murrumbidgee Valley and the East Gippsland region, where a swathe 250 metres wide would have to be cut out to allow for the safe passage of the train. This loss of trees will have to go into the debit side of the ledger when we count Mr Hawke's billion trees. The impact on flora and fauna cannot be assessed without a proper study, although the fences alone could have a major effect on some animal species. The fences and the masts for the high-tension power lines will certainly degrade the aesthetic quality of the wilderness areas. Farmers are also concerned about the effects of the herbicides that will have to be sprayed regularly along the track corridor.

Let us assume for a moment that the VFT goes ahead and captures the projected market share. I suspect that the noise will be really impressive. If the VFT goes through one's backyard 70 times a day, one will be able to visit suburbs under the Mascot flight path for a quiet holiday, except at the present moment. The Japanese have tried to silence their much slower trains without much success. This may limit the utility of farming land close to the lines and presents a strong argument for using as much of the existing rail corridor for faster train services rather than cutting across country.

On the other hand, there will be relative silence along the SRA lines in New South Wales, with at least a massive reduction in existing passenger services. This will certainly lead to a loss of jobs in State rail services-more, it has been suggested, than will be offered by the VFT. I have no particular brief for the SRA, as it exists now. Generations of mismanagement and the intransigence of the unions have run the system down. This has been aided by the de facto subsidising of long-distance road freight, which ought to be uncompetitive with a properly run rail freight system. Taxes and other imposts on all of us repair the massive damage to the roads caused by heavily-laden trucks.

On tonight's news we saw yet another semi-trailer accident on the Hume Highway. It cost three lives. Fatal accidents involving the semi-trailers that run parallel to our rail systems have been much in the news and the response of the New South Wales Government was to institute a revenue-earning police program called `big brother'. I do not think it fully appreciated the irony of the title, which illustrates the tendency of all our governments to react to problems with repressive rather than constructive action. Not only would action to revive rail freight conserve fuel and help with our balance of payments problems; it would also make a small contribution to our global environmental problems by reducing our net carbon dioxide contribution to the atmosphere.

One of the first questions that come to mind with the VFT is: Will it work? I found this answered in the VFT concept report: `No, it won't'. The projected timetables are impressive, but the very high speeds cited are not the result of technical analysis of existing high-speed rail systems and informed projections. Instead, they are a product of the need to compete directly with aeroplanes travelling at over 900 kilometres per hour. Allowing market analysts to design a high-speed rail system is on a par with asking a barber to fix the brakes on one's car.

John Nestor described the timetable claims as akin to East-West Airlines telling us that its engineers were going to develop an aircraft 30 per cent faster than Concorde by 1995. Developing a train that could run routinely at 350 kilometres an hour would involve solving a number of problems that have been scarcely touched in the official report, including adhesion, wear and power pick-up problems. There would also be considerably larger stresses on the motors and power transmission than exist in the painfully developed overseas systems.

Adding to the air of unreality is the amazing versatility of the new train. It will simultaneously travel at express speed to match the airlines but also provide a regular service for regional centres and aid the decentralisation of Sydney and Melbourne by providing regular commuter services from places like Bowral. Apparently it can stop on a pin with its triple braking system and accelerate like a jet fighter.

There is talk of developing this technology here and of the value of the technological spin-offs to local industry. The dollar signs have gone up in the eyes of interested parties and they are saying what a terrific idea the VFT is. However, I doubt that there will be much local development. With a timescale of only five years, we are most likely to see the slower Japanese bullet trains on the tracks, although they may be painted green and gold. Even if there is some local development it is unlikely to generate significant export potential. If this project goes ahead it will almost certainly prove that the practical limit of wheel on rail systems is under 300 kilometres per hour.

Several authors of articles on the VFT have cast a cold eye over the financial claims made by the consortium. I mentioned John Nestor earlier. Nestor deals with some of the technical improbabilities and goes on to estimate expected returns on the considerable investment required for the VFT. Accepting the consortium's claims for market share and making generous assumptions about a very low interest rate, even a very cursory calculation reveals that the VFT could not possibly pay its way with the proposed fare structure.

Interestingly, the VFT concept report practically concedes that the project is not viable. In section 2.5.4 titled `VFT Finances' it concedes that `accounting losses would be incurred for several years of operation'. Note the use of `accounting' to minimise the fact that the losses would be real and require what the report calls `structuring', which, as far as I can tell from my position of financial naivety, just means that a lot more money would have to be fed into the system. The claims that the use of the route for pipelines and communications would earn significant revenue are unsubstantiated and it is hard to see the Gippsland route offering a useful and economic pipeline for any product. Natural gas pipelines from the Bass Strait fields already exist for much of the distance, and they are closer to the existing rail route. We should also take note of the recent catastrophic accident in the USSR, where a pipeline running beside a railway ruptured and caused great loss of life.

A more interesting reference under `VFT Finances' is the claim that `real estate value capture' could `contribute to the financing of the project'. What does this mean? Is the project as much concerned with property speculation as transport? Will the consortium seek special treatment from governments for its land acquisition program and development applications by arguing that the project will fail unless they can make profits in this area? It seems very likely. At the end of the very short and sketchy section on finance the report says that it `may be open to governments to invest in the VFT'. May be open? It will be an offer that they cannot refuse.

There are several other troubling features of the economics of the project. Are the companies involved going to use the `accounting losses' for tax loss purposes? What is the role of the financial engineering company Kumagai-Gumi? This company has a very interesting record of being able to entangle Australian governments in its construction programs. There is the Sydney Harbour tunnel. Notice that Kumagai prefers not to enter into open tenders. There is the Victorian central development project, where Kumagai has managed to get the terms of its contract changed in its favour, although critics argue that the project should be put out to tender again. There is the Adelaide station environs redevelopment, where special legislation was passed to bypass local planning and building controls. I suspect that we will see a lot more of this in the future if the VFT goes ahead. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate my copious notes in Hansard, as there is restlessness in the chamber. I would be quite happy to do so with the consent of those present.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Kumagai Gumi obviously has ready access to the almost embarrassing surplus of cash in the Japanese financial system. They will be willing to forgo profits for the sake of entry to the local market. They can afford to take the long view and their ambitions may have little to do with providing an economically viable fast train service. The Australian companies also have an incentive to cuddle up to Kumagai because of possible cooperative ventures in the future with this wealthy international company.

Although the concept report is sketchy on details of finance it does dedicate some space to a philosophical explanation of the difference between ``bad'' foreign debt and ``good'' foreign debt. Apparently the finance for the VFT will be good foreign debt, despite the fact that this massive investment will produce no balance of payments benefits except perhaps a slight increase in tourism revenues and perhaps a reduction in outlays for imported fuels.

If Australia is to run up a 4.8 billion dollar debt it ought to be invested in projects that will enhance our export earnings, not in a flashy people mover that will grow at the expense of existing transport systems. But will it displace other transport systems? It seems naive to suppose that the airlines would lie down and let the VFT run all over them. And will Australians suddenly alter their car-driving habits just because the VFT is available? The report makes the somewhat ingenuous suggestion that the State rail systems could benefit from the VFT by taking the cars of VFT travellers interstate. With the current state of the SRA, for instance, travellers would be lucky to get their cars within a week and this program would surely be totally uneconomic. Australians drive their cars so much partly because of the woeful inadequacy of public transport systems and the lack of this infrastructure makes the VFT itself much less attractive.

I find the market survey presented by the consortium unconvincing even discounting the technical problems presented by the system's manifest inability to compete with the airlines on travel time. Initial data was provided by a survey conducted by Macquarie University, extra data was injected and the package was sent off for analysis by three bodies overseas. The vast difference between the proposed Australian setting and the densely populated areas where high speed trains run successfully makes me doubt the validity of the market study.
Social Dislocation and Land Resumption

If a large percentage of passenger travel through South-East Australia is shifted to the Canberra-Gippsland route there will be considerable social dislocation, both in the areas from which travellers have been diverted and in the new growth centres around the proposed line and its stations. I have already mentioned the apparent intention of the consortium to enter into real estate speculation and development-probably on a preferential basis. Others will no doubt want to get into the action. Like the shift away from existing transport systems, the speculation and development will offer little real net benefit. A few will benefit-as they have in the over-heated Sydney real estate market-but many will be disadvantaged.

Land resumption will be closely associated with this. Not only will the land necessary for the track corridor need to be resumed, but there will be extra areas for stations, shunting yards, power transformers and no doubt whatever ancillary services that the consortium deems necessary for the proper operation of the service. We may well see government legislation allowing the consortium a liberal interpretation of what is necessary, allowing them to resume land at bargain basement prices and either develop it themselves or lease or sell it later at a considerable profit.

There will be considerable inequity associated with land resumption and development along the VFT route. A landowner whose property is bisected by the track will lose ready access to parts of his or her own land, will be assaulted 70 times a day by the horrendous noise of the lowflying VFT and will have to put up with a vista of unsightly fences and high-voltage power gantries-losses well in excess of any likely compensation.

A neighbour who lives over the hill may be able to make a killing by developing a tourist hotel or a high-density town-house development for displaced city dwellers. Rates and the general cost-of-living would be sure to rise. All of this could result in a degradation of community cohesion.

With so much at stake and the exact route uncertain there may well be a temptation for some people with a bit of loose change on hand to resort to a bit of brown paper bag and used banknote negotiation to have the track re-routed to a more convenient alignment.
The Canberra Connection

It does not surprise me that this idea had its genesis in Canberra and that Canberra has been suggested as a suitable location for the VFT headquarters. Absurd concepts emerge and prosper in this rarified atmosphere. One of the strong arguments for the VFT is the inconvenience and inefficiency of air-travel from Sydney to the under-equipped and often fog-bound Canberra airport. First let me assure you that the nation is not going to collapse in a heap if a few politicians and public servants fail to turn up on time.

On the other hand, it is also argued that Canberra airport could be expanded to international standard, when it would serve also as Sydney's second airport. Travellers could take the VFT to Sydney which would be only an hour away-or so it is claimed. There are also vague claims about massive developments in Canberra based on access via the VFT, although looking at a map it's hard know quite where they will be put. The arguments about Canberra would seem to work both ways for the VFT.
There is an argument for an improved rail service to Canberra, but it does not support the VFT, which proposes totally unrealistic transit times through the suburban sprawl of Sydney.
There is also a good argument for the fast freight service which the concept report mentions approvingly because the VFT could not carry heavy freight.
A proposal for improved rail services

Reviving rail services is a good idea, but it must involve an enhancement of our existing system. If the money is available then it ought to be spent on a staged upgrading of this system. A paper by the society for social responsibility in engineering suggests an upgrading of the existing track to allow a technically feasible 250 km/h and extending the railway at 250 km/h standard from Goulburn to Canberra to Wagga with the long overdue electrification of the line. Some deviations from the existing line would be needed to permit the higher speeds but the total investment would be a fraction of that mooted for the VFT and such a program would allow a realistic period for developing the technology needed.

If the program proved itself then track modification and electrification could be extended to Melbourne and travel times could be reduced to 4 or 5 hours-which is realistically the best that the VFT would be likely to achieve. This program would also facilitate fast freight and overnight rail courier services. The best use would be made of the existing track, there would be a minimum of land resumption-by a government authority-and there would be public accountability.
I wouldn't pretend that this program is without its difficulties, the major one is shaking the SRA out of its long sleep but this has to be done anyway and the sooner the better.
Less Haste More Speed

There are some basic assumptions behind the VFT project that will soon be seen as anachronistic. We will soon be forced to realise, if we haven't caught on already, that we need to reassess philosophies of untrammeled growth and development, the high-speed go ahead at any cost thinking that has dominated Western culture. I don't suggest that we all ought to eat only lentils and go to bed at dusk. I am very appreciative of the benefits of our technology and we are going to need all our inventiveness to find solutions to the problems that we have largely made for ourselves through our ignorance. I earlier mentioned the Concorde supersonic passenger plane in passing. A few years ago predictions were that we would all soon be wizzing through the stratosphere in supersonic planes. This has turned out not to be technically or economically feasible. Larger sub-sonic passenger transports were the realistic limit.

We may find that there is a place for faster passenger rail services on the east coast of Australia, especially if fuel shortages raise the cost of other forms of transport and rail efficiencies and services are improved. There is no reason why the catering and communications services mooted for the VFT could not be provided on other rail systems. An emphasis could be placed more on quality of travel rather than merely speed.

We also may have to consider more often whether our journeys are really necessary. I am amazed at the way this project has assumed reality-to the point where many people assume it will go ahead-despite glaring contradictions on finance and technical feasibility and the extraordinary delegation of the land acquisition rights of governments to a private consortium for private profit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dunn need not concern herself about the safety aspects of the very fast train. The very fast train will, in fact, operate with the same amount and sophistication of computer equipment as modern aircraft do, and all the driver will have to do to ensure the safety of the very fast train is to install in his cabin the same safety equipment that air crew now install in the cabins of modern aircraft, that is, a doberman pinscher. Not many people know that. One may well ask, `Why would one put a doberman pinscher in the cockpit of a modern aircraft to ensure safety?'. Why would one, indeed? And as no-one else asked, I had to. Well, the reason is this. The pilot has to feed the dog and the dog has to bite the pilot if he touches the controls. All we have to do is put one of those in the VFT and we will have nothing to worry about. The reason that I rise briefly tonight in the adjournment--
—Is to tell that joke.

—No, that was totally fortuitous. It is to place on record my concern again about the actions of members of the Northern Territory Government-I have, in fact, released a statement tonight on the subject-in regard to their 30 per cent pay claim.
—It is defamatory.

—We have had a bad record unfortunately in the Northern Territory in terms of pay claims for politicians. I remember only too well the headline that appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser the last time politicians in the Northern Territory got a pay claim. The heading was, `Australia's Golden Politicians'. At that stage of the game politicians in the Northern Territory were the highest paid in Australia and, arguably, particularly in terms of backbenchers, the most underworked. As I said before, the obvious example to use is the position of the Government backbenchers who service the town of Alice Springs where four State members of parliament represent 22,000 people. Each member has an average number of 2,200 electors. The Parliament sits on 21 days a year and has no active committee system operating in the recesses. It really is a great deal of money for the amount of work those members do.

SPEECH.PARA: I place on record again the fact that the timing of this pay claim in the Northern Territory is appalling. Politicians should act as politicians. In other words, there should be a political consideration. We in the Northern Territory at the moment are hurting more than those in any other place in Australia because of the pilots strike. There is no question at all that the pilots who are failing to service the Northern Territory will use as a weapon for their identical pay claim the fact that the leaders of government who are busily condemning the strike at the moment have just voted themselves precisely the same pay rise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.12 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: PAPER

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was tabled:
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act-Order 1989-No. L7-Prohibition on export of sheep to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, dated 22 August 1989.
The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government's Phosphate Mining Corporation set aside $6.5 million in the event of mine closure, for the restoration and rehabilitation of large areas of Christmas Island scarred by mining, and did the Government decide to spend only $500,000 on selective rehabilitation.

(2) Is it not a fact that last year's cyclone caused massive damage to the Island's rainforest canopy, that thousands of trees were blown over and many Abbott's Boobies', chicks, fledglings and nesting sites were lost, increasing concern over the long-term survival of the species.
(3) Has the selective rehabilitation of mined areas near nesting concentrations begun.

(4) Is the Department aware that the 1987/88 Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service Annual Report says ``previously in this Report the need to implement a rehabilitation program has been stressed. Not to do so makes almost inevitable the loss of this species of great national and international concern'', if so, what action is being taken.
(5) Has the nursery on the Island been abandoned; if so, what effect will this have and what plans are in train to compensate for this.

(6) Has the Island Administration, the Department or the Government ever received representations about the dangers of Newcastle Disease being imported in live poultry brought to Christmas Island from Singapore and Indonesia.
(7) Have any studies been done on whether Abbott's Booby or the Frigate Bird are susceptible to Newcastle Disease.
(8) What quarantine measures are in place to detect possible importation of Newcastle Disease to Christmas Island.

(9) On 15 March 1988 did the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) tell the Senate he would ``very shortly'' ``almost double'' the Christmas Island National Park, which then covered 17 per cent of the Island.
