(10) What consultations has the Department at this stage undertaken with Christmas Islanders on this extension.

(11) Is it not a fact that the General-Secretary of the Union of Christmas Island Workers (Mr Bennett) wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saying by all means extend the National Park, but do so in consultation with the community.
(12) Did any consultation occur with the community following this letter.

(13) Is it fair to say that this proposal to double the National Park was a fairly arbitrary one and that little consultation, other than with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, occurred on the boundaries.
(14) Is it fair to say that, under this proposal, areas of dubious significance were proposed to be included, while areas which should have been included were excluded.

(15) When referring to doubling the National Park, did Mr Arnaudon say in a minute of 22 March 1988 that ``all significant rainforest is included''; if so, why has the Department been working on quadrupling the size of the Christmas Island National Park to cover approximately 70 per cent of the Island.
(16) Why was it decided that the National Park should be quadrupled, when previously the Minister had been content that it be doubled.
(17) Who suggested and decided the National Park could be quadrupled and when did this happen.

(18) Is it not a fact that, following Senator Richardson's promise to double the Park, the previous Opposition Spokesman on External Territories (Mr Braithwaite) suggested that he personally believed the National Park could be tripled, without causing any problems to mining.
(19) Was the Department and the Minister made aware of this comment, which was reported in the ``Canberra Times''.
(20) On what date was the proposal to double the National Park, which in March 1988 was to be announced very shortly, put in doubt.
(21) What consultations has the Department had on the proposal to quadruple the National Park with Christmas Islanders and, in particular, the Christmas Island Community Council.
(22) Were there any consultations with mining companies on this extension.

(23) Do the new boundaries of the new National Park, as outlined in the Notice under subsection 7 (12) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, published in the Australian on 5 April 1989, contain areas of regrowth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The earlier answer provided by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories to this question, which was published in Hansard on 16 August 1989, pages 212-213, contained the statement, at section 13, that ``The proposed new park boundaries were established on the basis of known research and incorporate all areas identified by an independent consultant in 1985 as wildlife habitat of national or international significance and/or areas of high landscape value. Other areas of the Island subsequently identified in these categories have also been included.' The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has now advised me that the Department's records show that a narrow coastal strip from the general area of Grimes Cave to Smith Point was excluded from the proposed new park boundaries to allow future use of Daniel Roux Cave system if needed for water supply purposes and he has provided the following amended answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the time the Government decided to close the mining operation on Christmas Island it made $500,000 available for rehabilitation of areas which would afford the Abbott's Booby the greatest protection as the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island had not set aside any rehabilitation funds.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Government's rehabilitation program has commenced with re-establishment of an Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service plant nursery on the Island. Plants are being propagated in the nursery and will be replanted in previously cleared areas of the Island focusing initially on areas affording the Abbott's Booby the greatest protection.
(4) Yes. The Government's conservation strategy for the Island which focuses on the preservation of the Island's rare flora and fauna is being implemented. The strategy includes:
a Commonwealth funded $0.5 million programme for the selective rehabilitation of rainforest clearings to promote breeding success of the endangered Abbott's Booby;
a major extension to the Christmas Island National Park, (which will increase the size of the present Park to cover between 60-70% of the Island);
the development of an appropriate plan for Park management; and
land which will remain outside the new Park boundaries will be managed in sympathy with Park management objectives.
(5) See (3) above.
(6) Yes.

(8) Since July this year, in accordance with Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service policy and under the provisions of the Territory's Prohibited Imports Ordinance 1988, no eggs, poultry or poultry products are permitted entry into Christmas Island unless they are sourced from the Australian mainland.

(9) The Senate Hansard of 15 March 1988 records ``I am considering a further extension of the national park, which will almost double its size. Hopefully, I can announce that and a plan of management for the enlarged area very shortly.'' At the time of formal notification the agreed park boundaries exceeded the initial estimate quoted by the Minister.
(10) No formal consultation had occurred.

(11) Mr Bennett wrote to the Prime Minister on 9 May 1988 outlining his concern that the possible extension to the National Park may impact adversely on the proposals to reopen the mining industry. In the same letter Mr Bennett also requested that the local community be given the opportunity to make submissions on the proposed new boundaries.

(12) The former Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, replied to Mr Bennett on behalf of the Prime Minister on 2 September 1988. In his response Mr Punch informed Mr Bennett that representations on the proposed new boundaries would be called for from interested organisations and the public as required under Section 7 (12) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975.

(13) The proposed new park boundaries were established on the basis of known research and incorporate areas identified by an independent consultant in 1985 as wildlife habitat of national or international significance and/or areas of high landscape value, except for a narrow coastal strip from the general area of Grimes Cave to Smith Point. The Department's records show that this area was excluded to allow future use of Daniel Roux Cave system if needed for water supply purposes. Other areas of the Island subsequently identified as having national or international significance or high landscape value have also been included. Areas of the Island of high local conservation value although not included in the park extension will be managed in sympathy with the park and are areas where some tourist development could proceed. These boundaries will be kept under review.
(14) It is considered that all areas included within the park boundaries were justified. Further areas which are currently excluded will be reconsidered for inclusion at some time in the future.
(15) See (13) above.
(16) See (13) above.

(17) In July 1988 the proposal to extend the National Park was agreed between the Minister for the Arts and Territories, (Hon Clyde Holding MP), and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, (Senator Richardson), on the basis of a joint submission from my Department and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

(18) The Department has no record of any such comment by Mr Braithwaite. Mr Braithwaite was quoted in the ``Canberra Times'' on 22 March 1988 as saying that a coalition government would rehabilitate areas already mined and would be prepared to triple the area of rainforest currently included as national park. The article does not report Mr Braithwaite as saying that he would treble the size of the National Park. In fact the same article goes on to suggest that the Government should not limit private mining concerns to clearing stockpiles and that the Government should be prepared to allow the clearing of an additional 80 hectares of rainforest. In his media release of 21 March 1988 Mr Braithwaite does not rule out the need to clear additional areas of rainforest for a future mining operation.
(19) Officers of the Department were aware of the article, however, the Department does not have any record of the ``Canberra Times'' article specifically being brought to the Minister's attention.
(20) See (17) above.

(21) Prior to formal notification in April 1989, the proposed extension to the Park was informally raised by the Administrator with local community members and representatives both individually and in Community Consultative Group meetings. The formal consultation process has now commenced with the public being invited to provide comments as part of the formal notification process under the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service Act. Information on the proposed extension is available on the Island in English, Chinese and Malay. The Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service will fully consider any comments before final gazettal occurs.

(22) On 11 February 1988 the former Minister for Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch MP stated in a media release that the Government would not allow any further rainforest clearing as this was not consistent with the Government's long term strategy for the Island. Potential mine operators were advised that mining was to be conducted only in previously mined and cleared areas of the Island.
